('26', 0, 1, 2, 47) 1. LETTER TO JOSEPH J. GHOSE
('26', 0, 2, 3, 76) [Tuesday, January 24, 1922] 1
('26', 0, 3, 4, 106) DEAR MR. GHOSE 2, I thank you for your letter.
('26', 0, 3, 5, 153) I have just received the following wire from my son to whom I sent your letter as soon as I got it:
('26', 0, 4, 6, 253) Ghose’s letter astounding.
('26', 0, 4, 7, 280) Allegations false.
('26', 0, 4, 8, 299) Allahabad volunteers best behaved.9 Is there likelihood of your having been misinformed?
('26', 0, 4, 9, 388) It is likely that my boy has been misled.
('26', 0, 4, 10, 430) I cannot imagine his deceiving me.
('26', 0, 4, 11, 465) I should, with your assistance, like to reach the bottom of this difference of opinion.
('26', 0, 4, 12, 553) I may add that my boy is very careful and his judgement is as a rule sound.
('26', 0, 4, 13, 629) I believe too that he thoroughly understands the spirit of the struggle.
('26', 0, 4, 14, 702) Will you not see him and discuss the matter with him?
('26', 0, 4, 15, 756) I am asking him to meet you.
('26', 0, 4, 16, 785) I am not disposed to stop all picketing.
('26', 0, 4, 17, 826) I think it has moral value if it is absolutely peaceful.
('26', 0, 4, 18, 883) You had certainly a perfect right to punish the boys who did not obey you.
('26', 0, 4, 19, 958) And boys who disobey must take the risk of being rusticated.
('26', 0, 4, 20, 1019) I am sorry you are having all this trouble.
('26', 0, 6, 21, 1063) From a photostat: S.N. 7656
('26', 0, 7, 22, 1091) 2. LETTER TO DEVDAS GANDHI
('26', 0, 8, 23, 1118) Tuesday [January 24, 1922] 3
('26', 0, 9, 24, 1147) DEVDAS, I have your telegrams.
('26', 0, 9, 25, 1178) That Sherwani has been struck off the rolls is quite welcome.
('26', 0, 9, 26, 1240) After all, he is not going to practise until we have the reins of Government in our own hands.
('26', 0, 9, 27, 1335) I have sent a copy of your telegram to Ghose.
('26', 0, 9, 28, 1381) You may see him by appointment and explain to him the whole thing.
('26', 0, 9, 29, 1448) I send you a copy of the letter I have written to him.
('26', 0, 9, 30, 1503) We do not want to hide any of our faults.
('26', 0, 10, 31, 1545) 1 From Ghose’s reply dated January 31, 1922 (S.N. 7810) 2 Joseph J. Ghose; then Head Master, Modern High School, Allahabad 3 The news of Sherwani having been struck off the rolls was wired to Gandhiji by the addressee on January 23. The Tuesday following was January 24.

('26', 1, 4, 6, 2021) 3. LETTER TO C. VIJAYARAGHAVACHARIAR
('26', 1, 5, 7, 2058) SABARMATI, January 25, 1922
('26', 1, 6, 8, 2086) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter.
('26', 1, 6, 9, 2119) I still think that the Conference 1 has done much good.
('26', 1, 6, 10, 2175) It has cleared the air and defined our position as never before.
('26', 1, 6, 11, 2240) Sir Sankaran’s 2 action will be forgotten.
('26', 1, 6, 12, 2283) But the attitude of non co operators will, I think, be remembered to their credit.
('26', 1, 7, 13, 2366) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI
('26', 1, 8, 14, 2396) From the original: C. Vijayaraghavachariar Papers.
('26', 1, 8, 15, 2447) Courtesy: Nehru Memorial Museum and Library
('26', 1, 9, 16, 2491) 4. NOTES
('26', 1, 10, 17, 2500) AN ENGLISH LADY BLESSES
('26', 1, 11, 18, 2524) “An English lady” who sends her name and address, writing from Calcutta, says:
('26', 1, 12, 19, 2603) It elevates one to see the admirable way in which Mr. Gandhi shows us the truth and opens our eyes to the atrocious things that our so called noble Government are doing daily.
('26', 1, 12, 20, 2779) The letter that an “English missionary” has written is admirable.
('26', 1, 12, 21, 2845) 3 I am afraid, there are many more like her, but are too proud to come forward and acknowledge the noble work that Mr. Gandhi is doing.
('26', 1, 12, 22, 2981) His patience and work are like the spring that lies hidden far below.
('26', 1, 12, 23, 3051) No matter what the world may preach, God will give him a harvest greater than he expects.
('26', 1, 12, 24, 3141) It is only those who work in silence reap the harvest.
('26', 1, 12, 25, 3196) Millions are
('26', 1, 13, 26, 3209) 1 The Leaders’ Conference, also known as the Malaviya Conference, was held in Bombay on January 14 and 15, 1922; vide “Speech at Leaders Conference, Bombay” , 14 1 1922 ; 15 1 1922. 2 Sir Sankaran Nair, Chairman of the Leaders’ Conference, quit it on January, 15, when the Committee appointed by the Conference held meeting in Bombay.
('26', 1, 13, 27, 3544) For Gandhiji’s interview regarding this, vide “Women’s Part”, 15 12 1921. 3 Vide “Notes”, 12 1 1922, under the sub title “In God’s Hands”.

('26', 2, 1, 2, 3730) watching and judging him.
('26', 2, 1, 3, 3756) But there is One above all, watching and judging each struggle in his daily life, and when his toil and struggle are over, his work and name will live for ever.
('26', 2, 1, 4, 3917) His name will be worshipped by millions who have gained freedom by his hard work.
('26', 2, 1, 5, 3999) God bless and spare him and his tear wife, and give them both health and strength to go on until this struggle is over, which will not be long.
('26', 2, 1, 6, 4143) It is not without hesitation that I share this letter with the reader.
('26', 2, 1, 7, 4214) Although written impersonally, it is so personal.
('26', 2, 1, 8, 4264) But I hope there is no pride in me.
('26', 2, 1, 9, 4300) I feel I recognize fully my weakness.
('26', 2, 1, 10, 4338) But my faith in God and His strength and love is unshakable.
('26', 2, 1, 11, 4399) I am like clay in the Potter’s hands.
('26', 2, 1, 12, 4437) And so in the language of the Gita, the compliments are laid at His feet.
('26', 2, 1, 13, 4511) The blessings such as these, I confess, are strength giving.
('26', 2, 1, 14, 4572) But my reason for publishing this letter is to encourage every true non co operator in the non violent path he is pursuing, and to wean the false ones from their error.
('26', 2, 1, 15, 4741) This is a terribly true struggle.
('26', 2, 1, 16, 4775) It is not based on hate though men of hate are in it.
('26', 2, 1, 17, 4829) It is a struggle which is based on love, pure and undefiled.
('26', 2, 1, 18, 4890) If I felt any hatetowards Englishmen or those who in their blindness are associated with the blind administrators, I have the courage to retire from the struggle.
('26', 2, 1, 19, 5053) A man who has the least faith in God and His mercy, which is His justice, cannot hate men, though at the same time he must hate their evil ways.
('26', 2, 1, 20, 5198) But having abundant evil in himself and ever standing in need of charity, he must not hate those in whom he sees evil.
('26', 2, 1, 21, 5317) This struggle, therefore, is intended to make friends with Englishmen and the whole world.
('26', 2, 1, 22, 5408) It cannot be by false flattery, but by plainly telling Englishmen of India that their ways are evil and that we will not co operate with them so long as they retain them.
('26', 2, 1, 23, 5579) If we are wrong in so thinking, God will forgive us, for we mean no ill to them and we are prepared to suffer at their hands.
('26', 2, 1, 24, 5705) If we are right, as sure as I am writing this, our suffering will open their eyes even as it has opened those of “an English lady”.
('26', 2, 1, 25, 5837) Nor is she the only one.
('26', 2, 1, 26, 5862) I meet Englishmen during my travels.
('26', 2, 1, 27, 5899) I do not know them, but they greet me cordially and wish me success and pass on.
('26', 2, 1, 28, 5980) True, as against scores who thus bless me, there are hundreds that curse me.
('26', 2, 1, 29, 6057) These curses also I am bidden to lay at His feet.
('26', 2, 1, 30, 6107) They come from ignorance.
('26', 2, 1, 31, 6133) Many Englishmen and even some Indians consider me and my activity to be mischievous.
('26', 2, 1, 32, 6218) Non co operators must tolerate even these.
('26', 2, 1, 33, 6261) If they get angry and retaliate, they lose the battle, whereas if they suffer, they win without fail and without delay.
('26', 2, 1, 34, 6381) The whole of the delay is due, !I am convinced, to our shortcomings.
('26', 2, 1, 35, 6450) We have not been always non violent.
('26', 2, 1, 36, 6487) We have, contrary to our pledge, harboured ill will.
('26', 2, 1, 37, 6540) Our opponents, the English administrators, their co operators, the talukdars, the rajas have distrusted us and have felt afraid of us.
('26', 2, 1, 38, 6675) We are bound by our pledge
('26', 3, 0, 1, 6702) 4 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('26', 3, 1, 2, 6742) to clothe them with the fullest protection.
('26', 3, 1, 3, 6786) Whilst we may not help them in the exploitation of the poor and the weak, we must not harm them.
('26', 3, 1, 4, 6883) Though they are in a hopeless minority, they must be made to feel safer in our midst than they are behind the bayonets.
('26', 3, 1, 5, 7003) If we were in a hopeless minority, ours would be an easier position—we would long ago have proved our faith.
('26', 3, 1, 6, 7112) As it is, our numbers embarrass us.
('26', 3, 1, 7, 7148) The dissatisfaction with the present regime is common to us; but not the burning faith in non violence.
('26', 3, 1, 8, 7252) We must not be satisfied till we have rendered impossible the disgraceful scenes that took place in Madras.
('26', 3, 1, 9, 7360) We must not, with non violence on our lips, obstruct court proceedings.
('26', 3, 1, 10, 7432) Either we seek imprisonment, or we do not.
('26', 3, 1, 11, 7475) If we do, we must let the Government take us away as fast as they wish.
('26', 3, 1, 12, 7547) The struggle is prolonged to the extent that we fail to understand the implications of non violence.
('26', 3, 1, 13, 7648) ADMITTED AS A BOARDER If anyone has any doubt about the true inwardness of the struggle, I hope the following 1 from Babu Prasanna Kumar Sen will help to dispel it.
('26', 3, 1, 14, 7813) At the time of being sentenced, he was Secretary of the District Congress Committee of Chittagong.
('26', 3, 2, 15, 7912) I have been admitted as a boarder in His Majesty’s Hotel for two years and a half.
('26', 3, 2, 16, 7995) During the last 4 or 5 years I was always thinking of bidding adieu to my profession as a lawyer .
('26', 3, 2, 17, 8094) and retiring to Hrishikesh in the Himalayas for spending the rest of my days there in religious pursuits as a recluse.
('26', 3, 2, 18, 8213) So long I could not .
('26', 3, 3, 19, 8235) Now the All Merciful Father has showered His immense blessings on me by suddenly taking me off from the midst of worldly bustles and vouchsafing unto me complete rest within the prison walls .
('26', 3, 4, 20, 8428) I am now fully convinced, my dear Mahatmaji, that this temporary rest will .
('26', 3, 4, 21, 8505) qualify me for the attainment of the highest object of human life—the eternal nirvana.
('26', 3, 4, 22, 8592) I assure the reader that Prasanna Babu’s wish to attain supreme happiness in jail is not an idle dream.
('26', 3, 4, 23, 8696) I know Hrishikesh.
('26', 3, 4, 24, 8715) It certainly holds blackguards on earth as it holds saints.
('26', 3, 4, 25, 8775) I know the prison life.
('26', 3, 4, 26, 8799) Only a pitch black wall separated one of the greatest murderers of South Africa and me.
('26', 3, 4, 27, 8887) We were both in isolation cells by design, for we were both considered dangerous to society.
('26', 3, 4, 28, 8980) I had to suffer most in that cell for nearly two months.
('26', 3, 4, 29, 9037) But I learnt most when I suffered most.
('26', 3, 4, 30, 9077) It was the time of the fattest harvest.
('26', 3, 4, 31, 9117) Whilst the suffering lasted, it was difficult to bear.
('26', 3, 4, 32, 9172) But it is now one of the richest treasures in life’s memory.
('26', 3, 4, 33, 9233) We have today converted the jails into heavens of
('26', 3, 5, 34, 9283) 1 Only excerpts reproduced here

('26', 4, 1, 2, 9362) refuge for liberty loving men.
('26', 4, 1, 3, 9393) They can be easily turned into abodes for attaining nirvana.
('26', 4, 1, 4, 9454) The prison cell where Socrates drank the poison cup was undoubtedly the way to bliss.
('26', 4, 1, 5, 9540) He lives today through the memory of that ineffaceable scene.
('26', 4, 1, 6, 9602) “SWARAJ ASHRAM”
('26', 4, 2, 7, 9618) Prasanna Babu pictures the jail as a means to attain the highest state.
('26', 4, 2, 8, 9690) Babu Tarun Ram Phooken calls his jail “Swaraj Ashram.” Sjt.
('26', 4, 2, 9, 9750) Phooken is an Assam leader.
('26', 4, 2, 10, 9778) I may inform the reader that he is a first class shot and a fine sportsman.
('26', 4, 2, 11, 9854) But he has learnt the secret of suffering.
('26', 4, 2, 12, 9897) Writing from the Silchar Jail he says:
('26', 4, 3, 13, 9936) I think I was doing enough mischief from the Government point of view to justify my arrest and imprisonment.
('26', 4, 3, 14, 10045) I am obliged to you and alsoto the officials concerned for the peace and safety secured for me here.
('26', 4, 3, 15, 10146) I trust you will soon be able to secure peace and safety for those outside the jail.
('26', 4, 3, 16, 10231) We will accept them when they come in all humility but, I hope not in humiliation.
('26', 4, 3, 17, 10314) We should seek no temporary peace, but permanent peace based upon equality and on the principle of common participation for common benefit, for, I believe that sort of peace only can be lasting.
('26', 4, 3, 18, 10509) Peace on any other terms is sure to leave a sting behind which will be beneficial neither to the governed nor to the governors.
('26', 4, 4, 19, 10637) If we play the game manfully, honourably and without malice or bitterness, it does not much matter, in my humble opinion, whether we win or lose; for selfless sufferings, if there be any, will not and cannot be lost eternally.
('26', 4, 4, 20, 10864) The letter is countersigned by the Superintendent of the jail.
('26', 4, 4, 21, 10927) Motilalji warns me from his hotel in Lucknow against embarking upon any premature and patched up peace.
('26', 4, 4, 22, 11031) He is willing to be in jail indefinitely.
('26', 4, 4, 23, 11073) There are many Swaraj Ashrams cropping up in our midst.
('26', 4, 4, 24, 11129) But there are none so true as the jails.
('26', 4, 4, 25, 11170) They are built not with money but with stout hearts.
('26', 4, 4, 26, 11223) IN BURMA The nationalist wave is spreading.
('26', 4, 4, 27, 11267) I have made room for two articles on Burma.
('26', 4, 4, 28, 11311) Swami Shraddhanandji 1 and Mr. Abbas Tyabji gave me glowing accounts of the national awakening in that land of elephants and wonders.
('26', 4, 4, 29, 11445) The spoliation of Burma by the British is a sad chapter in their sad history.
('26', 4, 4, 30, 11523) And sadder still to me is the fact that Indians have not hesitated to take part in the spoil.
('26', 4, 4, 31, 11617) I have never been able to take pride in the fact that Burma has been made part of British
('26', 4, 5, 32, 11707) 1 Mahatma Munshiram (1856 1926); later known as Shraddhananda; natio nalist leader of Arya Samaj; took prominent part in public activities in Delhi and the Punjab
('26', 5, 0, 1, 11870) 6 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('26', 5, 1, 2, 11910) It never was and never should be.
('26', 5, 1, 3, 11944) The Burmese have a civilization of their own.
('26', 5, 1, 4, 11990) The Buddhism of Burma is quite different from the Buddhism of India, as European Christianity is totally different from Christ’s Christianity.
('26', 5, 1, 5, 12133) I wish to say nothing in disparagement of either.
('26', 5, 1, 6, 12183) The message of Jesus was too strong for the European mentality.
('26', 5, 1, 7, 12247) The message of the Buddha was too strong for the Burmese mentality.
('26', 5, 1, 8, 12315) Both the nations have profited by the messages they received to the extent of their receptivity.
('26', 5, 1, 9, 12412) But there is no doubt that Europe has still to understand the deep meaning and the mysteries of the mission of Jesus, as the Burmese of the Buddha.
('26', 5, 1, 10, 12560) This the latter can only do, if they are enabled to progress along their own lines.
('26', 5, 1, 11, 12644) It is, therefore, a matter of the keenest joyto me that there is a wonderful awakening in Burma.
('26', 5, 1, 12, 12741) There is no doubt that the Burmese, if they persist ill their effort, can solve their simple problem much more quickly than we can with diversity of bewildering complications.
('26', 5, 2, 13, 12917) IN AMBALA
('26', 5, 3, 14, 12927) The Punjab is truly working wonders.
('26', 5, 3, 15, 12964) The Sikh must take and they fully deserve, the credit for producing the non violent atmosphere.
('26', 5, 3, 16, 13060) Their pertinacity, their amazing sacrifice at Nankana Saheb, 1 the imprisonment of their best leaders and the Govenment’s complete surrender, have filled the Punjab with pride and hope and the spirit of sacrifice and non violence.
('26', 5, 3, 17, 13291) The reader will not, therefore, be surprised to read the following from Lala Duni Chand of Ambala: 2
('26', 5, 4, 18, 13392) Lala Duni Chand has nursed Ambala for years.
('26', 5, 4, 19, 13437) He had, before non co operation days, a very lucrative practice of which he used to devote the largest part to the many public works which he had initiated.
('26', 5, 4, 20, 13594) He had, therefore, no difficulty in getting round him a band of self sacrificing young men to work with him.
('26', 5, 4, 21, 13703) He is now having them to go to jail without any difficulty.
('26', 5, 4, 22, 13763) Swaraj is the visible immediate fruit of sacrifice.
('26', 5, 4, 23, 13815) The citizens of Ambala are, therefore, feeling the advent of swaraj.
('26', 5, 4, 24, 13884) The awakening among the women of the Punjab as elsewhere is an event whose value we are not at the present moment able to measure adequately.
('26', 5, 4, 25, 14026) If the truth is to be told, it was Mrs. Duni Chand who paved the way for Lala Duni Chand’s sacrifice.
('26', 5, 4, 26, 14128) She it was who prepared him for it.
('26', 5, 4, 27, 14164) Nor is Mrs. Duni Chand’s the only instance.
('26', 5, 4, 28, 14208) I have the privilege of knowing several sisters who are responsible for their husband’s greatness.

('26', 6, 1, 2, 14530) IN ROHTAK As in Ambala, so in Rohtak.
('26', 6, 1, 3, 14568) The pages of Young India have made the public familiar with the sacrifice of Lala Sham Lal.
('26', 6, 1, 4, 14660) Only his was undertaken in spite of his wife and parents.
('26', 6, 1, 5, 14718) He had to battle against tremendous difficulties.
('26', 6, 1, 6, 14768) But he bore then all town.
('26', 6, 1, 7, 14795) He has now the honour of being arrested in common with other friends.
('26', 6, 1, 8, 14865) These men are the pride of their country.
('26', 6, 1, 9, 14907) They are not fanatics.
('26', 6, 1, 10, 14930) They are hard headed business men who have given up their businesses at the call of country and religion.
('26', 6, 1, 11, 15036) They are no breakersof peace.
('26', 6, 1, 12, 15066) They are the keepers of it.
('26', 6, 1, 13, 15094) And a government must be on the very verge of bankruptcy that finds it necessary to lock up such citizens.
('26', 6, 2, 14, 15201) IN AMRITSAR
('26', 6, 3, 15, 15213) Lala Girdhari Lal, President, District Congress Committee, Maulana Mahomed Daud Gaznavi, President, Khilafat Committee, Master Sunam Rai, President, City Congress Committee, and Sardar Ravell Singh, President, District Sikh League, were arrested and are now convicted because they had the audacity to arrange a public meeting in the teeth of the Seditious Meetings proclamation.
('26', 6, 3, 16, 15592) Amritsar has already contributed a good number.
('26', 6, 3, 17, 15640) Now all the presidents have been taken away.
('26', 6, 3, 18, 15685) They have got two years’ rigorous imprisonment each and Rs. 500 fine each, or three months more in default.
('26', 6, 3, 19, 15793) They have all been taken to Mianwali Jail.
('26', 6, 3, 20, 15836) The beauty of it is that no matter where you look, no Congress Committee is without its officers.
('26', 6, 3, 21, 15934) The people have learnt that in a well managed organization the officers live for ever, though individual holders of office may die, be imprisoned, or desert.
('26', 6, 3, 22, 16092) The idea itself is really magnificent connoting as it does the unity of man and his estate.

('26', 6, 7, 29, 16574) It will be impossible to allow any incitement to pass unnoticed, or to tolerate any dabbling in this form of mischief by Government servants or pensioners.
('26', 6, 7, 30, 16730) It will, unfortunately, be necessary to add substantially to the

('26', 7, 0, 1, 16926) 8 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('26', 7, 1, 2, 16966) burdens of the province by the entertainment of such additional police and executive staffs as may be necessary for the maintenance of order.
('26', 7, 1, 3, 17108) The notice argues:
('26', 7, 2, 4, 17127) Successful, it (civil disobedience) could only be an education of the criminally inclined among the population in methods which they would be naturally ready to put into practice against any kind of government, present or future; unsuccessful, it could only throw back the course of progress and establish well founded doubts of the political maturity of thosewho deliberately introduced so dangerous a poison into the veins 1 of their motherland.
('26', 7, 2, 5, 17575) The writer of the notice has overargued the Government case and thus overreached himself.
('26', 7, 2, 6, 17665) The notice has merely resulted in stiffening the backs of the people.
('26', 7, 2, 7, 17735) In the first place, civil disobedience is not and cannot be instilled into the minds of the criminally inclined people.
('26', 7, 2, 8, 17855) The educated class, the women, and students are hardly criminally inclined.
('26', 7, 2, 9, 17931) And even the peasantry cannot be classed among “the criminally inclined”.
('26', 7, 2, 10, 18005) If the people had not learnt to be peaceful, they would not have stood the assaults and insults that Dr. Gokul Chand Narang and his fellow commissioners have so graphically described in their able and closely reasoned report on the allegations of assaults 2 committed by the police on the 13th day of December 1921 in Lahore.
('26', 7, 2, 11, 18331) Secondly, the civil disobedience is not aimed at all Government, present or future.
('26', 7, 2, 12, 18415) It is aimed only at the present Government which has criminally defied the will of a whole people.
('26', 7, 2, 13, 18514) Thirdly, why is it mischievous or poisonous to tell people not to obey a Government which has systematically emasculated the people?
('26', 7, 2, 14, 18647) Are the people to continue to be party to humiliations imposed upon them by an irresponsible bureaucracy?
('26', 7, 2, 15, 18753) But let us look at Dr. Gokul Chand Narang’s report.
('26', 7, 2, 16, 18805) In my opinion, it provides abundant justification for disciplined civil disobedience, if the people are to live as free men.
('26', 7, 2, 17, 18930) The Committee has found that: 1. The volunteers were carrying on peaceful work.
('26', 7, 2, 18, 19010) 2. The police “with long brass bound lathis” suddenly came down upon the volunteers and the public and belaboured them without warning.
('26', 7, 2, 19, 19146) 3. The volunteers on refusing to disperse in spite of injuries received by them were arrested, discharged and rearrested and after a few hours’ detention about one o’clock at night were deliberately set
('26', 7, 3, 20, 19349) 1 The source has “views.” 2 Vide “Notes”, 22 12 1921, under the sub title, “Remarkable Proof”.
('26', 8, 0, 1, 19444) VOL. 26 : 24 JANUARY, 1922 12 NOVEMBER, 1923 9
('26', 8, 1, 2, 19491) down at separate places far away from their homes.
('26', 8, 1, 3, 19542) 4. The volunteers were filthily abused by the custodians.
('26', 8, 1, 4, 19600) How are the people to deal with such legalized criminality?
('26', 8, 1, 5, 19660) Are they meekly to submit to it or are they as self respecting men to disregard authority by disobeying orders?
('26', 8, 1, 6, 19772) If the things Dr. Gokul Chand Narang has described happen in a city like Lahore, what must be the plight of poor villagers?
('26', 8, 1, 7, 19896) If the newspaper reading public were not utterly ignorant of the village life and indifferent to the hardships of villagers, the fetish of law and order in whose name unspeakable horrors are perpetrated would have been destroyed long ago.
('26', 8, 1, 8, 20135) The campaign of civil disobedience is designed to evolve true law and order which the public will consider it a privilege and a duty to obey.
('26', 8, 1, 9, 20277) IN BENGAL Things are no better in Bengal.

('26', 20, 1, 2, 52791) 8. NON PAYMENT OF TAXES
('26', 20, 2, 3, 52815) The idea of non payment of taxes is in the air.
('26', 20, 2, 4, 52863) The Andhras have made us more familiar with the cry than any other part of India.
('26', 20, 2, 5, 52945) Whilst the Congress has given provincial autonomy to every province, I have ventured to warn the provinces against embarking upon a non payment campaign till I had tried the experiment myself in some area under my own supervision.
('26', 20, 2, 6, 53176) 1 I abide by that warning.
('26', 20, 2, 7, 53203) I must also draw attention to the fact that we are not to start offensive civil disobedience till the 31st instant, or if it is sooner, till the Malaviya Conference Committee knows the result of its negotiations and knows that the proposed Round Table Conference is not to come off.
('26', 20, 2, 8, 53486) Therefore, any suspension of taxes at the present moment can only be regarded as temporary holding back pending the result of the negotiations carried on by that Committee.
('26', 20, 2, 9, 53659) But 31st January will be soon upon us.
('26', 20, 2, 10, 53698) And it is necessary to consider the question of nonpayment of taxes in all its bearings.
('26', 20, 2, 11, 53787) On this subject a friend who is in deep sympathy with the national movement, and who is a fairly accurate student of it, thus expresses his apprehensions:
('26', 20, 3, 12, 53942) I have often thought to what extent the non violent non co operation movement transgresses the religious limits, when it embarks on civil disobedience in the form of non payment of taxes.
('26', 20, 3, 13, 54130) I look upon the non violent non co operation as essentially a spiritual movement.
('26', 20, 3, 14, 54212) I know Mr. Gandhi does not think it otherwise.
('26', 20, 3, 15, 54259) Will not the programme of the non payment of taxes transgress the religious limit and lead to violence and bring into the movement people who are not as yet saturated with the principle of non violence?
('26', 20, 3, 16, 54462) Is not Mr. Gandhi holding out, however unconsciously, a material bait for his spiritual movement by which he means to conquer the Government?
('26', 20, 3, 17, 54604) Recent events have shown that the temper of violence and the belief in violence are not eliminated from our character in the mass.
('26', 20, 3, 18, 54735) And, therefore, it would be a leap in the dark fraught with disastrous consequences to carry out the programme of civil disobedience in the form of non payment of taxes.
('26', 20, 3, 19, 54905) I am, therefore, most anxious that Mr. Gandhi should not begin civil disobedience in this form as yet.
('26', 20, 3, 20, 55008) The validity of the objection lies in the statement that the non payment campaign will bring into the movement peoplewho are not as yet saturated with the principle of non violence.
('26', 20, 3, 21, 55190) This is very true, and because it is true, non payment does “hold out a material

('26', 21, 1, 2, 55360) It follows, therefore, that we must not resort to non payment because of the possibility of a ready response.

('26', 21, 1, 21, 57573) They will not do all these things after swaraj, if they will not do them now.
('26', 21, 1, 22, 57651) They must be taught to know that the practice of these national virtues means swaraj.
('26', 21, 1, 23, 57737) Thus civil non payment of taxes is a privilege capable of being exercised only after rigorous training.

('26', 27, 1, 2, 71227) 11. REPRESSION IN ANDHRA
('26', 27, 2, 3, 71252) By the time this is in print, probably all eyes will be turned towards Andhra Desh.
('26', 27, 2, 4, 71336) Its plucky people are preparing to offer mass civil disobedience in certain tahsils and are consequently deferring payment of tax for the time being.
('26', 27, 2, 5, 71486) I have warned the Andhra Committee that if the Round Table Conference comes off, those who are deferring payment of taxes due will have immediately to pay them and that they should prepare for the difficult fight only if the people are thoroughly disciplined for nonviolence and are otherwise able to conform to the conditions named by the All India Congress Committee at Delhi.
('26', 27, 2, 6, 71865) 1 Mr. Venkatappayya, however, informs me that the people are disciplined and ready and that they can fulfil the conditions laid down.
('26', 27, 2, 7, 71999) The Government of Madras are evidently seized with nervous fear over these suspensions.
('26', 27, 2, 8, 72087) They are drafting additional police to Guntur and making demonstrations.
('26', 27, 2, 9, 72160) They are suspending the operation of the ordinary method of tax collection and have threatened to adopt a summary procedure.
('26', 27, 2, 10, 72285) They are reported even to be arming themselves with extraordinary powers.
('26', 27, 2, 11, 72359) In those circumstances, I offer no apology for presenting the readers of Young India with the following report 2 of repression received from the Secretary of the Provincial Committee.
('26', 27, 2, 12, 72543) The report covers the period between 3rd January to 15th January.
('26', 27, 2, 13, 72609) The report enables the reader to understand the inwardness of the movement and the measure of sacrifice the Andhra people are preparing for.
('26', 27, 2, 14, 72750) May Got give them courage, powers of endurance and wisdom to do the right thing at the right time.

('26', 28, 2, 4, 73257) I shall be back here in a week, maybe a month, or a year, or perhaps I may not return at all.

('26', 29, 4, 8, 75653) From the discussions about a settlement which took place in the two Houses of the Central Legislature, we can see that our position and that of the Government are as far apart as the North Pole and the South.
('26', 29, 4, 9, 75862) This is precisely why I have said that negotiations with the Government at this juncture are useless.

('26', 30, 1, 3, 77729) The reason is not far to seek.

('26', 30, 2, 12, 78563) 14. ENROLMENT OF VOLUNTEERS
('26', 30, 3, 13, 78591) It is observed that the work of enrolling volunteers is not going on as vigorously as it ought to be.
('26', 30, 3, 14, 78693) The Provincial Congress Committee office does not overflow with candidates wishing to be enrolled as volunteers, as its ticket counter was raided during the Congress Week.
('26', 30, 3, 15, 78865) There used to be, such a demand for tickets for admission to the meetings of the Subjects Committee that the President and the Secretary went almost crazy.
('26', 30, 3, 16, 79021) Whom should they oblige and whom not?
('26', 30, 3, 17, 79059) Why should not enrolment of volunteers, too, proceed with the same speed?
('26', 30, 3, 18, 79133) Some say that if the condition regarding khadi is omitted, enrolment will be faster.
('26', 30, 3, 19, 79218) Personally, I do not believe that it will be so.
('26', 30, 3, 20, 79267) No one who wishes to enrol himself as a volunteer will object to khadi.
('26', 30, 3, 21, 79339) It can never be that a volunteer who offers to take a pledge to be ready to die will hesitate to wear khadi or that he will not buy khadi worth Rs. 5 or Rs. 10, if necessary.
('26', 30, 3, 22, 79514) A man will even borrow this amount and become a volunteer.
('26', 30, 3, 23, 79573) Do not some men incur debts in order to indulge their addictions?
('26', 30, 3, 24, 79639) Why, then, should it not become an addiction with us to go and enrol ourselves as volunteers?
('26', 30, 3, 25, 79733) Some say that, if the pledge about untouchability is omitted, a large number will come forward to be enrolled.
('26', 30, 3, 26, 79844) This, too, is

('26', 31, 1, 4, 80028) We cannot enter the heaven of swaraj, leaving the untouchables behind.
('26', 31, 1, 5, 80099) This objection, however, merely illustrates the saying: “Unwilling to dance, one finds fault with the courtyard.” Moreover, neither I nor even the Working Committee has the power to grant exemptions from conditions.
('26', 31, 1, 6, 80315) The resolution was passed by the Congress and can be modified by it alone.
('26', 31, 1, 7, 80390) And I for one regard the very idea of getting it modified as cowardice.
('26', 31, 1, 8, 80462) Again, every condition included in the pledge is a matter of principle.

('26', 31, 1, 16, 81575) Only those who are prepared to fulfil in toto the conditions of the pledge should register their names, no matter if their number is small.
('26', 31, 1, 17, 81715) A few sincere people may by and by become many.

('26', 31, 2, 21, 82080) 15. GOVERNMENT’S CIVILITY

('26', 32, 1, 2, 82339) The Government knows that there is the possibility of a real struggle in Bardoli.
('26', 32, 1, 3, 82421) The Collector, therefore, has issued an “explanation”, which is interesting.
('26', 32, 1, 4, 82498) The Government could have called it a “notification”, instead of giving it the civilized title of “explanation”.

('26', 32, 1, 12, 83179) If, however, the language of the explanation has been chosen by an English officer, and deliberately, I regard the fact as an important change and as an auspicious beginning for our struggle.
('26', 32, 1, 13, 83371) It is not a small thing that both the parties can fight, standing firm on their ground and yet with courtesy and without ceasing to be civilized.
('26', 32, 1, 14, 83517) We would like such a fight to go on for ever.

('26', 33, 0, 1, 84726) 34 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('26', 33, 1, 2, 84767) While welcoming this explanation, I merely wish to say that not a single Patidar of the Bardoli taluka has been kept in the dark.
('26', 33, 1, 3, 84897) All men and women have been told that the Government 1. can sell the entire crop, 2. can give away for a song a crop worth lakhs, 3. can remove even cattle, and household utensils, 4. can confiscate even Inami lands, 5. can imprison people, 6. can cut off railway, telegraphic and postal communications, surround the Bardoli taluka, and try to wear out the people by blockading them thus.
('26', 33, 1, 4, 85286) The people may fight only if they can bear all these hardships.
('26', 33, 1, 5, 85350) Further, the people of Bardoli have also been told that, if on the whole they remain firm in their determination, adhere to truth, preserve complete peace, shed all fear, remain united among themselves, keep up complete non co operation, maintain friendly relations with the Dheds and Bhangis and do not regard them as untouchables, adopt complete swadeshi and wear only hand spun, hand woven cloth and spin and weave the required cloth in Bardoli itself, then not even a hair of theirs will be touched and they will not only get back their confiscated lands but will also end others’ sufferings and, themselves becoming free, play a big part in liberating the whole country.
('26', 33, 1, 6, 86026) In this struggle, there is no place for hypocrisy, outward show and falsehood, and nothing should be kept hidden.
('26', 33, 1, 7, 86140) All should fight with their own strength or rely on God.

('26', 43, 3, 5, 111204) The first time I came here, I merely inspected the preparations made by the brothers and sisters of this taluka.
('26', 43, 3, 6, 111317) At that time, there was no responsibility on you or me.

('26', 43, 3, 8, 111654) I certainly could not say that Bardoli was actually ready.

('26', 50, 2, 8, 130728) 20. BARDOLI’S DECISION
('26', 50, 3, 9, 130751) January 30, 1922 Bardoli has come to a momentous decision.
('26', 50, 3, 10, 130810) It has made its final and irrevocable choice.
('26', 50, 3, 11, 130856) Vithalbhai Patel, the President, addressed a conference 1 of the representatives of the Taluka in a speech impressive for its warning.
('26', 50, 3, 12, 130991) He certainly did not mince matters.
('26', 50, 3, 13, 131027) There was an audience of khaddar clad representatives numbering 4,000. There were five hundred women, a large majority of whom were also in khaddar.
('26', 50, 3, 14, 131176) They were interested and interesting listeners.
('26', 50, 3, 15, 131224) It was an audience of sober, responsible men and women with a stake.
('26', 50, 3, 16, 131293) I followed Vithalbhai and went through every one of the conditions of mass civil disobedience laid down by the Congress.
('26', 50, 3, 17, 131414) 2 I took the sense of the meeting on every one of the conditions, separately.
('26', 50, 3, 18, 131492) They understood the implications of Hindu Muslim Parsi Christian unity.
('26', 50, 3, 19, 131564) They realized the significance and the truth of non violence.
('26', 50, 3, 20, 131626) They saw what the removal of untouchability meant; they were prepared, not merely to take into national schools, but to induce untouchable children to join them; they have had no objection to the untouchable drawing water from the village wells.
('26', 50, 3, 21, 131872) They knew that they were to nurse the untouchable sick as they would nurse their ailing neighbours.
('26', 50, 3, 22, 131972) They knew that they could not exercise the

('26', 51, 1, 4, 132355) And lastly, they were ready to face forfeiture of their movables, their cattle and their land.

('26', 53, 3, 5, 137025) 21. TO THE PATELS OF BARDOLI
('26', 53, 4, 6, 137054) BARDOLI, January 30, 1922 The Taluka Parishad had committed itself to a very serious and solemn duty and has taken a grave responsibility upon its shoulders.
('26', 53, 4, 7, 137212) We trust that in this sacred work of regenerating the country, the Patels 1 of Bardoli will do their duty to the utmost.
('26', 53, 4, 8, 137333) Many of them have expressed their readiness to give up their posts.
('26', 53, 4, 9, 137401) We hope that from now on every Patel will look upon himself no longer as a Patel in the service of the Government but as a Patel in the service of the community.
('26', 53, 4, 10, 137563) We, therefore, expect that their letters of resignation will be placed in our hands without delay.
('26', 53, 4, 11, 137662) We have not yet lost hope that the Government will repent of its sins and purify itself and so we do not propose to forward the letters of resignation immediately to the Government.
('26', 53, 4, 12, 137844) But the moment civil disobedience is announced, we intend to forward them.
('26', 53, 4, 13, 137919) Meanwhile, we should go ahead with preparations as if we had decided to start civil disobedience immediately.
('26', 53, 4, 14, 138029) We expect, therefore, that every Patel will hand over his letter of resignation to us without delay.

('26', 54, 1, 2, 138354) 22. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, SURAT 1
('26', 54, 2, 3, 138392) January 31, 1922 Dr. Choithram 2 has told you that there is a possibility of the Government arresting me in about ten days and hence you expressed a desire to meet me.
('26', 54, 2, 4, 138560) But I must say that now I have no desire at all to go to jail.
('26', 54, 2, 5, 138623) I would rather be killed by a bullet, or die by hanging.
('26', 54, 2, 6, 138680) And I also wish that many other Gujaratis should ask for a similar death.
('26', 54, 2, 7, 138754) For some time past, I have been praying to God for this very thing— that He may give me death at the hands of this Government.
('26', 54, 2, 8, 138881) I cannot hear the reports or bear the thought of the sufferings of our people in different parts of the country.
('26', 54, 2, 9, 138994) Some have their belongings seized and some are flogged.
('26', 54, 2, 10, 139050) The Government disperses meetings by force.
('26', 54, 2, 11, 139094) How can we tolerate all this?
('26', 54, 2, 12, 139124) Courting impriso nment is not the way to stop what is happening.
('26', 54, 2, 13, 139189) The remedy lies in another Jallianwala Bagh and I wish that, if the Government’s oppression does not stop immediately, we should have many repetitions of the Jallianwala Bagh in Gujarat.
('26', 54, 2, 14, 139376) But there should be one big difference.
('26', 54, 2, 15, 139416) The people had collected in the Jallianwala Bagh for a holiday, they had no idea at all that they might be shot down.
('26', 54, 2, 16, 139534) They had no such desire.
('26', 54, 2, 17, 139559) Had they known that they might be shot down, perhaps no one would have even gone there.
('26', 54, 2, 18, 139647) As for us, however, I wish that we should face the bullets willingly.
('26', 54, 2, 19, 139717) Let some General Dyer stand before us with his troops.
('26', 54, 2, 20, 139772) Let him start firing without warning us.
('26', 54, 2, 21, 139813) It is my prayer to God that, if that happens, I should continue to talk to you cheerfully even at that time just as I am doing now and that you should all remain sitting calmly then, under a shower of bullets, as you are doing now.
('26', 54, 2, 22, 140045) It would be a great thing for Gujarat if, at that time, your ears and backs were turned towards me but your chests and your eyes faced the direction from which the bullets came and you welcomed them.
('26', 54, 2, 23, 140245) Gujarat has talked A lot, has passed enough resolutions; but, while almost the whole of the country has been suffering, we have had practically to suffer nothing.
('26', 54, 2, 24, 140408) This does not mean, I know, that we have lagged behind others in

('26', 55, 1, 16, 141867) How many would offer to attend on any of them who might get fever just as we would serve our brother or sister, mother or father in such a condition?
('26', 55, 2, 17, 142017) Why should we blame the Government?
('26', 55, 2, 18, 142053) If we must blame anyone, we should blame ourselves, reproach ourselves for not having improved, despite bitter experiences, and carried out the required degree of self purification, for not having shown enough selflessness and made enough sacrifices.
('26', 55, 2, 19, 142304) I often feel that we shall not be able to rid ourselves of our numerous evils and fears till we have shown in action that we can die in large numbers.
('26', 55, 2, 20, 142455) As we have not suffered much till now, I pray for myself and for Gujarat that we may have to go through more suffering than what the other provinces have had to bear.
('26', 55, 2, 21, 142622) Only the new Bharat that will be born as a result of that suffering will be a fit country to live in, and only with such strength can we help to heal the wounds in the hearts of our Muslim brethren.
('26', 55, 2, 22, 142821) Through such suffering alone can we secure Justice for the Punjab and in such strength lies swaraj.
('26', 55, 2, 23, 142921) Let the Government, therefore, arrest me if it chooses to do so.
('26', 55, 2, 24, 142986) One need not at all feel unhappy if it does, need not be disturbed or lose one’s head.
('26', 55, 2, 25, 143073) I actually hope that, when I am arrested, the weaknesses which still remain in us will disappear, that the register of volunteers will also get filled with your names, my brothers and sisters, and all of you will start wearing hand woven khadi made from

('26', 59, 0, 1, 148239) 60 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('26', 59, 1, 2, 148280) 26. LETTER TO VICEROY 1
('26', 59, 2, 3, 148304) [BARDOLI, February 1, 1922] 2
('26', 59, 3, 4, 148334) TO HIS EXCELLENCY THE VICEROY DELHI SIR, Bardoli is a small tahsil in the Surat District in the Bombay Presidency, having a population of about 87,000 all told.
('26', 59, 3, 5, 148495) On the 29th ultimo it decided under the presidency of Mr. Vithalbhai Patel to embark on mass civil disobedience, having proved its fitness for it in terms of the resolution 3 of the All India Congress Committee which met at Delhi during the first week of November last.
('26', 59, 3, 6, 148765) But as I am perhaps chiefly responsible for Bardoli’s decision, I owe it to your Excellency and the public to explain the situation under which the decision has been taken.
('26', 59, 3, 7, 148938) It was intended under the resolution of the All India Congress Committee, before referred to, to make Bardoli the first unit for mass civil disobedience in order to mark the national revolt against the Government for its consistently criminal refusal to appreciate India’s resolve regarding the Khilafat, the Punjab and swaraj.
('26', 59, 3, 8, 149266) Then followed the unfortunate and regrettable rioting on the 17th November last in Bombay, resulting in the postponement of the step contemplated by Bardoli.
('26', 59, 3, 9, 149424) Meanwhile repression of a virulent type has taken place with the concurrence of the Government of India in Bengal, Assam, the United Provinces, the Punjab, the Province of Delhi and, in a way, in Bihar and Orissa and elsewhere.
('26', 59, 3, 10, 149652) I know that you nave objected to the use of the word “repression” for describing the action of the authorities in these provinces.
('26', 59, 3, 11, 149783) In my opinion when action is taken which is in excess of the requirements of a situation, it is undoubtedly repression.
('26', 59, 3, 12, 149903) The looting of property, assaults on innocent people, the brutal treatment of prisoners in the jails including flogging can in no sense be described as legal, civilized or in any way necessary.
('26', 59, 3, 13, 150097) This official lawlessness cannot be described by any other term but lawless
('26', 59, 4, 14, 150173) 1 This was published in the newspapers on February 4, 1922, For the Gov ernment’s reply vide Appendix “Government of India”Communique”on Gandhiji’s Letter to Viceroy”, 6 2 1922. 2 From India in 1921 22 3 Vide “The All India Congress Committee”, 10 11 1921.
('26', 60, 0, 1, 150430) VOL. 26 : 24 JANUARY, 1922 12 NOVEMBER, 1923 61
('26', 60, 1, 2, 150478) repression.
('26', 60, 1, 3, 150490) Intimidation by non co operators or their sympathizers to a certain extent in connection with hartals and picketing may be admitted but in no case can it be held to justify the wholesale suppression of peaceful volunteering or equally peaceful public meetings under a distorted use of an extraordinary law which was passed in order to deal with activities which were manifestly violent both in intention and action, nor is it possible to designate as otherwise than repression, action taken against innocent people under what has appeared to many of us an illegal use of the ordinary law, nor again can the administrative interference with the liberty of the Press under a law that is under promise of repeal be regarded as anything but repression.
('26', 60, 1, 4, 151239) The immediate task before the country, therefore, is to rescue from paralysis freedom of speech, freedom of association andfreedom of the Press.
('26', 60, 1, 5, 151384) In the present mood of the Government of India and in the present unprepared state of the country in respect of complete control of the forces of violence, non co operators were unwilling to have anything to do with the Malaviya Conference whose object was to induce Your Excellency to convene a round table conference.
('26', 60, 1, 6, 151704) But as I was anxious to avoid all avoidable suffering, I had no hesitation in advising the Working Committee of the Congress to accept the recommendations of that Conference.
('26', 60, 1, 7, 151879) 1 Although in my opinion the terms were quite in keeping with your own requirements as I understood them through your Calcutta speech and otherwise, you have summarily rejected the proposal.
('26', 60, 1, 8, 152070) In the circumstances, there is nothing before the country but to adopt some non violent method for the enforcement of its demands including the elementary rights of free speech, free association and free Press.
('26', 60, 1, 9, 152281) In my humble opinion the recent events are a clear departure from the civilized policy laid own by Your Excellency at the time of the generous, manly and unconditional apology 2 of the Ali Brothers, viz., that the Government of India should not interfere with the activities of non co operation so long as they remained non violent in word and deed.
('26', 60, 1, 10, 152631) Had the Government’s policy remained neutral and allowed public opinion to ripen and have its full effect, it would have been possible to advise postponement of the adoption of civil disobedience of an aggressive type till the Congress had acquired fuller control over the forces of violence in the country and enforced greater discipline among the millions of its adherents.
('26', 60, 1, 11, 153007) But this lawless repression (in a way unparalleled in the history of this
('26', 60, 2, 12, 153081) 1 Vide “Working Committee’s Resolution”, 7 l 1922. 2 Vide “Draft of Ali Brothers Apology”, 30 5 12921.
('26', 61, 0, 1, 153184) 62 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('26', 61, 1, 2, 153225) unfortunate country) has made the immediate adoption of mass civil disobedience an imperative duty.
('26', 61, 1, 3, 153325) The Working Committee of the Congress has restricted it to only certain areas to be selected by me from time to time, and at present it is confined only to Bardoli.
('26', 61, 1, 4, 153490) I may, under said authority, give my consent at once in respect of a group of 100 villages in Guntur in the Madras Presidency, provided they can strictly conform to the conditions of non violence, unity among different classes, the adoption and manufacture of hand spun khadi and untouchability.
('26', 61, 1, 5, 153786) But before the people of Bardoli actually commence mass civil disobedience, I would respectfully urge you as the head of the Government of India, finally to revise your policy and set free all the non co operating prisoners who are convicted or under trialfor non violent activities and to declare in clear terms a policy of absolute non interference with all non violent activities in the country whether they be regarding the redress of the Khilafat or the Punjab wrongs or swaraj or any other purpose and even though they fall under the repressive sections of the Penal Code or the Criminal Procedure Code or other repressive laws subject always to the condition of non violence.
('26', 61, 1, 6, 154469) I would further urge you to free the Press from all administrative control and to restore all the fines and forfeitures recently imposed.
('26', 61, 1, 7, 154607) In thus urging I am asking Your Excellency to do what is being done today in every country which is deemed to be under civilized Government.
('26', 61, 1, 8, 154748) If you can see your way to make the necessary declaration within seven days of the date of publication of this manifesto, I shall be prepared to advise postponement of civil disobedience of an aggressive character, till the imprisoned workers have, after their discharge, reviewed the whole situation and considered the position de novo.
('26', 61, 1, 9, 155086) If the Government makes the requested declaration I shall regard it as an honest desire on its part to give effect to public opinion and shall therefore have no hesitation in advising the country to be engaged in further moulding public opinion without violent restraint from either side and trust to its working to secure the fulfilment of its unalterable demands.
('26', 61, 1, 10, 155452) Aggressive civil disobedience in that case will be taken up only when the Government departs from its policy of strictest neutrality or refuses to yield to clearly expressed opinion of the vast majority of the people of India.
('26', 61, 1, 11, 155679) I remain, Your Excellency’s faithful servant and friend, M. K. GANDHI Young India, 9 2 1922

('26', 66, 1, 2, 165935) FRIGHTFULNESS IN MEERUT
('26', 66, 2, 3, 165959) Kazi Bashiruddin Ahmed, Secretary, District Khilafat Committee writes: 1
('26', 66, 3, 4, 166032) It is not without deep grief that I reproduce this letter and the one that follows.
('26', 66, 3, 5, 166116) I feel humiliated and ashamed to find that human nature can stoop so low.
('26', 66, 3, 6, 166190) I have no reason to doubt the accuracy of the statements of my correspondents.
('26', 66, 3, 7, 166269) My advice to all these brave co workers is: “Abide by your pledge of non violence; forgive the persecutors; they are evidently mad; they do not know what they are doing; never mind the abusive language; it fouls the utterer, not the unwilling listener; the assaults do injure our bodies, but they can only do us good if we can only bear them manfully and without resentment.” For me this exhibition of unmanly lawlessness on the part of the police is one more proof of the corrupt nature of the system.
('26', 66, 3, 8, 166772) Barbarism has been cultivated and human nature deliberately degraded for the sake of sustaining power, usurped in the commercial interest of a minority intent upon exploiting and draining this poor country which I fondly believe was once rich in men and material.

('26', 80, 1, 2, 202046) 33. PRACTISING LAWYERS AND VOLUNTEERING
('26', 80, 2, 3, 202086) TO The Editor, YOUNG INDIA
('26', 80, 4, 4, 202113) 1. Is it permissible for practising lawyers to enrol themselves as volunteers?
('26', 80, 5, 5, 202192) Writing about lawyers in Young India dated the 12th instant, 1 you observe, “But the Congress 2 has purposely opened an honourable door for them.
('26', 80, 5, 6, 202338) The original draft was perhaps uncertain as to any but full non co operators being entitled to sign the volunteers’ pledge.
('26', 80, 5, 7, 202462) The conditions for them are easy of fulfilment being mostly matters of belief.”
('26', 80, 6, 8, 202542) On the other hand, in a report of your conference with the Bengal delegate at Ahmedabad, 3 published in The Tribune of 20th January 1922, the following passage occurs:
('26', 80, 7, 9, 202710) “Questioned as to how a practising lawyer can serve the country according to the resolution, Mahatmaji said:
('26', 80, 8, 10, 202819) A practising lawyer can certainly wear khadi but he cannot be a volunteer.
('26', 80, 9, 11, 202894) P: I fear that work shall stop in some places for want of men.
('26', 80, 10, 12, 202957) MAHATMAJI: .
('26', 80, 10, 13, 202970) You will certainly get their help in conncetion with your work among the untouchables, or for temperance work or in connection with swadeshi, but they cannot be members of the Volunteer Corps.
('26', 80, 10, 14, 203163) The Volunteer Corps is being formed in defiance of Government notification and only those are fit to go to jail who are pure minded men.” Is this report in any way materially incorrect or has there been lately a change in your views on the subject?
('26', 80, 10, 15, 203412) To the ordinary practising lawyer the matter is not quite free from difficulty.
('26', 80, 10, 16, 203492) For, whilst the Congress resolution 4 is comprehensive enough to include co operators and non co operators, lawyers and laymen alike, it seems quite inconsistent, almost hypocritical, on the part of a practising lawyer to enrol himself as a volunteer.
('26', 80, 11, 17, 203744) For one thing, it is entirely against the spirit of all the Congress resolutions on non co operation and your own interpretations of them, that a man, who has failed to obey the call of the country, should appear before the public in any prominent form of public activity.

('26', 82, 2, 6, 207221) 34. TO KHOJA BROTHERS AND SISTERS A Muslim friend has written a long letter about the poor progress of swadeshi among the Khojas 2. I reproduce the following portion from it: 3
('26', 82, 3, 7, 207398) I have not addressed a special appeal to the Khojas till now, as I had no occasion to do so.
('26', 82, 3, 8, 207491) We cannot ignore even a group of five men in this national and religious struggle, not to speak of a group of 2,50,000. We should accept what people give and then appeal to them for more.
('26', 82, 3, 9, 207679) The Khojas are in fact a prominent community.
('26', 82, 3, 10, 207725) they have money and also ability; some of them are men of wide outlook.
('26', 82, 3, 11, 207797) They have some liberal hearted gentlemen among them.
('26', 82, 3, 12, 207850) Sometimes I even meet open hearted men and women belonging to that community.
('26', 82, 3, 13, 207928) Some of them, I know, read Navajivan carefully and regularly.
('26', 82, 3, 14, 207990) If I could, I would certainly draw the Khoja brothers and sisters towards non co operation or, if not to that, at least towards swadeshi.
('26', 82, 3, 15, 208128) Swadeshi is such an all embracing and simple duty which everyone can discharge that no Indian should ever forsake it.
('26', 82, 3, 16, 208246) An eight year old Telugu girl writes: “Having faith that swaraj can be won through the spinning wheel, I ply it regularly and spin.
('26', 82, 3, 17, 208378) I believe that we shall get swaraj if we do this.” I have told this girl in reply that my faith in the spinning wheel is the same as before.
('26', 82, 3, 18, 208519) I certainly believe that, only if the people start spinning daily as a matter of religious duty, give up foreign cloth, wear khadi and all the time pray to God for help while spinning and do no more, we shall win swaraj.
('26', 82, 3, 19, 208740) Those people, therefore, who do not understand all the items in the non co operation programme, or if they understand them, do not have the strength to act as required, should at any rate start following the swadeshi dharma immediately.
('26', 82, 3, 20, 208977) Many Khoja sisters have told me

('26', 85, 4, 6, 213947) 37. LETTER TO MAHADEV DESAI
('26', 85, 5, 7, 213975) BARDOLI, February 3, 1922
('26', 85, 6, 8, 214001) MAHADEV, I hope you got my reply to your letter.
('26', 85, 6, 9, 214050) I make use of your letters regularly.
('26', 85, 6, 10, 214088) I do not see any difficulty as long as you do everything with the permission of the jailor.
('26', 85, 6, 11, 214180) There can be still less difficulty when it is necessary to break the jail rules deliberately and openly.
('26', 85, 6, 12, 214285) I have already written to explain when the rules may be disobeyed.
('26', 85, 6, 13, 214352) You must have seen that a decision has been taken that Bardoli should make the start.
('26', 85, 6, 14, 214438) I have now, according to our practice, sent an ultimatum to the Viceroy which expires on the 11th.
('26', 85, 6, 15, 214537) This means that we have got to do something tangible on that day.
('26', 85, 6, 16, 214603) My letter must have reached the Viceroy today.
('26', 85, 6, 17, 214650) If he concedes the demands put forth in it, civil disobedience will be suspended for the time being.
('26', 85, 6, 18, 214751) The demands are that the Viceroy should withdraw his notification, should release the prisoners and declare that our peaceful activities will not be interfered with.
('26', 85, 6, 19, 214917) If he concedes these demands, we would resume our work of organizing our movement peacefully.
('26', 85, 6, 20, 215011) Freedom of the Press is covered by our demands.
('26', 85, 6, 21, 215059) The Viceroy will not perhaps grant this demand, but he will have to ultimately, if Bardoli shows its strength of self sacrifice and if the other parts of the country remain peaceful.
('26', 85, 6, 22, 215242) You must now be running self government there.

('26', 86, 10, 14, 216086) MY DEAR CHARLIE, I have your wire.
('26', 86, 10, 15, 216121) I did not expect better results about East Africa, nor do I expect more from South Africa at present.
('26', 86, 10, 16, 216223) The Indians will all the same hold their own somehow.
('26', 86, 10, 17, 216277) Whilst you should do all you can, I would like you to see with me that it is not to be expected that the condition in the colonies can possibly improve before it has considerably improved in India.
('26', 86, 10, 18, 216475) You can have no notion of the wicked deeds that are happening in India in the name of Law and Order.

('26', 87, 4, 6, 217157) 40. ANGAD’S MISSION OF PEACE
('26', 87, 5, 7, 217186) It is a rule of civilized fighting that a warrior, having mobilized all his strength, acts with the utmost modesty.
('26', 87, 5, 8, 217302) From then onwards, he never forsakes courtesy.
('26', 87, 5, 9, 217349) At the commencement of every battle, he gives due Warning to the opponent, cautions him and requires him to rectify his mistake and remove the cause of the conflict.
('26', 87, 5, 10, 217515) Rama made such an appeal to Ravana.
('26', 87, 5, 11, 217551) On arriving at Setubandh Rameshwar 2, he collected together his army of vanaras 3 and held a discussion as to who should convey the warning to Ravana.
('26', 87, 5, 12, 217702) To many, of course, this step seemed unnecessary, while some saw weakness in it.
('26', 87, 5, 13, 217783) To make an appeal to a proud person like Ravana amounted to feeding his pride.
('26', 87, 5, 14, 217862) Rama listened to these arguments attentively and explained to his army that Rama’s soldiers should not worry whether the peace mission would have any effect on Ravana or not.
('26', 87, 5, 15, 218037) They should only think of what civilized behaviour required of them.
('26', 87, 5, 16, 218106) If this made Ravana prouder, he would become all the more over confident.
('26', 87, 5, 17, 218180) What would Rama lose by that?
('26', 87, 5, 18, 218210) He was bound to become the stronger for having given due warning and done his duty.
('26', 87, 5, 19, 218294) He chose the strong, patient, and courteous Angad and sent him on a peace mission to Ravana.The latter, of course, got irritated.
('26', 87, 5, 20, 218424) Was he likely to listen to reason?
('26', 87, 5, 21, 218459) In the end, however, he lost his kingdom and his life.
('26', 87, 5, 22, 218514) Following this same principle of civilized behaviour, we have sent a courteous peace offer to the Viceroy.
('26', 87, 5, 23, 218621) He is not likely to pay attention to it.
('26', 87, 5, 24, 218662) How does that affect us?
('26', 87, 5, 25, 218687) Actually, his not paying attention to it will greatly increase our strength.
('26', 87, 5, 26, 218764) The world, too, will turn more definitely in our favour.
('26', 87, 5, 27, 218821) Our world of course means our brothers who still think that we are misguided and who support the Government.
('26', 87, 5, 28, 218930) This time the issue is different.
('26', 87, 5, 29, 218964) Before we secure a settlement about the Khilafat, the Punjab or swaraj, we have to settle accounts with the Government and its supporters in regard to another matter.
('26', 87, 6, 30, 219131) 1 Of February 1,1922 2 A town on the southern tip of India 3 Monkeys
('26', 88, 0, 1, 219200) VOL. 26 : 24 JANUARY, 1922 12 NOVEMBER, 1923 89
('26', 88, 1, 2, 219248) This Government has always maintained its control by distracting the people’s attention.
('26', 88, 1, 3, 219337) The real disease is ignored and attention is focussed on something else.
('26', 88, 1, 4, 219410) The Bengalis’ disease was the grievance about partition.
('26', 88, 1, 5, 219467) If they were driven by that disease to throw bombs, the Government described this bomb throwing as their disease and tried to make the people forget the original disease.
('26', 88, 1, 6, 219638) Using the bomb throwing as an excuse, it tried systematically to harass innocent citizens and to emasculate the people.
('26', 88, 1, 7, 219758) A like disease was the Rowlatt Act.
('26', 88, 1, 8, 219794) In the excitement caused by that disease, the Punjab became delirious.
('26', 88, 1, 9, 219865) The Government perpetrated a massacre in order to cure the province of this disease, and in this way tried to conceal the original disease.
('26', 88, 1, 10, 220005) Now, the country suffers from the triple fever of the Khilafat, the Punjab and swaraj.
('26', 88, 1, 11, 220092) It is in agony with suffering.
('26', 88, 1, 12, 220123) A fire within sometimes leads to insanity.
('26', 88, 1, 13, 220166) Taking this insanity to be the real malady, the Government has adopted a policy of repression.
('26', 88, 1, 14, 220261) Thus, it has become a rule with it to make the people forget the real malady, to look upon its effects themselves as the disease and to follow a policy of repression to cure them of that.
('26', 88, 1, 15, 220449) We have now learnt by experience that we should give the Government no opportunity to deceive the people.
('26', 88, 1, 16, 220555) We may not mind whether or not it cures the real malady, but we should not let it assume the evils resulting from that disease to be the disease itself and try to suppress them.
('26', 88, 1, 17, 220733) The Government has maintained its rule till today by doing exactly this.
('26', 88, 1, 18, 220806) If the people are hurt by any mistake of the Government or by its arbitrary actions, and even lose their head in consequence, then in suppressing them the Government will try to make the public forget its high handedness; this we should not permit it to do.
('26', 88, 1, 19, 221064) If we can wrest from it this weapon for ever, it will not be able to adopt autocratic methods.
('26', 88, 1, 20, 221159) Once repression becomes impossible autocracy will give way to the reign of public opinion.
('26', 88, 1, 21, 221250) Fortunately, the Government itself has focussed attention on this issue by resorting to repression.
('26', 88, 1, 22, 221350) We should forthwith take up the challenge.
('26', 88, 1, 23, 221393) The Government may harass us as much as it likes but a fourth demand has been added to the earlier three, and it should get priority over them.
('26', 88, 1, 24, 221537) We should create conditions in which it would be impossible for the Government to resort to repression.
('26', 88, 1, 25, 221641) Repression means gagging us, dissolving our associations and suppressing our organs of public opinion.
('26', 88, 1, 26, 221744) How can we bear Lalaji’s Bande Mataram being forced to stop publication?
('26', 88, 1, 27, 221817) Can we see Mazharul Huq Saheb’s Motherland being suppressed?
('26', 88, 1, 28, 221878) Jafar Ali Khan’s Zamindar, Habib Khan’s Siyasat and Radhakishan’s Pratap —all these have been suppressed.
('26', 88, 1, 29, 221984) The Independent was suppressed long ago, and so was the Swaraj of Prayag.
('26', 88, 1, 30, 222058) The remedy for all this
('26', 89, 0, 1, 222082) 90 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('26', 89, 1, 2, 222123) must surely be in our hands.
('26', 89, 1, 3, 222152) Such repression ought not to be allowed to go on.
('26', 89, 1, 4, 222202) A government which does not wish to submit to public opinion will always try to silence protests by the people.
('26', 89, 1, 5, 222314) If it fails in the attempt, that will be its defeat.
('26', 89, 1, 6, 222367) In the peace offer, therefore, which has been dispatched from Bardoli, the demand that the Government should stop repression is given the first place.
('26', 89, 1, 7, 222518) When we can express our views freely, when our organs are allowed to be published and we can form our associations in freedom, we are as good as free; three fourths of swaraj will have been then established.
('26', 89, 1, 8, 222726) A vigorous expression of public opinion will by itself suffice to bend the Govern ment.
('26', 89, 1, 9, 222814) It is certainly part of the meaning of swaraj that we should have freedom of action and expression.
('26', 89, 1, 10, 222914) Only murder will be outlawed then.
('26', 89, 1, 11, 222949) Even under swaraj, we shall not get the right to murder anyone.
('26', 89, 1, 12, 223013) It has been indicated in that peace offer that, if the Government releases all persons imprisoned for peaceful activities and stops repression, we shall suspend civil disobedience for the present.
('26', 89, 1, 13, 223210) In aggressive civil disobedience, an individual or a group respectfully disobeys even innocent man made laws on purpose to defy authority.
('26', 89, 1, 14, 223349) The civil disobedience which we are carrying on all over the country today has been forced on us and, therefore, it is defensive.
('26', 89, 1, 15, 223479) One simply cannot avoid it.
('26', 89, 1, 16, 223507) This means that we express our view though the Government gags us, hold meetings though these are prohibited, publish newspapers when orders are passed for their closure.
('26', 89, 1, 17, 223678) All this is defensive Civil disobedience.
('26', 89, 1, 18, 223720) We have been offering it and will certainly go on offering it as long as arbitrary orders continue to be issued.
('26', 89, 1, 19, 223833) But the other type of civil disobedience, which is not for self defence but is meant to harass the Government, which is a form of revolt, we may call off if the Government abandons its policy of repression.
('26', 89, 1, 20, 224040) I feel that we should suspend it on this condition.
('26', 89, 1, 21, 224092) For, if the Government removes the restrictions over our speech, our pen and our associations, it will have to concede our other demands in a short time.
('26', 89, 1, 22, 224246) That is to say, the task before Bardoli today is to secure the release of our fighters and compel the Government to give up repression.
('26', 89, 1, 23, 224382) If Bardoli achieves this, it will have done its job fully.
('26', 89, 1, 24, 224441) If, however, the Viceroy does not concede even this, what will Bardoli do?
('26', 89, 1, 25, 224516) If he does not concede even the right to express public opinion, how can we avoid launching aggressive civil disobedience?
('26', 89, 1, 26, 224639) A man may be on the defensive up to a certain limit, but beyond that he may even start an offensive.
('26', 89, 1, 27, 224740) Aggressive civil disobedience may be
('26', 90, 0, 1, 224777) VOL. 26 : 24 JANUARY, 1922 12 NOVEMBER, 1923 91
('26', 90, 1, 2, 224825) looked upon as a kind of non violent offensive.
('26', 90, 1, 3, 224873) We have explained all this to the Viceroy.
('26', 90, 1, 4, 224916) By making this peace offer, we have shown the highest culture.
('26', 90, 1, 5, 224979) The offer means that, if the Viceroy grants by the 11th instant the demand made on behalf of Bardoli, the civil disobedience to be started by the latter will be postponed for the time being.
('26', 90, 1, 6, 225170) After the fighters are released, we shall carry on the fight as all of us together may decide to do.
('26', 90, 1, 7, 225271) Personally, I believe that, if our demand is accepted, there will be little need for us to start mass civil disobedience.
('26', 90, 1, 8, 225393) The acceptance of our demand can mean nothing else.
('26', 90, 1, 9, 225445) I, therefore, think that the demand for freedom of speech, writing and association is unlikely to be accepted.

('26', 90, 1, 11, 225607) Deficiencies which still remain should be removed and every man and woman should pray to God for strength to bear loss of life or property.

('26', 90, 2, 13, 225783) 41. MY SPEECH AT SURAT
('26', 90, 3, 14, 225806) I like to give summaries of others’ and my own speeches and I know I have the ability to do this, but I rarely get time for that.
('26', 90, 3, 15, 225936) It happens that I have the time and the inclination to give a summary of my speech at Surat on the 31st.
('26', 90, 4, 16, 226041) On that day, there was a meeting of the Working Committee in Surat.
('26', 90, 4, 17, 226109) It was attended by Hakim Ajmal Khan, Mian Chhotani, Dr. [M.A.] Ansari, Dr. Choithram [Gidwani], Shri Kaujalgi and Shri Vithalbhai Patel, all members, and me.
('26', 90, 4, 18, 226267) Taking advantage of this occasion, they had arranged a meeting for the citizens of Surat.
('26', 90, 4, 19, 226357) It had been decided that I should not attend the meeting and so I was busy with my work.
('26', 90, 4, 20, 226446) Meanwhile, Shri Dayalji came and’ informed me that the audience demanded my presence.
('26', 90, 4, 21, 226532) The reason was that Dr. Choithram had needlessly dropped a remark at the meeting that I might possibly be arrested within ten days.
('26', 90, 4, 22, 226664) On the audience insisting that, in that case, they would like to see me, Shri Dayalji came to persuade me and I went.
('26', 90, 4, 23, 226782) Generally, I go to a meeting prepared with an outline of what I am going to say.
('26', 90, 4, 24, 226863) This time, however, I had not thought about anything at all.
('26', 90, 4, 25, 226924) But the thought which had been in my mind for some time past came up vividly before me and I put it before the citizens of Surat in such emphatic language as I had not used before.
('26', 90, 4, 26, 227105) I think

('26', 91, 1, 2, 227223) every Gujarati should know what I said.
('26', 91, 1, 3, 227263) I should like to see that same thought in everyone’s mind.
('26', 91, 1, 4, 227322) I, therefore, wanted to give my Surat speech for the benefit of all.
('26', 91, 1, 5, 227391) There was a time when I felt how good it would be if I were in jail.
('26', 91, 1, 6, 227460) But now my desire to go to jail has nearly vanished.

('26', 91, 3, 12, 227848) 42. HOPES HELD OUT
('26', 91, 4, 13, 227867) Bardoli has held out great hopes.
('26', 91, 4, 14, 227901) May God grant the people of Bardoli courage and good sense!
('26', 91, 4, 15, 227961) Just as a pledge was taken in the masjid in Pretoria in South Africa, just as this was done at Muzaffarpur for Champaran, just as the mill hands of Ahmedabad took a pledge under a tree on the river bank, just as the Patidars of Kheda took a pledge at Nadiad, so the representatives of the Patidars of Bardoli took a pledge under a tree and they and others did so once again in the Conference pandal.
('26', 91, 4, 16, 228361) In the same way as the previous pledges were fulfilled somehow, will not God help us to fulfil this one too?
('26', 91, 4, 17, 228470) Some will fall and others will take their place; in the end, however, will not our hopes be fulfilled?
('26', 91, 4, 18, 228573) Truth always wins, and it is the divine law that, as long as there is even one person prepared to lay down his life to vindicate truth because it is truth, so long is the victory of truth certain even though crores may be ranged against it.
('26', 91, 4, 19, 228814) This law admits of no exception.
('26', 91, 4, 20, 228847) But then, have I made a mistake in trusting Bardoli?
('26', 91, 4, 21, 228900) I go on making mistakes and every time God rectifies them.
('26', 91, 4, 22, 228959) People deceive me a thousand times; even so, how can I distrust them?
('26', 91, 4, 23, 229029) As long as I see the slightest excuse for trusting people, I will certainly trust them.
('26', 91, 4, 24, 229117) It is foolish to continue trusting after one has had definite ground for not trusting.
('26', 91, 4, 25, 229204) But to distrust a person on mere suspicion is arrogance and betrays lack of faith in God.
('26', 91, 4, 26, 229294) It is faith that keeps the world going.
('26', 91, 5, 27, 229334) 1 For the speech, vide “Speech at Public Meeting, Surat”, 31 1 1922
('26', 92, 0, 1, 229402) VOL. 26 : 24 JANUARY, 1922 12 NOVEMBER, 1923 93
('26', 92, 1, 2, 229450) If I knew that certain people always deceived me and yet I went on trusting them, there would be no limit to my foolishness.
('26', 92, 1, 3, 229575) The people of Bardoli have been so frank with me that I felt it a sin to distrust them.
('26', 92, 1, 4, 229663) I was sceptical when I sat down for discussion with their representatives, but they inspired trust in me.
('26', 92, 1, 5, 229769) The people of Bardoli are simple minded and trustful; they do not care for comforts.
('26', 92, 1, 6, 229854) They are neither very rich nor very poor; they are not violent, nor are they cowards.
('26', 92, 1, 7, 229940) They are not quarrelsome but affectionate.
('26', 92, 1, 8, 229983) There are no serious disputes among them.
('26', 92, 1, 9, 230025) They have maintained cordial relation with officials.
('26', 92, 1, 10, 230079) Since they have no local grievances, their request to be allowed to fight is altogether unselfish.
('26', 92, 1, 11, 230178) They have worked hard to make themselves fit and spared no effort to that end.
('26', 92, 1, 12, 230257) They have not become perfect in the matter of swadeshi, but they are trying honestly to be so.
('26', 92, 1, 13, 230352) They have shaken off untouchability to an extent to which no other part of the country has done.
('26', 92, 1, 14, 230449) I, therefore, believe that, if any taluka is fit [for civil disobedience], Bardoli certainly is.
('26', 92, 1, 15, 230546) Some people may feel that the people of Bardoli are known to be rather meek and so they will soon get tired of going to jail, will be afraid to face death and will lose all courage when the Government starts seizing their properties.
('26', 92, 1, 16, 230780) My experience right to this day has been that it is the meek who patiently submit to suffering.
('26', 92, 1, 17, 230876) Aggressive people cannot bear suffering.
('26', 92, 1, 18, 230917) They make others suffer.
('26', 92, 1, 19, 230942) And is not this struggle itself meant for the meek?
('26', 92, 1, 20, 230994) It is planned not to turn the meek into aggressive people but to make them brave and to teach the aggressive to be humble, while preserving their courage.
('26', 92, 1, 21, 231149) If the struggle can be won only by aggressive people courting imprisonment, we may take it that we are already defeated for, in that case, it is they who will rule.
('26', 92, 1, 22, 231314) If that happens, we shall have to say that God is the support, not of the meek, but of the aggressive.
('26', 92, 1, 23, 231417) Then Europe’s doctrine of might being right will hold good even here.
('26', 92, 1, 24, 231487) Is it for this that the Ali Brothers, Das, Lalaji and Motilalji have gone to jail?
('26', 92, 1, 25, 231570) We wish to eschew an aggressive spirit, as also hypocrisy, arrogance, violence, untruth, brute force, etc., and to ensure victory of non violence, straightforwardness, humility, simplicity, truth and soul force.
('26', 92, 1, 26, 231782) Therefore, the first quality we should look for is what we call meekness.
('26', 92, 1, 27, 231856) When meekness is infused with courage, it shines at its best.
('26', 92, 1, 28, 231918) I expect this to happen in Bardoli too.
