('26', 165, 2, 22, 398278) 80. INTERVIEW TO “THE BOMBAY CHRONICLE”
('26', 165, 3, 23, 398318) BARDOLI, February 15, 1922
('26', 165, 4, 24, 398345) QUESTION: Have you resolved on any definite programme of activity on your own part in the immediate or near future?
('26', 165, 4, 25, 398461) ANSWER: If your question refers to my personal programme, for the time being I propose to remain in Bardoli and watch the effect upon all the people of the constructive programme placed before them by the Working Committee, which, I am hoping, will be accepted by the All India Congress Committee.
('26', 165, 4, 26, 398759) There is enough work and enough variety for every real worker, but you will notice that it
('26', 165, 5, 27, 398850) 1 Of February 16, 1922
('26', 166, 0, 1, 398873) VOL. 26 : 24 JANUARY, 1922 12 NOVEMBER, 1923 167
('26', 166, 1, 2, 398922) resolves itself into two things: spread of non violence and spread of khaddar.
('26', 166, 1, 3, 399001) The one is to mark a definite inward change and the other to mark a definite outward advance.
('26', 166, 1, 4, 399095) India cannot hold her own against the world without non violence, and she cannot become economically free without the universal adoption of the spinning wheel.
('26', 166, 2, 5, 399255) Do you mean to go on any tour of India in the near future?
('26', 166, 2, 6, 399314) So far as I can see, not in the immediate future except that I shall have to go to Delhi to attend the All India Congress Committee meeting.
('26', 166, 3, 7, 399455) People say that you will be compelled by circumstances to abandon all political activities and devote the rest of your life to tackling social problems like untouchability, intemperance and so on.
('26', 166, 3, 8, 399652) Is there any such likelihood?
('26', 166, 3, 9, 399682) Not so far as I can see the present temper of the nation.
('26', 166, 3, 10, 399740) In spite of the aberrations which I have noted India’s has become solidly non violent.
('26', 166, 3, 11, 399827) I think, both the classes and the masses, and so long as Congressmen continue to endorse the programme laid down and not reject the gospels of non violence and the spinning wheel, I am not likely to abandon my present vocation.
('26', 166, 3, 12, 400055) For me there is no distinction between politics and religion.
('26', 166, 3, 13, 400117) Politics are a sham without a religious backing; and if I am today immersed in the political life of the country it is because politics, i.e., the political conditions of the country are the predominant part of the national life.
('26', 166, 3, 14, 400347) No advance is possible without touching the political life at one point or another.
('26', 166, 4, 15, 400431) In view of the danger of violence would it not be better to give up all idea of mass civil disobedience and concentrate on items of less risk such asdefiance of notifications under the Criminal Law Amendment Act and perfect the organization in at least one city, say Calcutta, and fill the jails?
('26', 166, 4, 16, 400728) I do not think that it is necessary to give up the idea of mass civil disobedience.
('26', 166, 4, 17, 400812) There is nothing wrong in the idea.
('26', 166, 4, 18, 400848) It is not only not an immoral thing but it is a right of the people which can never be surrendered.
('26', 166, 4, 19, 400948) It simply means that the masses should be trained to act non violently.
('26', 166, 4, 20, 401020) What is there wrong in that ideal?
('26', 166, 4, 21, 401055) I confess that I am not going to embark upon mass civil disobedience hastily.
('26', 166, 4, 22, 401133) I would want almost absolute assurances before I think next time of embarking upon mass disobedience myself.
('26', 166, 4, 23, 401242) After all, the civil disobedience in South Africa was mass civil disobedience; there were no untoward incidents in that campaign.
('26', 166, 4, 24, 401372) The disobedience in Kaira in 19l8 was also mass civil disobedience and there was not a single instance of violence.
('26', 166, 4, 25, 401488) Mass civil disobedience for the whole of India and in the name of India is merely an extension of a successful programme.
('26', 166, 4, 26, 401610) I would certainly not have stopped the Bardoli programme had there been no danger of it being thoughtlessly copied
('26', 167, 0, 1, 401725) 168 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('26', 167, 1, 2, 401767) by other parts of India.
('26', 167, 1, 3, 401792) I am certain that in spite of outbreaks of violence in other parts of India, the people of Bardoli would have kept fully non violent but that would not have served the national purpose.
('26', 167, 1, 4, 401978) If Bardoli had to offer mass civil disobedience for local grievances I would certainly not have been stopped.
('26', 167, 2, 5, 402088) If you can effect a breach in one place or break a single link you will break the whole chain.
('26', 167, 2, 6, 402183) Will it not, therefore, be advisable to concentrate on the fight for municipal rights and bring Government to its knees?
('26', 167, 2, 7, 402304) You cannot do it through a single programme.
('26', 167, 2, 8, 402349) It will certainly help, but to attain swaraj through mere municipal reform would be a slow process.
('26', 167, 2, 9, 402449) I am certainly hoping that Ahmedabad and Surat will give a good account of themselves and demonstrate the utter futility of the coercion which the Government of Bombay has thoughtlessly attempted and whilst, if Ahmedabad and Surat succeed, their success will indirectly help the national movement, it will not solve the question of swaraj.
('26', 167, 2, 10, 402789) Swaraj movement means mass education which you cannot impart directly through a few cities perfecting and achieving independent government.
('26', 167, 2, 11, 402929) Indeed the disciplined opposition that Ahmedabad, Surat and Nadiad are pluckily offering has become possible because of the general awakening.
('26', 167, 2, 12, 403072) When the experiment is completed and if it becomes successful, the people will see how the citizens of these three places will have shown grit, constructive ability, capacity for suffering and all other noble qualities that go to make a nation great.
('26', 167, 2, 13, 403323) But that experiment by itself cannot give India swaraj within the time contemplated by the Congress programmes.
('26', 167, 3, 14, 403435) Are you going to organize municipal fight in Ahmedabad and Surat?
('26', 167, 3, 15, 403501) I am not; but I am hoping that the citizens of both these places will not give up a struggle which they have commenced in right earnest.
('26', 167, 4, 16, 403638) There is a class of people who have begun to think that your idea of India attaining a non violent condition is Utopian; and they say that even if after two years’ incessant effort on your behalf to teach non violence to your countrymen the country becomes pacific and you begin your civil disobedience campaign, any single mad cap by a violent deed of political complexion can disturb the harmony They add that you cannot expect all the 315 millions of the Indians to be non violent even after centuries of preaching: “The great prophets like Buddha, Chaitanya, Nanak, Kabir who preached only love and non violence have not succeeded even after 2,500 years in making India entirely non violent.
('26', 167, 4, 17, 404334) Violence is bound to exist so long [as] humanity is not raised to the condition of angels and saints.
('26', 167, 4, 18, 404436) Even if the country remains quiet for a long period to come, what guarantee is there that oppression may not engender violence on the part of some individuals?
('26', 167, 4, 19, 404596) The mob mind when outraged
('26', 168, 0, 1, 404623) VOL. 26 : 24 JANUARY, 1922 12 NOVEMBER, 1923 169
('26', 168, 1, 2, 404672) beyond control is bound to be inflamed and go mad.
('26', 168, 1, 3, 404723) Should the whole country, for the crimes of a few individuals, set at rest the longing for swaraj, a satisfying solution of the Khilafat and justice to the Punjab atrocities?”
('26', 168, 2, 4, 404899) In the face of such hard facts, is it not wise to accept violence as inevitable and only try to check it and not stamp it out completely from the surface of India?
('26', 168, 2, 5, 405063) Many say that the risk will always be there and civil dis obedience without such risk will never be practicable.
('26', 168, 2, 6, 405176) They urge that you yourself said the Choice is between lawless repression and mass civil disobedience with all its dangers.
('26', 168, 2, 7, 405300) May I know what you have got to say in reply to this?
('26', 168, 2, 8, 405354) This sermon in question betrays woeful ignorance of the struggle and the bearing of non violence upon it.
('26', 168, 2, 9, 405460) I do not mean you are ignorant.
('26', 168, 2, 10, 405492) You are merely the mouthpiece for people who are sceptics.
('26', 168, 2, 11, 405551) I should certainly despair of success if I attempted anything that Jesus, Buddha or Mahomed failed to achieve.

('26', 168, 2, 13, 405722) I do not believe that India cannot be taught to see the very simple truth that for her to thing of attaining swaraj by an armed conflict is an impossible dream for several generations.
('26', 168, 2, 14, 405907) There is no country on the face of the earth so ill fitted for an armed conflict as India.
('26', 168, 2, 15, 405998) It may be that the forces of violence may not be sufficiently controlled in order to conduct a campaign of non violentmass civil disobedience.
('26', 168, 2, 16, 406141) If that is the conclusion at which all the leaders arrive it does not mean that India cannot attain her freedom by non violent means.
('26', 168, 2, 17, 406275) There are many forms of civil disobedience open to a satyagrahi; but I confess that mass civil disobedience is the shortest cut.
('26', 168, 2, 18, 406404) If it proves to be impossible I have no doubt that a milder programme of civil disobedience can be conceived so as to give the people a training in self sacrifice.
('26', 168, 2, 19, 406568) From this the masses will learn the law of suffering, in its applicantion to the nation, as they today practise it for domestic affairs.
('26', 168, 2, 20, 406705) There is certainly no swaraj without going through the fire and suffering and it gladdens my heart to read reports that I daily receive of people undergoing incredible suffering without retaliation for the sake of the nation.
('26', 168, 2, 21, 406931) I have, therefore, absolutely no misgivings on the point.
('26', 168, 2, 22, 406989) I am not trying to achieve the impossible.
('26', 168, 2, 23, 407032) Violence there always will be, and I should not be perturbed by stray cases of violence.
('26', 168, 2, 24, 407121) I have advised suspension of civil disobedience because the violence practised near Gorakhpur was not individual, not in connection with any private wrong but from a vague sense of political wrong.
('26', 168, 2, 25, 407319) I do not despair of the people bearing the necessity of self restraint on occasions such as at Chauri Chaura which led to popular violence.

('26', 169, 1, 3, 407750) I believe that slowly but surely the spirit of non violence is spreading.
('26', 169, 1, 4, 407824) It is really not so difficult or impracticable as the string of questions put to me suggests.

('26', 199, 6, 6, 481526) 93. LETTER TO CHAIRMAN, A.I.C.C.
('26', 199, 7, 7, 481559) BARDOLI, February 22, 1922
('26', 199, 8, 8, 481586) TO THE CHAIRMAN OF THE WORKING COMMITTEE OF THE ALL INDIA CONGRESS COMMITTEE, DELHI
('26', 199, 9, 9, 481670) SIR, At the meeting of the Working Committee held at Surat on 31st January last, the following resolution was passed:
('26', 199, 10, 10, 481788) The Working Committee records its firm conviction that dissemination of correct news about Indian political situation in foreign countries is absolutely essential 2 and refers to Mahatma Gandhi all the correspondence on the subject of foreign propaganda now with the Working Secretary, with a request that he should prepare a definite scheme in that behalf at an early date so as to enable the next meeting of the Working Committee to consider it.
('26', 199, 10, 11, 482236) Having considered the resolution and the papers forwarded to me by the Secretary, I beg to report as follows: In my opinion it is not only undesirable but it may prove even harmful to establish at the present stage any agency in any foreign country for the dissemination of correct news in such country about the political situation in India, for the following reasons:
('26', 199, 11, 12, 482606) 1 Gandhiji was about to leave for Delhi after his five day fast, to attend A.I.C.C. meeting there to be held on February 24 and 25. 2 In December 1920 it was decided to suspend foreign propaganda and to wind up the British Congress Committee and its journal India, published from London; vide “Speech on Foreign Propaganda, Nagpur”, 29 12 1920.
('26', 200, 0, 1, 482951) VOL. 26 : 24 JANUARY, 1922 12 NOVEMBER, 1923 201
('26', 200, 1, 2, 483000) First, because it would distract public attention and instead of making the people feel that they have to rely purely on their own strength, it will make them think of the effect of their actions on foreign countries and the support latter can render to the national cause.
('26', 200, 1, 3, 483274) This does not mean that we do not care for the world’s support, but the way to gain that support is to insist upon the correctness of every one of our actions and rely upon the automatic capacity of Truth to spread itself.
('26', 200, 1, 4, 483497) Secondly, it is my experience that when an agency is established for any special purpose, independent interest ceases to a certain extent and what is distributed by the agency is previously discounted as coming from interested quarters.
('26', 200, 1, 5, 483734) Thirdly, the Congress will not be able to exercise effective check over such agencies, and there is great danger of authoritative distribution of wrong information and wrong ideas about the struggle.
('26', 200, 1, 6, 483934) Fourthly, it is not possible at the present moment to send out of India any person of importance for the sole purpose of disseminating news in foreign countries, for such men are too few for the internal work.
('26', 200, 1, 7, 484144) I am therefore of opinion that the work of publishing the Congress Bulletin should be better organized, if necessary, by engaging a special editor for the purpose and by sending the Congress Bulletin regularly to the chief news agencies of the world.
('26', 200, 1, 8, 484395) The editor should be instructed to enter into correspondence with these newspapers or news agencies which may be found to interest themselves in Indian questions.
('26', 200, 1, 9, 484558) It is my firm opinion based upon experience gained through the conduct of the journals I have edited in South Africa and here that the more solid the Congress work and the sufferings of the Congress men and women, the greater the publicity will the cause attain without special effort.
('26', 200, 1, 10, 484844) From the exchanges of letters and correspondence that I receive day by day from all parts of the world in connection with the conduct of Young India, I observe that never was so much interest taken in Indian affairs throughout the world as it is today.
('26', 200, 1, 11, 485097) It follows that the interest will increase in the same proportion as the volume of our sufferings.
('26', 200, 1, 12, 485196) The very best method of disseminating correct information about the political situation, therefore, is to make the Congress work purer, better organized and to evoke a greater spirit of suffering.
('26', 200, 1, 13, 485393) Not only is curiosity thereby intensified, but people become
('26', 201, 0, 1, 485454) 202 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('26', 201, 1, 2, 485496) more eager to understand the inwardness and the exact truth about the situation.
('26', 201, 2, 3, 485577) I remain,
('26', 201, 3, 4, 485587) Yours faithfully,
('26', 201, 4, 5, 485605) M. K. GANDHI Young India, 9 3 1922
('26', 201, 5, 6, 485640) 94. NOTES
('26', 201, 6, 7, 485650) AN EXCELLENT CHOICE
('26', 201, 7, 8, 485670) In selecting Sardar Kharak Singh as the successor to Aga Mahomed Safdar as President of the Provincial Congress Committee, the Congress Committee has made an excellent choice.
('26', 201, 7, 9, 485846) It could not have done better.
('26', 201, 7, 10, 485877) In honouring Sardar Saheb the Committee has honoured itself.
('26', 201, 7, 11, 485938) The election of Sardar Kharak Singh is also a delicate compliment paid to the Sikhs for their bravery, sacrifice and patriotism.
('26', 201, 7, 12, 486067) Nowadays the office of President of a Congress Committee, a Khilafat Committee or a Gurdwara Committee is no sinecure.
('26', 201, 7, 13, 486186) Prosecution for some offence or another under the ordinary or extraordinary laws imposed by the Government upon the people of India almost follows as a matter of course in many provinces.
('26', 201, 7, 14, 486374) With the exception of a few provinces, some office bearers of the various Committees have contributed their quota to His Majesty’s hotels.
('26', 201, 7, 15, 486513) I congratulate Sardar Kharak Singh, therefore, upon his courage in taking up the reins of office at this stormy period of the nation’s career.
('26', 201, 7, 16, 486656) SATISFACTORY FOR BOTH PARTIES The imprisonment of leaders seems to satisfy both the Government and the public.
('26', 201, 7, 17, 486767) It is obvious that they satisfy the Government, otherwise they would not have performed the thankless task of imprisoning leaders.
('26', 201, 7, 18, 486898) They believe that thereby they will be able to suppress the non co operation movement.
('26', 201, 7, 19, 486985) It is equally obvious that the people are satisfied with these imprisonments because the movement, wherever they take place, is making headway.
('26', 201, 7, 20, 487129) The latest instance comes from Nellore.
('26', 201, 7, 21, 487169) Although this place was doing steady work it was not pulsating with vitality as it must be doing now.
('26', 201, 7, 22, 487271) An esteemed worker writes: 1

('26', 202, 1, 3, 487652) The Secretary is Mr. Ram Reddy, when you last came to Nellore.
('26', 202, 1, 4, 487715) He belongs to the most influential family of the Reddy community and his prosecution has carried our gospel to far off nooks and corners which would have otherwise been impenetrable ....

('26', 203, 1, 9, 491554) MALABAR RECONSTRUCTION Mr. Madhava Rao and others of the Servants of India Society and the Secretaries of the Young Men’s Christian Association have jointly issued a series of questions regarding reconstruction in Malabar.

('26', 203, 1, 14, 492135) If, however, the people in want are supplied with spinning wheels, most of the questions will be automatically solved.

('26', 203, 1, 16, 492564) I would, therefore, heartily commend to the organizers of the reconstruction scheme this one single proposition as the central truth round which all the other propositions should be made to revolve.
('26', 203, 1, 17, 492763) They will then find that any scheme so constructed will lead to economy, efficiency and the least waste.

('26', 206, 2, 7, 499299) ESSENCE OF CIVIL DISOBEDIENCE
('26', 206, 3, 8, 499329) A friend, a Congress official, writes from Simla: 1
('26', 206, 4, 9, 499381) certain members, belonging to different Congress organizations, have found out certain novel methods of disobeying law by staging certain plays which have been proscribed by the Government, for instance Zakhm i Punjab which was staged sometime ago in Multan and very recently in Simla, resulting in arrests in both the cases.
('26', 206, 4, 10, 499707) Now may I ask your opinion about this form of disobedience practised before the date fixed in the resolution of the All India Congress Committee, viz., 15th January 1922?
('26', 206, 4, 11, 499878) Further, were the actors in these plays justified in informing the Government in a spirit of defiance beforehand that they were going to stage a proscribed play and by such action inviting arrests?

('26', 206, 4, 13, 500369) May I ask if this kind of propaganda instead of proving helpful will not bring about mischievous results?
('26', 206, 4, 14, 500475) The staging of the play was certainly not justified if it was done before the l5th January.
('26', 206, 4, 15, 500567) It was also not justified if it was done without the consent of the Provincial Congress Committee.
('26', 206, 4, 16, 500666) Every form of civil disobedience was subject to the previous sanction of the local Congress Committee.
('26', 206, 4, 17, 500769) The staging of the play was also unjustified if the play itself was calculated needlessly to excite passions and to induce hatred.
('26', 206, 4, 18, 500900) Assuming that all the conditions I have named were fulfilled, the managers were quite right in giving previous information to the Government in a dignified manner, because the essence of civil disobedience is that it is public and made specially known to those interested in arresting.

('26', 227, 2, 9, 552136) 103. RESOLUTION AT A.I.C.C. MEETING, DELHI
('26', 227, 3, 10, 552179) February 25, 1922
('26', 227, 4, 11, 552197) The following resolution was passed on the 25th ultimo at the session of the All India Congress Committee held at Delhi.
('26', 227, 4, 12, 552318) The All India Congress Committee having carefully considered the resolutions passed by the Working Committee at its meeting held at Bardoli on the 11th and 12th instant, confirms the said resolutions with the modifications 1 noted therein and further resolves that individual civil disobedience whether of a defensive or aggressive character may be commenced in respect of particular places or particular laws at the instance of and upon permission being granted therefore by the respective Provincial Committee; provided that such civil disobedience shall not be permitted unless all the conditions laid down by the Congress or the All India Congress Committee or the Working Committee are strictly fulfilled.
('26', 227, 4, 13, 553029) Reports having been received from various quarters that picketing regarding foreign cloth is as necessary as liquor picketing, the All India Congress Committee authorizes such picketing of a bona fide character on the same terms as liquor picketing mentioned in the Bardoli resolutions.
('26', 227, 4, 14, 553316) The All India Congress Committee wishes it to be understood that the resolutions of the Working Committee do not mean any abandonment of the original Congress programme of non co opera 
('26', 227, 5, 15, 553502) 1Vide footnotes to “Working Committee’s Resolutions at Bardoli”, 12 2 1922.
('26', 228, 0, 1, 553578) VOL. 26 : 24 JANUARY, 1922 12 NOVEMBER, 1923 229
('26', 228, 1, 2, 553627) tion or permanent abandonment of mass civil disobedience but considers that an atmosphere of necessary mass non violence can be established by the workers concentrating upon the constructive programme framed by the Working Committee at Bardoli.
('26', 228, 1, 3, 553872) The All India Congress Committee holds civil disobedience to be the right and duty of the people to be exercised and performed whenever the State opposes the declared will of the people.
('26', 228, 1, 4, 554059) Note: Individual civil disobedience is disobedience of orders or laws by a single individual or an ascertained number or group of individuals.
('26', 228, 1, 5, 554202) Therefore, a prohibited public meeting where admission is regulated by tickets and to which no unauthorized admission is allowed, is an instance of individual civil disobedience, whereas a prohibited meeting to which the general public is admitted without any restriction is an instance of mass civil disobedience.
('26', 228, 1, 6, 554517) Such civil disobedience is defensive when a prohibited public meeting is held for conducting a normal activity although it may result in arrest.
('26', 228, 1, 7, 554662) It would be aggressive if it is held not for any normal activity but merely for the purpose of courting arrest and imprisonment.
('26', 228, 2, 8, 554791) Young India, 2 3 l922
('26', 228, 3, 9, 554813) 104. TEST FOR AHMEDABAD AND SURAT
('26', 228, 4, 10, 554847) The residents and city fathers of Ahmedabad and Surat 1 are about to be put to a test.
('26', 228, 4, 11, 554934) How far we have imbibed the spirit of public service, to what extent the citizens look upon one another as members of a family, in what degree they possess the qualities of firmness, respect for their pledged word, self sacrifice and perseverance—all this will be seen now.
('26', 228, 4, 12, 555208) If all the representatives of the citizens display these qualities, there can be only one result—the committees nominated by the Government will remain idle for want of work.
('26', 228, 4, 13, 555383) There can be no better proof of the hollowness of the Reforms than the supersession of these two big municipalities.
('26', 228, 4, 14, 555500) Had the city fathers acted arbitrarily, it might perhaps have been right to deprive them of their power; but in this case the Government knows, and so does the Indian “minister” for Local Self Government, that
('26', 228, 5, 15, 555710) 1 Vide “My Notes”, 19 2 1922, under the sub title “To Citizens of Ahmedabad and Surat”.
('26', 229, 0, 1, 555798) 230 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('26', 229, 1, 2, 555840) the citizens and their representatives are of one mind in this dispute, that both wish to preserve the autonomy of the Education Department.
('26', 229, 1, 3, 555981) Despite this, the Government and “our” minister have superseded the municipalities, instead of taking whatever remedies are available under the law, and have thereby flouted public opinion.
('26', 229, 1, 4, 556171) It has been thus proved that the Reforms confer altogether arbitrary powers on the Government and that the people would derive no benefit at all from them.
('26', 229, 1, 5, 556327) But, instead of considering the advantages or disadvantages of the Reforms, it would be more appropriate here to consider what is in the interest of the citizens.
('26', 229, 1, 6, 556490) The pledge which they have taken should be honoured.
('26', 229, 1, 7, 556543) If they accept defeat on such simple issues, I would say, and the world too would say, that they are not fit for local self government.
('26', 229, 1, 8, 556679) As our fitness for swaraj is to beproved by winning it, so also it is to be proved by displaying our capacity to preserve it.
('26', 229, 1, 9, 556805) We shall be considered strong only if we can defend the country against external aggression.
('26', 229, 1, 10, 556898) Only that person’s body is considered healthy who remains healthy even when attacked by germs from outside.
('26', 229, 1, 11, 557006) Education is the central issue in this battle.
('26', 229, 1, 12, 557053) The citizens may or may not protect their rights in other matters; but they would be completely defeated if they accept defeat in the field of education.
('26', 229, 1, 13, 557207) If this happens, it will be proved beyond doubt that the citizens have not learnt to think or act independently.
('26', 229, 1, 14, 557320) If the people give in, that would prove that the representatives, being resourceful, went on fighting the Government and the citizens enjoyed watching the fight, but that the latter did not bother in the least to think or act independently.
('26', 229, 1, 15, 557561) It is, therefore, the primary duty of the citizens of these two cities not only to retain complete control over their children’s education, but also to put it on such firm foundation that no one should be tempted to go to a Government school.
('26', 229, 1, 16, 557804) We shall discover, if we make this attempt, that anything which is not done spontaneously will not last long.
('26', 229, 1, 17, 557914) Only if the citizens are true non co operators will they refuse to send their children to Government schools.
('26', 229, 1, 18, 558024) If they care for the quality of their children’s education, they will put it on a sound foundation.
('26', 229, 1, 19, 558124) Likewise, educated persons in Ahmedabad and Surat will give their services for teaching, the citizens will offer convenient accommodation for schools and meet various other requirements and thus demonstrate to the
('26', 230, 0, 1, 558338) VOL. 26 : 24 JANUARY, 1922 12 NOVEMBER, 1923 231
('26', 230, 1, 2, 558387) Government nominated committees that they are ready for any number of sacrifices for the sake of their children’s education.
('26', 230, 1, 3, 558512) We have to face the urgent problem of funds for this educati onal programme.
('26', 230, 1, 4, 558589) It is my considered view that the citizens have the right to refuse to pay the educational cess they have been paying.
('26', 230, 1, 5, 558708) Whether or not they insist on this right, it should not be difficult for the residents of Ahmedabad and Surat to collect the required amount.
('26', 230, 1, 6, 558850) By collecting it, they will demonstrate their strength and unity.
('26', 230, 1, 7, 558916) Money given for the purpose of education is no philanthropy.
('26', 230, 1, 8, 558977) It is investment of the best kind.
('26', 230, 1, 9, 559012) Parents will get full return on it.
('26', 230, 1, 10, 559048) I hope that the residents of the two cities will manage all these things without delay.
('26', 230, 1, 11, 559136) If Ahmedabad and Surat succeed in these tasks, there is not a shadow of a doubt that they will provide a splendid example for the rest of the country to follow.
('26', 230, 1, 12, 559297) It cannot but have a profound effect on the kind of swaraj the country will have.
('26', 230, 1, 13, 559379) If these two cities can achieve this without rousing the least hatred or resentment and without violation of peace to the slightest extent, we shall have demonstrated effectively how non violent non co operation should be carried on.
('26', 230, 1, 14, 559613) I should like the citizens to assert their independence in other matters also; however, it is my considered advice to leaders to move slowly and take every step after careful deliberation.
('26', 230, 1, 15, 559802) I hear it said that the citizens have lost heart because of the suspension of civil disobedience in Bardoli and the loss of control over the municipalities.
('26', 230, 1, 16, 559959) If this be so, they have not understood the meaning of non co operation nor have they understood the nature of their own fight.
('26', 230, 1, 17, 560087) In non co operation, resolutions such as those passed at Bardoli are quite normal.
('26', 230, 1, 18, 560170) In a great war, one strategy after another is adopted and abandoned.
('26', 230, 1, 19, 560239) The aim behind all is one and the same.
('26', 230, 1, 20, 560279) It is sometimes as necessary to abandon a strategy as it may have been to adopt it.
('26', 230, 1, 21, 560363) There is no room for defeat in a satyagraha struggle, whereas there is every possibility of one in an ordinary battle; but, even when defeated, the troops do not lose courage.
('26', 230, 1, 22, 560539) We Indians have been accused of being unable to stand a defeat.
('26', 230, 1, 23, 560603) Defeat in a single battle sees us running away in confusion.
('26', 230, 1, 24, 560664) I cherish an earnest hope that India will give a lie to this accusation.
('26', 230, 1, 25, 560737) As for the Bardoli resolutions, I do not regard them as signs of our defeat at all.
('26', 230, 1, 26, 560821) I look upon them, rather, as sure signs of our regard for truth and our courage.
('26', 230, 1, 27, 560902) Moreover, the struggle in Ahmedabad and Surat is a local one.
('26', 231, 0, 1, 560964) 232 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('26', 231, 1, 2, 561006) It must not be affected by the Bardoli resolutions.
('26', 231, 1, 3, 561058) Why, again, should there be any disappointment because of the supersession of the municipalities?
('26', 231, 1, 4, 561156) Our actions were deliberately intended to bring about this result.
('26', 231, 1, 5, 561223) The underlying purpose of the struggle is to see that at every step the Government places itself in a false position.
('26', 231, 1, 6, 561341) It is designed to expose its autocratic ways.
('26', 231, 1, 7, 561387) The net result of the nomination of committees by it is that the municipalities of Ahmedabad and Surat are now completely in the non co operation camp.
('26', 231, 1, 8, 561539) The citizens alone can now check their advance in that direction.
('26', 231, 1, 9, 561605) It is true that we have lost control over a few buildings and other things.
('26', 231, 1, 10, 561681) What does that matter?
('26', 231, 1, 11, 561704) The representatives of the people can meet under a mango tree.
('26', 231, 1, 12, 561767) It is not necessary for them to meet in granite buildings for transacting their business.
('26', 231, 1, 13, 561857) The new committees cannot insist on getting the latrines cleaned against the will of the people; nor on lighting the streets..
('26', 231, 1, 14, 561984) The citizens can demonstrate within one week that the committees can do only what they permit them to do.
('26', 231, 1, 15, 562090) I, therefore, see no reason for the leastfeeling of frustration.
('26', 231, 1, 16, 562155) Such a feeling can only be a sign of our ignorance.

('26', 231, 2, 18, 562244) 105. MY NOTES
('26', 231, 3, 19, 562258) IN THE CALCUTTA JAIL
('26', 231, 4, 20, 562279) Harilal Gandhi writes from the Calcutta Jail: 1
('26', 231, 5, 21, 562327) The news which appeared in the papers, that the sentences of the prisoners in Calcutta Jail have been reduced by half, has turned out in many cases to be without foundation.
('26', 231, 6, 22, 562501) HOW CAN WE POSSIBLY PAY “CHOTHAI”?
('26', 231, 7, 23, 562536) The leading Patidars of Karamsad 2 had come forward to offer civil disobedience with such courage that they were prepared to be ruined.
('26', 231, 7, 24, 562672) Now that they are required to pay up the revenue dues under the Bardoli Resolution, they feel unhappy.
('26', 231, 7, 25, 562775) To add to this, the Government officials, in their vindictiveness, demand chothai which the Patidars simply cannot bring themselves to pay.
('26', 231, 8, 26, 562915) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('26', 231, 8, 27, 562952) 2 In Anand taluka, which was preparing to offer civil disobedience under the leadership of Abbas Tyabji
('26', 232, 0, 1, 563056) VOL. 26 : 24 JANUARY, 1922 12 NOVEMBER, 1923 233
('26', 232, 1, 2, 563105) But did we ever expect any decency from the Government?
('26', 232, 1, 3, 563161) Is it ever likely to miss an opportunity of victimizing people?
('26', 232, 1, 4, 563225) Decency on our part consists in permitting them to have their revenge without getting angry ourselves.
('26', 232, 1, 5, 563328) We should not even petition the officials to waive the demand.
('26', 232, 1, 6, 563391) To pay such fines is part of our atonement.
('26', 232, 1, 7, 563435) If people are prepared to be ruined, what objection can they have to paying a fine?
('26', 232, 1, 8, 563519) But those who pay such fine may rest assured that, when we have swaraj or when there is a settlement, their fines will be refunded if they demand that they should be.
('26', 232, 1, 9, 563686) I would particularly advise those from whom chothai is demanded that they should pay it up and keep an account of the payment.
('26', 232, 1, 10, 563813) The path of satyagraha has its own laws; it requires discrimi nation and readiness to suffer.
('26', 232, 1, 11, 563907) We should not hope that we shall have our revenge on such officials when our turn comes.
('26', 232, 1, 12, 563996) If anyone punishes us but we do not retaliate, the other person’s fund of hatred will be exhausted.
('26', 232, 1, 13, 564096) It is a universal law that an action which meets with no reaction finally spends itself.
('26', 232, 1, 14, 564185) One who has understood this law will never think of taking revenge.
('26', 232, 2, 15, 564253) CIVIL DISOBEDIENCE IN JHARIA
('26', 232, 3, 16, 564282) I had told the delegates who had assembled for the Congress week that the people should not plunge into active civil disobedience in Jharia, and I had said that I would write a note on this in Navajivan.
('26', 232, 3, 17, 564486) I beg forgiveness of these gentlemen for having forgotten to do so.
('26', 232, 3, 18, 564554) The circumstances in Jharia are exceptional.
('26', 232, 3, 19, 564599) There are thousands of workers there.
('26', 232, 3, 20, 564637) Besides them, only well to do Marwari, Gujarati, Bengali and other business people who have dealings with them live there.
('26', 232, 3, 21, 564760) To start active civil disobedience in this place will certainly mean arousing the working class.
('26', 232, 3, 22, 564857) Even individual civil disobedience is likely to cause excitement among them.
('26', 232, 3, 23, 564934) I have, therefore, given my emphatic advice against starting active civil disobedience in this place at present.
('26', 232, 3, 24, 565047) To introduce civil disobedience among workers would be inviting trouble.
('26', 232, 3, 25, 565120) In such places, therefore, activities like promoting the use of khadi, popularizing the spinning wheel and carrying on propaganda against drinking should be greatly intensified and, since Jharia is a mine of wealth as much as, and because, it is a centre of coal mines, it should provide the money required for all the activities in Bihar.
('26', 232, 3, 26, 565460) Ramjas Babu and other rich gentlemen of the place can give the fullest help in such work.
('26', 232, 3, 27, 565550) If they solve the Bihar Provincial
('26', 233, 0, 1, 565585) 234 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('26', 233, 1, 2, 565627) Congress Committee’s difficulties about money, spread the use of khadi among workers, themselves spin and persuade the latter to spin and weave, see that they give up drinking and make them aware of their duties and then of their rights, I would think that they had fully served the cause of non co operation.
('26', 233, 2, 3, 565937) PLEADING IN AGENCY COURTS
('26', 233, 3, 4, 565963) A friend writes to ask me if it is true that I have expressed the view that every non co operator can practise in Agency courts.
('26', 233, 3, 5, 566092) I have given such advice to no one.
('26', 233, 3, 6, 566128) However, with reference to the cases of Shri Mansukhlal and Shri Manilal Kothari which have recently come up in Kathiawar, I have indeed said that they can defend themselves in Agency courts and engage counsel.
('26', 233, 3, 7, 566339) Both of them are subjects of Indian States and are trying to uphold their own and others’ rights in these States.
('26', 233, 3, 8, 566453) They are not non co operators with regard to matters arising out of circumstances in Indian States.
('26', 233, 3, 9, 566553) Hence, if they wish to take up the problems of these States theywill have to be ready for fighting in courts and for similar steps, otherwise they will run the risk of having the worst of both the worlds.
('26', 233, 3, 10, 566758) This certainly does not mean that a lawyer who has joined non co operation may appear in cases in Agency courts or that a non co operator may himself resort to legal proceedings in them, nor does it imply that he can engage a lawyer in any matter arising out of his actions as a non co operator within the jurisdiction of an Agency; but it does mean that, if a non co operator has money claims in an Indian State, he can take the matter to a State court and engage a lawyer for the purpose.
('26', 233, 3, 11, 567249) We are not offering non co operation against the Indian States or the law courts there; hence dealings with the latter need not be avoided altogether.
('26', 233, 3, 12, 567400) But all such things are full of complications.
('26', 233, 3, 13, 567447) Non co operators, therefore, should take care not to place themselves in such difficult situations.
('26', 233, 3, 14, 567547) It is for this very reason that I have often said earlier that, for the present, it is not desirable for non co operators living in Indian States to get involved in local problems, otherwise they will run the risk of getting completely entangled in them.
('26', 233, 3, 15, 567802) However, according to the present policy in regard to non co operation, I think there can be no objection to anyone who does not mind being so entangled or who involuntarily gets involved in such a dispute, fighting out the matter in a court of law.
('26', 233, 3, 16, 568052) The foregoing gentlemen have been arrested in connection with
('26', 234, 0, 1, 568114) VOL. 26 : 24 JANUARY, 1922 12 NOVEMBER, 1923 235
('26', 234, 1, 2, 568163) matters relating to Indian States and the Agency officer has attacked the rights of the subjects of Indian States.
('26', 234, 1, 3, 568278) I see no objection to their taking legal steps in this matter.
('26', 234, 1, 4, 568341) Though both of them are non co operators in British India, they have been arrested in Kathiawar and they can, therefore, get released on bail and defend themselves.
('26', 234, 1, 5, 568506) It may be objected that an Agency, too, is part of the British Empire.
('26', 234, 1, 6, 568577) Someone may argue that what I have said seems reasonable enough so far as courts in Indian States are concerned, but that it is difficult to accept that position with regard to courts in the Agencies.
('26', 234, 1, 7, 568778) There are two aspects of this.
('26', 234, 1, 8, 568809) Just as the Agency is part of the British Empire, it is also part of the Indian States concerned.
('26', 234, 1, 9, 568907) Agencies exist because Indian States exist.
('26', 234, 1, 10, 568951) Hence, it is permissible for one to go to Agency courts in matters relating to Indian States, but a person cannot defend himself, or get himself released on bail, if he had gone to the Agency to preach non co operation and was arrested for that reason.
('26', 234, 1, 11, 569204) This is why I have been advising people from the very beginning that non co operation should not be introduced in Indian States, that people should work there to promote only such activities as swadeshi which give no cause for objection, and these, too, from a purely economic and moral point of view, and consequently that we should have no Congress Committees, etc., in Indian States and that those who wish to join the Congress may get themselves enrolled in any Committee in British India.
('26', 234, 1, 12, 569698) There is a way of resolving all these difficulties in an unexcep tionable manner.
('26', 234, 1, 13, 569780) We shall never go wrong if we always follow it.
('26', 234, 1, 14, 569828) If in any step we wish to take we are motivated by any kind of fear or self interest—for instance the fear of imprisonment—we should not take that step.
('26', 234, 1, 15, 569981) A non co operator must be fearless and unselfish; if he is truthful, non violent, fearless and unselfish, he will make no mistake.
('26', 234, 1, 16, 570112) He will consult his conscience and then go ahead unhesitatingly.
('26', 234, 1, 17, 570177) INSTANCE OF OPPOSITE KIND In the note above, we considered instances of conduct which might appear to be contrary to the principle of non co operation.
('26', 234, 1, 18, 570329) A correspondent from Indore reports an opposite instance.
('26', 234, 1, 19, 570387) He says that, at the time of the visit of the Prince of Wales to Indore, three gentlemen, Pandit Arya Datta, Sheth Chhotalal and Sheth Badrina rayan, all residents of Indore Cantonment, were ordered to leave the area.
('26', 234, 1, 20, 570605) They disregarded the order and were arrested in consequence.
('26', 234, 1, 21, 570666) They neither engaged lawyers nor defended themselves and are now
('26', 235, 0, 1, 570731) 236 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('26', 235, 1, 2, 570773) undergoing sentence of simple imprisonment for a month.
('26', 235, 1, 3, 570829) Thus, in this instance, people were arrested and imprisoned for offering non co operation as advised by the Congress.
('26', 235, 1, 4, 570947) The same correspo ndent reports further that fourteen other volunteers have also been arrested.
('26', 235, 1, 5, 571043) An athlete named Ramnarayan kept up his self control even when beaten up by a soldier, though he had strength enough to fight back.
('26', 235, 1, 6, 571175) NOTION OF BEING DEFILED IS LIKE A SUPERFLUOUS LIMB” 1
('26', 235, 2, 7, 571229) An Antyaj friend from Amreli writes:
('26', 235, 3, 8, 571266) There is intense contempt for Antyajas in the land of your birth.
('26', 235, 3, 9, 571332) The less said about the evil of untouchability in Kathiawar, the better I have been as far as Porbandar.
('26', 235, 3, 10, 571437) There is less of it by one or two per cent in Rajkot, Bhavnagar and Amreli; but, on the whole there is much more of it in Kathiawar than in Gujarat.
('26', 235, 3, 11, 571586) What if it happens to be my land of birth?
('26', 235, 3, 12, 571629) A man does not show that he is a good son by drowning himself in his father’s well.
('26', 235, 3, 13, 571713) As I quote this extract from the letter, I feel ashamed of the land of my birth.

('26', 240, 1, 2, 583128) 106. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS
('26', 240, 2, 3, 583156) DELHI, February 26, 1922
('26', 240, 3, 4, 583181) Mahatma Gandhi in the course of a Press interview made the following important statements:
('26', 240, 4, 5, 583272) He said that the proceedings of the All India Congress Committee were a perfect study.
('26', 240, 4, 6, 583359) I am not in a position to divulge all that happened in that Committee; not that there is anything to hide or to be ashamed of.
('26', 240, 4, 7, 583486) One thing was absolutely clear that there was deep disappointment and even strong resentment against the Bardoli resolutions 1.Coming as they did close upon the rejoinder 2 to the Government communique 3, it was difficult for the members to understand or appreciate the reason for a departure from the steps contemplated in my letter 4 to the Viceroy.
('26', 240, 4, 8, 583838) There was even a suspicion, not audible but certainly very visible, that I was labouring under the influence of Pandit Malaviyaji.
('26', 240, 4, 9, 583969) I was able to show that my own opinion was arrived at totally independently of Malaviyaji and before I met him after the Chauri Chaura tragedy.
('26', 240, 4, 10, 584113) Personally nothing would please me better than to be able to confess that I had yielded upon any point to Panditji’s persuasions.
('26', 240, 4, 11, 584243) On this matter of non co operation and civil disobedi ence it has always been a matter of grief to me to differ from Panditji.
('26', 240, 4, 12, 584370) However, I mention this merely to show the intensity of feeling.
('26', 240, 4, 13, 584435) It speaks volumes for the loyalty of the members of the All India Congress Committee to the Congress and for the discipline observed by them that in spite of their bitter disappointment and resentment they subsequently and after a full debate substantially confirmed the Bardoli resolutions.
('26', 240, 4, 14, 584727) I must confess that I myself do not like the wording of the covering resolution.
('26', 240, 4, 15, 584808) It is unnecessarily explanatory; the definitions, the reiteration of Congress policy and civil disobedience seem to me to be out of place; but when it became a matter of soothing ruffled feelings and of avoiding misunderstandings and misinterpretations I felt that it was better to be tautological and
('26', 240, 5, 16, 585110) 1 Of February 11 and 12 2 Of February 7 3 Of February 6; Vide Appendix “Interview to C. Rajagopalachari”, 3 4 1922.

('26', 241, 1, 2, 585284) verbose as the covering resolution undoubtedly is than to appear to be obscure or ambiguous.
('26', 241, 2, 3, 585377) For once I can generally endorse the interpretation put upon the Bardoli resolutions by Sir William Vincent.
('26', 241, 2, 4, 585486) He is quite correct in saying that the Bardoli resolutions do not in any shape or form mean a reversal of the policy or the modification of the Congress programme of non co operation and that it is merely a suspension of mass civil disobedience, and a suspension, till further instructions, of other activities of an aggressive character.
('26', 241, 2, 5, 585825) It could not be otherwise.
('26', 241, 2, 6, 585852) The Bardoli resolutions were addressed to the people and were intended to be of a penitential nature and also to prove incontestably to the people who are in symapthy with the movement that the sympathy of those who believe in violence not only not required but is held to be injurious to the cause.
('26', 241, 3, 7, 586152) I would however warn my critics and I know, some of them, although very friendly, have become very sensitive of fate.
('26', 241, 3, 8, 586270) Iwarn such critics against reading into the covering resolution any radical notification of the Bardoli resolutions except in two particulars.
('26', 241, 3, 9, 586413) One is the restoration of permission to resort to bona fide picketing of foreign cloth under direct supervision of local Congress committees, to be carried on by persons of known good character.
('26', 241, 3, 10, 586608) Complaints were bitter against foreign cloth merchants as to their indifference to the growing popular dislike, even on the part of those who use it, for foreign cloth, as also to the breach of solemn promises made by these merchants that they would not import any more foreign cloth.
('26', 241, 3, 11, 586893) The people have rightly resented the unpatriotic and selfish attitude of the merchants who in their desire to amass wealth have utterly disregarded the popular feeling against any further importation of foreign cloth into this country.
('26', 241, 3, 12, 587129) It would be a grave mistake to suppose that this opposition to foreign cloth is based upon any ill will.
('26', 241, 3, 13, 587234) Dislike of foreign cloth is a proof of national consciousness, of a supreme economic fact and this statement received additional support from the opposition that is growing against the use of cloth manufactured by mills of India.
('26', 241, 3, 14, 587464) There can be no question of ill will against those who are engaged in the mill industry of India.
('26', 241, 3, 15, 587562) But till the nation realizes, as I think it will, that the masses can as little afford to buy cloth manufactured in mills as it can afford to buy food cooked in hotels, it is impossible to withstand that unanimous demand for picketing foreign cloth shops.
('26', 241, 3, 16, 587818) I can only hope that the merchants of India who

('26', 242, 1, 2, 587915) have all these long years been engaged in a trade which has brought about the daily growing pauperism of the masses will rise to the occasion and even like the Japanese Samurai recognize the necessity of a little sacrifice.
('26', 242, 1, 3, 588139) I consider the sacrifice of foreign cloth trade slight for the simple reason that the merchants can find a respectable living if they turn their attention to organizing the khaddar manufacture and the khaddar trade and thus render even peaceful picketing wholly unnecessary.
('26', 242, 1, 4, 588414) If they would only co operate I would love to divert the energy of the best men and women in the country from picketing foreign cloth shops to becoming expert spinners, weavers, and carders and manufacturers of khaddar as fast as they can.
('26', 242, 1, 5, 588654) The second modification is that the power of reverting to individual civil disobedience whether of a defensive or of offensive type has been again given by the All India Congress Committee to theprovinces.
('26', 242, 1, 6, 588860) It does not therefore mean that the provinces are required immediately to resort to individual civil disobedience but it gives each province full powers to do so if circumstances required it and if the necessary non violent atmosphere is present in that province.
('26', 242, 1, 7, 589124) Whilst the provinces have thus their autonomy which was granted to them in November last at Delhi 1 restored to them, I would strongly advise them not to exercise those powers without the greatest deliberation or with undue haste.
('26', 242, 1, 8, 589355) Indeed I would advise them, unless circumstances render civil disobedience absolutely imperative, to take a little rest, and purge their volunteers, register of all the names of those who did not believe in every single detail of the requirements of the Congress pledge.
('26', 242, 1, 9, 589626) It would really add to the strength of the movement if the provinces before re embarking upon individual civil disobedience would put their house in thorough order and ensure perfect non violence, non violence not merely in deed but in thought and word.
('26', 242, 1, 10, 589880) Whilst it is perfectly true that the country as a whole has made remarkable progress in the cultivation of a non violent spirit it cannot be denied that there is still great room for the improvement and that we are living in a state of perpetual suspense.
('26', 242, 1, 11, 590136) The ideal atmosphere for civil disobedience, whether individual or mass, is undoubtedly an atmosphere of perfect calm.

('26', 244, 1, 5, 593897) Whilst from the Congress standpoint condemnation of the acts of the mob can be regarded as too severe, from the public point of view, I can safely say that blame can at least be evenly distributed between the Congress organizations and the Government.

('26', 245, 1, 2, 595548) 107. NOTES
('26', 245, 2, 3, 595559) CONGRESS A FETISH
('26', 245, 3, 4, 595577) We must avoid the Congress becoming a fetish.
('26', 245, 3, 5, 595623) I love the idea of everybody becoming a Congressman and everybody yielding willing and intelligent obedience to the Congress resolutions.
('26', 245, 3, 6, 595761) But I abhor the idea of anybody becoming a Congressman merely because it is an old or a great institution or yielding obedience to its resolutions whether one likes it or not.
('26', 245, 3, 7, 595937) The rule of majority has a narrow application, i.e., one should yield to the majority in matters of detail.
('26', 245, 3, 8, 596045) But it is slavery to be amenable to the majority no matter what its decisions are.
('26', 245, 3, 9, 596128) Thus notwithstanding the Congress resolution, it is wrong, in my opinion, to withdraw from Councils or not to covet election thereto, if one believes that Councils are even a tolerably good institution.
('26', 245, 3, 10, 596331) It is similarly wrong for a lawyer to suspend practice merely because the Congress says so.
('26', 245, 3, 11, 596423) Democracy is not a state in which people act like sheep.
('26', 245, 3, 12, 596480) Under democracy individual liberty of opinion and action is jealously guarded.
('26', 245, 3, 13, 596559) I therefore believe that the minority has a perfect right to act differently from the majority so long as it does not act in the name of the Congress.
('26', 245, 3, 14, 596710) A practising lawyer may become a Congressman; he cannot be called a non co operator.
('26', 245, 3, 15, 596795) He cannot and should not, therefore, be on the All India Congress Committee.

('26', 265, 7, 26, 648580) A PEEP OF A BOMBAY JAIL
('26', 265, 8, 27, 648604) With the compliments of the Director of Information, Bombay.
('26', 265, 9, 28, 648665) 1 Only excerpts from his letter reproduced above
('26', 266, 0, 1, 648714) VOL. 26 : 24 JANUARY, 1922 12 NOVEMBER, 1923 267
('26', 266, 1, 2, 648763) In the issue of Young India for January 19 an extract was printed from The Hindu dealing with the alleged ill treatment of a certain “Rahmat Rasool, a Punjabi Martial Law prisoner”, in the Hyderabad Central Prison.
('26', 266, 1, 3, 648978) 1 Enquiries show that the allegations made are unfounded.
('26', 266, 1, 4, 649036) The article appears to refer to a Gujarati prisoner named Himat Rasool, who was sentenced by the Ahmedabad Special Tribunal to transportation for life for cutting telegraph wires, setting fire to the telegraph office and rioting at Ahmedabad on 11th April 1919. The charges made and the actual facts relating thereto are as follows:
('26', 266, 2, 5, 649369) “On their arrival in this jail from the Andamans in November last no meals were given them for three days until the medical officer saw them and got them meals.”
('26', 266, 3, 6, 649531) The prisoners (who arrived on December 6th) were seen daily both by the medical officer and the Superintendent but they refused to take jowari diet as they wanted wheat diet.
('26', 266, 3, 7, 649706) This was given them on December 8th.
('26', 266, 3, 8, 649743) “Whenever the Superintendent approached them they were required to raise their hands as a Muslim does in prayer with the greeting ‘Sarkar is one’.
('26', 266, 3, 9, 649890) This immoral rule, interfering with the fundamental principles of Islam, Rahmat Rasool refused to obey, telling the Superintendent that for him God alone is one and that he can raise his hand in prayer before God alone, when the Superintendent proudly replied that he, as representative of Government, was his god in jail.” This is a pure invention.
('26', 266, 3, 10, 650240) When the Superintendent or any official visits the prisoners, the latter stand with their hands open, the arms being at right angles to the elbows and the elbows in at the sides.
('26', 266, 3, 11, 650419) The object of this is to show that there is nothing concealed in the hands with which an assault can be attempted.
('26', 266, 3, 12, 650534) This attitude is obviously not that of a Muslim raising his hands in prayer and the procedure to which no objection has ever been raised is common to all jails.
('26', 266, 3, 13, 650695) It is absolutely untrue that the Superintendent used the words attributed to him.
('26', 266, 3, 14, 650777) “The prisoner refused to be led away from the path of religion with the result that his religiousness was rewarded with the five fold punishment of 30 stripes, 6 months’ solitary confinement, six months’ gunny clothing, 6 months’ cross fetters and 6 months’ bar fetters.” The facts are that on December 13th the prisoner refused to stand up when ordered, became very excited and was grossly impertinent to the Superintendent.
('26', 266, 3, 15, 651203) He was awarded, not the punishment alleged but gunny clothing for one month and bar fetters for three months.
('26', 266, 3, 16, 651313) Since the arrival of this prisoner in jail he has been eleven times awarded punishments, including 30 stripes and cross bar fetters for ten days for gross insubordination and persistently refusing to work.
('26', 266, 3, 17, 651519) He is at present undergoing a punishment of three months’ separate confinement awarded him in the Andamans for refusing to work and refusing to obey orders.
('26', 266, 3, 18, 651676) His history sheet describes him as “a man of violent temper”.
('26', 266, 4, 19, 651738) 20th February, 1922 I venture to call this a brazen defence of a brutal punishment.
('26', 266, 5, 20, 651822) 1 Vide “Worse than Martial Law”, 19 1 1922.
('26', 267, 0, 1, 651866) 268 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('26', 267, 1, 2, 651908) tells the public in so many words, “We have done it and we pro pose to continue.” As I did not publish the incident for the edificationof the Government, I remain unperturbed by the shameless admission.
('26', 267, 1, 3, 652111) The reader will please note that in all this communique there is no denial of a single material in particular.
('26', 267, 1, 4, 652222) It makes no difference whether the name or description of the prisoner is correctly given.
('26', 267, 1, 5, 652313) The facts that the prisoner had to starve for three days, that he had to stretch forth his hands in a humiliating fashion, that he had gunny clothing for one month, bar fetters for three, and thirty stripes and that he is now undergoing separate confinement for three months is sufficient corroboration of the allegations of The Hindu.
('26', 267, 1, 6, 652649) I am prepared to assume that every prisoner who receives punishment is, in official parlance “a man of violent temper”.

('26', 268, 1, 2, 653894) 111. LETTER TO M. R. JAYAKAR
('26', 268, 2, 3, 653923) [March 2, 1922] 1
('26', 268, 3, 4, 653941) I was so sorry you became suddenly ill and had to get down at Palghar.
('26', 268, 3, 5, 654012) I would like you carefully to read every line of Young India.
('26', 268, 3, 6, 654074) I write to you to tell you that the meeting of the All India Congress has simply confirmed the views with which I left Bardoli.
('26', 268, 3, 7, 654202) So far as my influence counts I am going to dissuade people in the different provinces from embarking upon even defensive civil disobedience.
('26', 268, 3, 8, 654344) For the time being, I have persuaded them to concentrate their attention upon the constructive programme, but all this does not mean any change in my attitude towards the Government.
('26', 268, 3, 9, 654527) Its fraud, its hypocrisy, its unblushing worship of violence repel me more than ever and the time may come when I would want to shun the multitude as much as I shun the Government, though for a different reason.
('26', 268, 3, 10, 654739) I am anxious to enlist your full co operation.
('26', 268, 3, 11, 654786) Will you not give your whole hearted co operation in the prosecution of this constructive programme?
('26', 268, 3, 12, 654887) I would like you not to be engrossed in the effort to bring about a round table conference, which is a futile effort at the present time ; nor to be thinking of the prisoners.
('26', 268, 3, 13, 655063) They will be quite all right taking their rest cure in the prisons.
('26', 268, 3, 14, 655131) I would so much like you to give your undivided attention to some part or other of the constructive programme.
('26', 268, 3, 15, 655242) If you are well, as I hope you are, I would even trouble you to come over here and pass a quiet day with me.
('26', 268, 3, 16, 655351) We could then discuss the possibilities of working along the lines indicated by me.
('26', 268, 3, 17, 655435) I am in Ahmedabad till Wednesday.
('26', 268, 3, 18, 655469) Next Monday, as you know, is my silent day.
('26', 268, 3, 19, 655513) This will be in your hands on Friday.
('26', 268, 3, 20, 655551) You can come on Saturday, Sunday, Tuesday or Wednesday, the earlier is better.

('26', 269, 1, 2, 655724) 112. LETTER TO KONDA VENKATAPPAYYA 1
('26', 269, 2, 3, 655761) SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, SABARMATI, March 4, 1922
('26', 269, 3, 4, 655805) MY DEAR FRIEND, I have kept your letter of the 19th February in order to be able to write to you at length.
('26', 269, 3, 5, 655913) Your first question is whether the requisite non violent atmosphere can at all be attained and if so when.
('26', 269, 3, 6, 656020) This is really a question as old as non co operation.
('26', 269, 3, 7, 656074) It puzzles me to find some of the closest and most esteemed of co workers putting the question as if the requirement was a new thing.
('26', 269, 3, 8, 656208) I have not the shadow of a doubt that, if we can secure workers with an abiding faith in non violence and in themselves, we can ensure the non violent atmosphere required for the working of civil disobedience.
('26', 269, 3, 9, 656418) The discovery I have made during these few days is that very few understand the nature of non violence.
('26', 269, 3, 10, 656522) The meaning of the adjective “civil” before “disobedience” is of course “non violent”.
('26', 269, 3, 11, 656609) Why should the people not be trained to refrain from participating in activites which are likely to throw them off their balance?
('26', 269, 3, 12, 656739) I agree that it will be difficult to get 30 crores of people to be non violent, but I refuse to belive that it is diffcult, if we can get intelligent and honest workers, to make people who are not actively participating in the movement remain indoors.
('26', 269, 3, 13, 656991) Now, at Chauri Chaura 2 the procession was deliberately formed by volunteers.
('26', 269, 3, 14, 657069) It was wickedly taken in the direction of the Thana.
('26', 269, 3, 15, 657122) In my opinion, the forming of the procession itself was easily avoidable.
('26', 269, 3, 16, 657196) Having been formed, it was the easiest thing to avoid passing the Thana.
('26', 269, 3, 17, 657269) Two or three hundred volunteers are reported to have been in the procession.
('26', 269, 3, 18, 657346) I hold that it was equally easy for this large number of volunteers to have effectively prevented the atrocious murder of the constables or at least for every one of them to have perished in the flames lit by the mob which they were leading.
('26', 269, 3, 19, 657588) I must not also omit to tell you that these men knew that trouble was brewing, knew that the Sub Inspector was there, knew that there was collision between him and the people on two former occasions.
('26', 269, 3, 20, 657788) Was not the Chauri Chaura tragedy
('26', 269, 4, 21, 657822) 1 President, Andhra Provincial Congress Committee 2 A village in Gorakhpur district of Uttar Pradesh where on February 5, 1922, the mob set fire to the police station and 22 constables were burnt alive.
('26', 269, 4, 22, 658025) Gandhiji was profoundly shocked by this and imposed on himself a five days’ fast on February 12; Vide “The Crime of Chauri Chaura”, 16 2 1922.
('26', 270, 0, 1, 658168) VOL. 26 : 24 JANUARY, 1922 12 NOVEMBER, 1923 271
('26', 270, 1, 2, 658217) absolutely capable of being avoided?
('26', 270, 1, 3, 658254) I admit that nobody plotted the murder, but the volunteers should have foreseen the consequence of what they were doing.
('26', 270, 1, 4, 658375) Of the Bombay tragedy I was myself a witness.
('26', 270, 1, 5, 658421) The workers neglected the duty of telling the people, whilst they were preparing them about boycott, to remain tolerant, as also of posting volunteers in areas visited by the labouring population.
('26', 270, 1, 6, 658618) I myself neglected the duty of putting down every insolent laying of hands upon other people’s turbans and caps.
('26', 270, 1, 7, 658731) Finally take Madras.
('26', 270, 1, 8, 658752) Not one single incident which happened in Madras was unavoidable.
('26', 270, 1, 9, 658818) I hold the Congress Committee responsible for all that happened in Madras.
('26', 270, 1, 10, 658893) With the experience of Bombay fresh in their minds they could, even if they were not fully confident, have avoided hartal.
('26', 270, 1, 11, 659016) The fact is in every case all the workers did not understand the full purpose of non violence nor its implications.
('26', 270, 1, 12, 659132) They liked and loved excitement, and underneath these vast demonstrations was an idea unconsciously lurking in the breast that it was a kind of demonstration of force, the very negation of non violence.
('26', 270, 1, 13, 659335) To follow out non violence as a policy surely does not require saints for its working, but it does require honest workers who understand what is expected of them.
('26', 270, 1, 14, 659498) You say that the people work under the spell of one year’s limit.
('26', 270, 1, 15, 659564) There is much truth in what you say, but there again, if the people worked slowly under that spell, they were certainly not working for swaraj.
('26', 270, 1, 16, 659708) I can understand some temporary excitement, but excitement must not be the whole thing, nor the main part of a great national activity.
('26', 270, 1, 17, 659844) Swaraj after all is not a mango trick; it is a steady evolution, steady growing into strength such that a period must arrive when our strength has assumed such proportions as to tell upon the usurpers, but every moment of our activity we are gaining swaraj.
('26', 270, 1, 18, 660102) Certainly a peaceful Tehsil at the foot of the Himalayas will be affected by a violent hamlet situated near the Cape Comorin if there is a vital connection between the two, as there must be if they are both integral parts of India and your swaraj flag is to dominate both.
('26', 270, 1, 19, 660375) At the same time, for mass civil disobedience in Bardoli, I would certainly have thought nothing of anything happening in an out of the way Tehsil which had not come under the influence of the Congress and which had not resorted to violence in connection with any Congress activity.
('26', 270, 1, 20, 660658) You cannot predicate any such want of connection about Gorakhpur, Bombay or Madras.
('26', 270, 1, 21, 660742) Violence broke out in connection with a national activity.
('26', 270, 1, 22, 660801) You have the forcible illustration of Malabar.
('26', 270, 1, 23, 660848) 1 There it was organized and sustained violence offered by the Moplahs, and yet I did not allow Malabar to affect any of our plans, nor have I
('26', 270, 2, 24, 660991) 1 Vide “Moplah Outbreak”, 4 9 1921.
('26', 271, 0, 1, 661027) 272 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('26', 271, 1, 2, 661069) altered my views during all these months.
('26', 271, 1, 3, 661111) I can still distinguish between Malabar and Gorakhpur.
('26', 271, 1, 4, 661166) The Moplahs themselves had not been touched by the non co operation spirit.
('26', 271, 1, 5, 661242) They are not like the other Indians nor even like the other Mussulmans.
('26', 271, 1, 6, 661314) I am prepared to admit that the movement had an indirect effect upon them.
('26', 271, 1, 7, 661389) The Moplah revolt was so different in kind that it did not affect the other parts of India, whereas Gorakhpur was typical, and therefore, if we had not taken energetic steps, the infection might easily have spread to the other parts of India.
('26', 271, 1, 8, 661632) You say that, individual civil disobedience being withdrawn, there will be no opportunity to test the temper of the people.
('26', 271, 1, 9, 661756) We do not want to test the temper.
('26', 271, 1, 10, 661791) On the contrary we want the people to become immersed in industries and constructive activities so that their temper is not exposed to the constant danger of being ruffled.
('26', 271, 1, 11, 661964) A man wishing to gain self control instead of exposing himself to temptations avoids them, though, at the same time, he is ready for them if they come to him unsought and in spite of his wanting to avoid them.
('26', 271, 1, 12, 662174) We certainly have not suspended any item of non co operation.
('26', 271, 1, 13, 662236) This you will see clearly brought out in Young India.
('26', 271, 1, 14, 662290) I am satisfied that our success depends upon our cultivating exemplary self restraint and not disobeying even unseen orders of prohibition of meetings.
('26', 271, 1, 15, 662442) We must learn to conduct our campaign in spite of prohibitions and without civil disobedience.
('26', 271, 1, 16, 662537) If the people want excitement, we must refuse to give it to them even though we have to risk unpopularity and find ourselves in a hopeless minority.

('26', 279, 1, 17, 683919) By abolishing the spinning wheel, we have invited upon our selves starvation and immorality.

('26', 279, 1, 30, 684899) The spinning wheel gives yarn according to our capacity.

('26', 280, 1, 2, 685005) Preserving the spinning wheel means protecting the cow.

('26', 280, 1, 9, 685640) As Indians are weak, so are all their cattle, for the country’s state is that of a bankrupt.
('26', 280, 1, 10, 685733) India uses up its capital resources in order to live.
('26', 280, 1, 11, 685787) The capital is getting exhausted day by day.
('26', 280, 1, 12, 685832) India does not get enough of oxygen and feels suffocated.

('26', 280, 1, 15, 686036) For crores of people, the spinning wheel is the only occupation which can supplement their income from the fields; most emphatically, they have no other one.

('26', 280, 3, 18, 686244) CONGRESS LEVY
('26', 280, 4, 19, 686258) Those who command people’s obedience have their taxes willingly paid.

('26', 282, 1, 12, 691294) AHMEDABAD MUNICIPALITY A municipality is under the general control of the people, while a Committee [appointed by the Government] has administrative authority in its own hands.
('26', 282, 1, 13, 691471) When the Government set up such a committee, the Municipality became national, because the relations of the people’s representatives with the Government came to an end.
('26', 282, 1, 14, 691640) This event can be viewed from two angles.
('26', 282, 1, 15, 691682) If we regard the suspension of the Municipality by the Government as an unexpected and unwelcome development, we cannot say that the Municipality has become national; we should say, rather, that people have been deprived of the power they enjoyed.
('26', 282, 1, 16, 691930) If we hold—and that of course is the right thing to do—that it was our aim that the Government should either surrender to the Municipality or suspend it, then we can say that the Municipality has become independent or national.
('26', 282, 1, 17, 692158) It is for the citizens to show whether or not it has really become national.
('26', 282, 1, 18, 692235) If they trust their representative and get the city’s work done through them, then the Municipality has become national.
('26', 282, 1, 19, 692356) If on the contrary they submit to the Committee even in matters in which they can easily exercise their freedom, it will be plain that the Municipality has been taken over by the Government.
('26', 282, 1, 20, 692547) The honour of the citizens and of their representatives rests in the hands of the citizens themselves.
('26', 282, 1, 21, 692650) No one can command the obedience of another against his wishes.
('26', 282, 1, 22, 692714) This is an immutable law.
('26', 282, 1, 23, 692740) It is true that, in thousands of instances, we feel that people are made to do

('26', 283, 1, 2, 692861) things under force.
('26', 283, 1, 3, 692881) If someone makes me do anything under threat of death, we call it coercion.
('26', 283, 1, 4, 692957) However, if I have no fear of death, who can force me to do anything?
('26', 283, 1, 5, 693027) I cannot, therefore, say that I have done anything against my wish.
('26', 283, 1, 6, 693095) When a person does something, submitting to physical force, it is certainly customary to say that he did what he did against his will.
('26', 283, 1, 7, 693230) Actually, it is not so.
('26', 283, 1, 8, 693254) The soul binds as well as releases itself.
('26', 283, 1, 9, 693297) The dispute was only about education.
('26', 283, 1, 10, 693335) As regards lighting, sanitation, water supply, etc., the Municipality certainly wanted to co operate with the Government.

('26', 284, 1, 9, 696178) MERCHANTS’ ANXIETY We see that the merchant class feels apprehensive at present.
('26', 284, 1, 10, 696259) The merchants fear that the present struggle will ruin business.
('26', 284, 1, 11, 696324) This is not a correct view.
('26', 284, 1, 12, 696352) The struggle is not directed against trade or traders; it is for the benefit of trade.
('26', 284, 1, 13, 696439) Today, out of every hundred rupees, the traders themselves earn only five and send the rest out of the country.
('26', 284, 1, 14, 696551) If the present struggle succeeds, they will retain all the hundred or keep five for themselves and let ninety five reach the homes of the poor.
('26', 284, 1, 15, 696695) Businessmen need only to be fearless, to have confidence and take a little risk.
('26', 284, 1, 16, 696776) It is not that the Government encourages trade; it encourages slavery and, at most, brokerage.
('26', 284, 1, 17, 696871) For every Indian whom it allows to be a millionaire, it helps a hundred others in Europe to be so.
('26', 284, 1, 18, 696970) I hope businessmen who understand this plain reasoning will plunge headlong into the struggle; if the trading class plays its part well, there will be an early end to this struggle and the traders themselves, as also the rest of the country, will be able to carry on their normal work in peace.
('26', 284, 1, 19, 697265) The cloth merchants will have to show more courage than others.
('26', 284, 1, 20, 697329) They should give up trade in foreign and mill cloth and should sell pure khadi only.
('26', 284, 1, 21, 697414) Honest trade in khadi also can flourish; it will provide livelihood to hundreds and thus promote the welfare of the people.
('26', 284, 1, 22, 697538) One need not assume that businessmen can never remain honest.
('26', 284, 1, 23, 697600) They will see from experience that, if they set a limit to their profits, they will never have to resort to untruth.

('26', 285, 1, 2, 697794) 116. FOREWORD
('26', 285, 2, 3, 697808) SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, SABARMATI, March 5, 1922 Typed copies of Mr. Badrul Hassan’s chapters on the Drink and Drug Evil have lain on my desk for over three months.
('26', 285, 2, 4, 697968) I had hoped to be able to go through them and write a fairly long foreword, and in that hope I have been postponing writing the foreword.
('26', 285, 2, 5, 698106) I must no longer do so.
('26', 285, 2, 6, 698130) Mr. Badrul Hassan was for many months assisting me in bringing out Young India from week to week.
('26', 285, 2, 7, 698228) The readers of Young India will recall his chapters on the Alcohol and Opium habits.
('26', 285, 2, 8, 698313) They discover a close study of blue books and statistical abstracts.
('26', 285, 2, 9, 698382) The chapters now presented to the reader are a reprint of Mr. Badrul Hassan’s writings in Young India with enlargements and additions.
('26', 285, 2, 10, 698517) They will repay perusal, and they cannot but help the reformer who is bent upon ridding India of the double evil.
('26', 285, 2, 11, 698631) Mr. Badrul Hassan’s study shows also how the policy of the Government has tended to increase the habit.
('26', 285, 2, 12, 698735) The facts and figures presented in these chapters to the reader demonstrate in the clearest possible manner that the Govern ment has trafficked in these two vices of the people of India.
('26', 285, 2, 13, 698922) It will be no defense to urge that the vice has existed in India from time immemorial.
('26', 285, 2, 14, 699009) No one organized the vice as the present Government has for purposes of revenue.
('26', 285, 2, 15, 699090) But I must not anticipate.
('26', 285, 2, 16, 699117) Let the young writer prove his own case.
('26', 285, 2, 17, 699158) M. K. GANDHI

('26', 287, 2, 3, 701501) Silence Day, March 6, 1922 You must have calmed down by now.
('26', 287, 2, 4, 701562) There is, therefore, not much to write.
('26', 287, 2, 5, 701602) I have not yet written to Mahadev.
('26', 287, 2, 6, 701637) I intend to do so today.
('26', 287, 2, 7, 701662) If I write, I shall send the letter to you and you may forward it to him, so that your curiosity may be satisfied.

('26', 287, 2, 9, 701836) I may learn something from it.
('26', 287, 2, 10, 701867) I am an anekantavadi.
('26', 287, 2, 11, 701889) This is the most important thing that I have learnt from Jain philosophy.
('26', 287, 2, 12, 701963) It is implicit in Vedanta philosophy, while in Jain philosophy it is explicitly stated.
('26', 287, 2, 13, 702051) I do not see any contradiction between what I did in Delhi 2 and what I am doing in suspending the movement.
('26', 287, 2, 14, 702160) Had I been rigid in Delhi, it would have been violence on my part.
('26', 287, 2, 15, 702227) When friends put their difficulties before me with an open mind, how could I brush them aside?
('26', 287, 2, 16, 702322) When, however I decided to give freedom to the Provinces, I made up my own plans and thus accommodated both the parties.
