('26', 288, 1, 2, 703410) 120. LETTER TO T. PRAKASAM
('26', 288, 2, 3, 703437) SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, SABARMATI, March 7, 1922
('26', 288, 3, 4, 703481) MY DEAR PRAKASAM 1, You ask me for my future programme.
('26', 288, 3, 5, 703537) I have just sent you a telegram as follows: “In Ahmedabad till Saturday Surat Sunday Monday Bardoli Tuesday.” But that is Government willing, for I have persistent rumours being thrust upon me that my leave is now more than over due, and I am also told that I shall be relieved of my burdens inside of 7 days.
('26', 288, 3, 6, 703847) Subject, therefore, to that happy contingency you have the foregoing programme.
('26', 288, 3, 7, 703927) If I am arrested, I look to you and all who are out to keep absolute peace.

('26', 288, 3, 11, 704388) I would certainly be delighted if on the night following my arrest there was throughout the length and breadth of India a bonfire of all foreign cloth voluntarily surrendered by the people without the slightest compulsion having been exercised and a fixed determination to use nothing but khaddar and, till then, in the glorious weather of India, to wear nothing but a piece of loin cloth, and in the case of Mussalmans the minimum required by religious obligation.

('26', 291, 4, 11, 709313) 124. NON VIOLENCE
('26', 291, 5, 12, 709331) When a person claims to be non violent, he is expected not to be angry with one who has injured him.
('26', 291, 5, 13, 709432) He will not wish him harm ; he will wish him well ; he will not swear at him ; he will not cause him any physical hurt.
('26', 291, 5, 14, 709552) He will put up with all the injury to which he is subjected by the wrongdoer.
('26', 291, 5, 15, 709630) Thus non violence is complete inno cence.
('26', 291, 5, 16, 709672) Complete non violence is complete absence of ill will against all that lives.
('26', 291, 5, 17, 709750) It therefore embraces even sub human life not excluding noxious insects or beasts.
('26', 291, 5, 18, 709833) They have not been created to feed our destructive propensities.
('26', 291, 5, 19, 709898) If we only knew the mind of the Creator, we should find their proper place in His creation.
('26', 291, 5, 20, 709990) Non violence is therefore, in its active form, goodwill towards all life.
('26', 291, 5, 21, 710064) It is pure Love.
('26', 291, 5, 22, 710081) I read it in the Hindu scriptures, in the Bible, in the Koran.
('26', 291, 5, 23, 710144) Non violence is a perfect state.
('26', 291, 5, 24, 710177) It is a goal towards which all mankind moves naturally though unconsciously.
('26', 291, 5, 25, 710254) Man does not become divine when he personifies innocence in himself.
('26', 291, 5, 26, 710323) Only then does he become truly man.
('26', 291, 5, 27, 710359) In our present state, we are partly men and partly beasts and, in our ignorance and even arrogance, say that we truly fulfil the purpose of our species when we deliver blow for blow and develop the measure of anger required for the purpose.
('26', 291, 5, 28, 710600) We pretend to believe that retaliation is the law of our being, whereas in every scripture we find that retaliation is nowhere obligatory but only permissible.
('26', 291, 5, 29, 710760) It is restraint that is obligatory.
('26', 291, 5, 30, 710796) Retaliation is indulgence requiring elaborate regulating.
('26', 291, 5, 31, 710854) Restraint is the law of our being.
('26', 291, 5, 32, 710889) For, highest perfection is unattainable without highest restraint.
('26', 291, 5, 33, 710956) Suffering is thus the badge of the human tribe.
('26', 291, 6, 34, 711004) 1 Anne Marie Petersen, a Danish missionary
('26', 292, 0, 1, 711047) VOL. 26 : 24 JANUARY, 1922 12 NOVEMBER, 1923 293
('26', 292, 1, 2, 711096) The goal ever recedes from us.
('26', 292, 1, 3, 711127) The greater the progress, the greater the recognition of our unworthiness.
('26', 292, 1, 4, 711202) Satisfaction lies in the effort, not in the attainment.
('26', 292, 1, 5, 711258) Full effort is full victory.
('26', 292, 1, 6, 711287) Therefore, though I realize more than ever how far I am from that goal, for me the Law of complete Love is the law of my being.
('26', 292, 1, 7, 711415) Each time I fail, my effort shall be all the more determined for my failure.
('26', 292, 1, 8, 711492) But I am not preaching this final law through the Congress or the Khilafat organization.
('26', 292, 1, 9, 711581) I know my own limitations only too well.
('26', 292, 1, 10, 711622) I know that any such attempt is foredoomed to failure.
('26', 292, 1, 11, 711677) To expect a whole mass of men and women to obey that law all at once is not to know its working.
('26', 292, 1, 12, 711774) But I do preach from the Congress platform the deductions of the law.
('26', 292, 1, 13, 711844) What the Congress and the Khilafat organi zations have accepted is but a fragment of the implications of that law.
('26', 292, 1, 14, 711959) Given true workers, the limited measure of its application can be realized in respect of vast masses of people within a short time.
('26', 292, 1, 15, 712091) But the little measure of it to be true must satisfy the same test as the whole.
('26', 292, 1, 16, 712172) A drop of water must yield to the analyst the same results as a lakeful.
('26', 292, 1, 17, 712245) The nature of my non violence towards my brother cannot be different from that of my non violence to the universe.
('26', 292, 1, 18, 712360) When I extend the love for my brother to the whole universe, it must still satisfy the same test.
('26', 292, 1, 19, 712458) A particular practice is a policy when its application is limited to time or space.
('26', 292, 1, 20, 712542) Highest policy is therefore fullest practice.
('26', 292, 1, 21, 712588) But honesty as policy while it lasts is not anything different from honesty as a creed.
('26', 292, 1, 22, 712676) A merchant believing in honesty as a policy will sell the same measure and quality of cloth to the yard as a merchant with honesty as a creed.
('26', 292, 1, 23, 712819) The difference between the two is that the political merchant will leave his honesty when it does not pay, the believing one will continue it even though he should lose his all.
('26', 292, 1, 24, 712997) The political non violence of the non co operator does not stand this test in the vast majority of cases.
('26', 292, 1, 25, 713103) Hence the prolongation of the struggle.
('26', 292, 1, 26, 713143) Let no one blame the unbending English nature.
('26', 292, 1, 27, 713190) The hardest “fibre” must melt in the fire of love.
('26', 292, 1, 28, 713241) I cannot be dislodged from the position because I know it.
('26', 292, 1, 29, 713300) When British or other nature does not respond, the fire is not strong enough, if it is there at all.
('26', 292, 1, 30, 713401) Our non violence need not be of the strong, but it has to be of the truthful.
('26', 292, 1, 31, 713479) We must not intend harm to the English or to our co operating countrymen if and whilst we claim to be non violent.
('26', 292, 1, 32, 713594) But the majority of us have intended harm and we have refrained from doing it because of our weakness or under the ignorant belief that mere refraining from physical hurt amounted to due fulfilment of our
('26', 293, 0, 1, 713799) 294 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('26', 293, 1, 2, 713841) pledge.
('26', 293, 1, 3, 713849) Our pledge of non violence excludes the possibility of future retaliation.
('26', 293, 1, 4, 713924) Some of us seem, unfortunately, to have merely postponed the date of revenge.
('26', 293, 1, 5, 714002) Let me not be misunderstood.
('26', 293, 1, 6, 714031) I do not say that the policy of non violence excludes the possibility of revenge when the policy is abandoned.
('26', 293, 1, 7, 714142) But it does most emphatically exclude the possibility of future revenge after a successful termination of the struggle.
('26', 293, 1, 8, 714262) Therefore, whilst we are pursuing the policy of non violence, we are bound to be actively friendly to English administrators and their co operators.
('26', 293, 1, 9, 714411) I felt ashamed when I was told that in some parts of India it was not safe for Englishmen or wellknown co operators to move about safely.
('26', 293, 1, 10, 714549) The disgraceful scenes that took place at a recent Madras meeting were a complete denial of non violence.
('26', 293, 1, 11, 714655) Those who howled down the Chairman, because he was supposed to have insulted me, disgraced themselves and their policy.
('26', 293, 1, 12, 714775) They wounded the heart of their friend and helper, Mr Andrews 1. They injured their own cause.
('26', 293, 1, 13, 714870) If the Chairman believed that I was a scoundrel, he had a perfect right to say so.
('26', 293, 1, 14, 714953) Ignorance is no provocation.
('26', 293, 1, 15, 714982) But a non co operator is pledged to put up with the gravest provocation.
('26', 293, 1, 16, 715055) Provocation there would be, when I act scoundrel like.
('26', 293, 1, 17, 715110) I grant that it will be enough to absolve every non co operator from the pledge of non violence and that any non co operator will be fully justified in taking my life for misleading him.
('26', 293, 1, 18, 715297) It may be that even cultivation of such limited non violence is impossible in the majority of cases.
('26', 293, 1, 19, 715398) It may be that we must not expect people even out of self interest not to intend harm to the opponent whilst they are doing none.
('26', 293, 1, 20, 715528) We must then, to be honest, clearly give up the use of the word “non violence” in connection with our struggle.
('26', 293, 1, 21, 715640) The alternative need not be immediate resort to violence.
('26', 293, 1, 22, 715698) But the people will not then be called upon to subject themselves to any discipline in non violence.
('26', 293, 1, 23, 715799) A person like me will not then feel called upon to shoulder the responsibility for Chauri Chaura.
('26', 293, 1, 24, 715897) The school of limited non violence will then still flourish in its obscurity, but without the terrible burden of responsibility it carries today.
('26', 293, 1, 25, 716043) But if non violence is to remain the policy of the nation, for its fair name and that of humanity, we are bound to carry it out to the letter and in the spirit.
('26', 293, 1, 26, 716204) And if we intend to follow out the policy, if we believe in it, We must then quickly make up with the Englishmen and the co operators.
('26', 293, 1, 27, 716339) We must get their certificate that they feel absolutely safe in our midst
('26', 293, 2, 28, 716413) 1 Charles Freer Andrews (1871 1940); English missionary, author, educa tionist and a close associate of Gandhiji

('26', 294, 1, 3, 716690) We must welcome them to our political platforms as honoured guests.

('26', 294, 1, 6, 716850) Our non violence must not breed violence, hatred and ill will.

('26', 294, 1, 8, 716981) A programme of non violence for the attainment of swaraj necessarily means ability to conduct our affairs on non violent lines.
('26', 294, 1, 9, 717109) That means inculcation of a spirit of obedience.

('26', 294, 1, 11, 717307) He means in effect that the Irish, having fought their way to their swaraj through violence, will be well able to maintain it by violence, if need be.
('26', 294, 1, 12, 717458) India on the other hand, if she wins swaraj in reality by non violence, must be able to maintain it chiefly by non violent means.

('26', 294, 1, 17, 718297) I say again that such a thing may be quite impossible of attainment.
('26', 294, 1, 18, 718366) But I know that nothing less is the implication of non violence.
('26', 294, 1, 19, 718431) And if the present workers do not believe in the probability of achieving such comparatively non violent atmosphere, they should drop the non violent programme and frame another which is wholly different in character.

('26', 295, 2, 7, 719781) 125. AFTER CHAURI CHAURA
('26', 295, 3, 8, 719806) TO THE EDITOR, Young India
('26', 295, 5, 9, 719833) I was one of the six deputed at Hata Tehsil by the District Congress Committee, Gorakhpur, to help the villages in resuming their normal aspect.
('26', 295, 5, 10, 719978) Hata Tehsil is in the vicinity of Chauri Chaura.
('26', 295, 5, 11, 720027) During my short stay there, I was flooded with the reports of the unbridled tyranny of the police from various quarters.
('26', 295, 5, 12, 720148) News came from Dhanavti (and I had no reasons to dismiss them as untrue) that the police had exacted bribes from the people on pain of implicating them in the Chauri Chaura affair.
('26', 295, 5, 13, 720329) While I was touring through the villages, I was authentically informed at Usri that three persons of Deogaon, Chattar Dhari, Ram Khagid and Amlu were made to pay Rs. 10, 2 and 1 respectively by the sowars at the point of the spear.
('26', 295, 5, 14, 720561) Reports of brutal assaults were not lacking.
('26', 295, 5, 15, 720606) I myself saw with my own naked eyes the cuts inflicted by the merciless shower of lashes (or cane) to which one Bhagelua Koeri of Ubhaon village was subjected.
('26', 295, 5, 16, 720766) One rupee was subsequently snatched away from him which belonged to the Congress Fund.
('26', 295, 5, 17, 720853) I have known the people who have been actually looted.
('26', 295, 5, 18, 720908) If the Government cares to contradict the reports, I will take it upon myself to prove the substance of the allegations I have made.
('26', 295, 6, 19, 721041) I assure you many a crime of the police would not see the light of the day.
('26', 295, 6, 20, 721117) If you come to know of the splendid patience with which the Khalabadis (the people of Basti Teshsil) are bearing the untold miseries that have fallen to their lot, you will bless them abundantly.
('26', 295, 7, 21, 721313) Sudarshan Bhawan Yours, etc.,
('26', 295, 8, 22, 721343) ALLAHABAD, JANG BAHADUR SINGH
('26', 295, 9, 23, 721373) 28 2 ’22 Whatever the guilt of the crowd at Chauri Chaura, the police outrages reported by numerous correspondents are wholly unjustified.
('26', 295, 9, 24, 721512) The remedy with the people is to love the police in spite of their atrocities and to wean them from their error.

('26', 296, 1, 2, 721696) 126. NOTES
('26', 296, 2, 3, 721707) PERPLEXED
('26', 296, 3, 4, 721717) A correspondent from Lahore writes under date 3rd March:
('26', 296, 4, 5, 721774) So far as the facts about “Bardoli decision” have come to light, it appears the decision was arrived at either under the influence of Pundit Malaviya 1 or under some far fetched notions of non violence.
('26', 296, 4, 6, 721977) In the former case the act is most unworthy, and in the latter it is most unwise.
('26', 296, 4, 7, 722059) Is not the ideal of the Congress swaraj and not non violence?
('26', 296, 4, 8, 722121) People have imbibed non violence generally, which surely must do for the Congress purpose.
('26', 296, 4, 9, 722212) How the breaches like those at Bombay and Gorakhpur can make the engine come to a standstill, I cannot understand.
('26', 296, 4, 10, 722327) And if M. Paul Richard is true as to your aspirations of World Leader through non violence even at the cost of Indian interest, it is surely unbecoming and, excuse me to say, dishonest.
('26', 296, 5, 11, 722513) And have you realized the effects of this sudden standstill?
('26', 296, 5, 12, 722574) Mr. Montagu’s 2 threat comes for that.
('26', 296, 5, 13, 722613) Lord Reading 3 and his Government are harder to us than ever before.
('26', 296, 5, 14, 722682) It had almost yielded.
('26', 296, 5, 15, 722705) As to the public, there is a general distrust prevailing among the classes and the masses.
('26', 296, 5, 16, 722796) Surely it is difficult to make men play things of the hour and their disgust and disappointment show how the fight was carried on in right earnest.
('26', 296, 5, 17, 722944) Don’t you perceive that it is a shock and that two such shocks must enervate the combatants altogether?
('26', 296, 6, 18, 723048) Besides, I have heard the responsible Mussalmans talk of withdrawing co operation even from the Hindus.
('26', 296, 6, 19, 723152) The fight is religious with them.
('26', 296, 6, 20, 723186) It is the Jihad, I should say.
('26', 296, 6, 21, 723217) God’s Command and the Prophet’s is no joke to start and to stop the Jehad at will.
('26', 296, 6, 22, 723300) If the Hindus should retire, they say they must devise their own course.
('26', 296, 6, 23, 723373) Will you take care to ease one heart that feels uneasy on this account?
('26', 296, 6, 24, 723445) It is impossible to withhold sympathy from the writer.
('26', 296, 6, 25, 723500) His letter is typical of the attitude I saw reflected in Delhi.
('26', 296, 6, 26, 723564) I have already given the assurance that Pundit Malaviyaji had nothing to do with Bardoli decision.
('26', 296, 6, 27, 723663) Nor have any“far fetched notions of non violence” anything to do with it.

('26', 298, 1, 3, 727247) OTHER IMPLICATIONS I invite the reader to study the leading article of the week on non violence.
('26', 298, 1, 4, 727344) 1 The article became fairly long even with a discussion of the main principles.
('26', 298, 1, 5, 727424) I did not therefore discuss the important side issues in it but reserved them for the Notes.
('26', 298, 1, 6, 727517) Such for instance are the questions: (1) When can even individual civil disobedience be resumed?
('26', 298, 1, 7, 727614) (2) What kind of violence will stop civil disobedience?
('26', 298, 1, 8, 727670) (3) Is there room for self defense in the limited conception of non violence?
('26', 298, 1, 9, 727748) (4) Supposing the Mussalmans or the Hindus secede, can a non violent campaign be carried on by one community alone?
('26', 298, 1, 10, 727864) (5) Supposing Hindus and Mussalmans both reject me, what would become of my preaching?
('26', 298, 1, 11, 727951) I shall take the question seriatim.
('26', 298, 1, 12, 727987) Civil disobedience, even individual civil disobedience, requires a tranquil atmosphere.
('26', 298, 1, 13, 728075) It must not be commenced till the workers have assimilated the spirit of non violence and have procured a certificate of merit from the co operators whether English or Indian, i.e., till they have really ceased to think ill of them.
('26', 298, 1, 14, 728308) The surest test will be when our meetings are purged of intolerance and our writings of bitterness.
('26', 298, 1, 15, 728408) Another necessary test will be our serious handling of the constructive programme.
('26', 298, 1, 16, 728491) If we cannot settle down to it, to me it will be proof positive of our disbelief in the capacity of non violence to achieve the purpose.
('26', 298, 2, 17, 728628) NON VIOLENT ATMOSPHERE It is not every kind of violence that will stop civil disobedience.
('26', 298, 2, 18, 728719) I should not be dismayed by family feuds even though they may be sanguinary.
('26', 298, 2, 19, 728796) Nor will the violence of robbers baffle me though they would be to me an indication of the absence of general purification.
('26', 298, 2, 20, 728920) It is political violence which must stop civil disobedience.
('26', 298, 2, 21, 728981) Chauri Chaura was an instance of political violence.
('26', 298, 2, 22, 729034) It arose from a political demons tration which we should have avoided if we were not capable of conducting it absolutely peacefully.
('26', 298, 2, 23, 729167) I did not allow Malabar and Malegaon 2 to interrupt our course, because the Moplahs were a special people and they had not come under the influence of non violence to any appreciable extent.
('26', 298, 2, 24, 729358) Malegaon is more difficult, but there is clear

('26', 299, 1, 3, 729603) Nor was mass civil disobedience imminent at the time.
('26', 299, 1, 4, 729657) It could not interrupt individual civil disobedience elsewhere.
('26', 299, 2, 5, 729721) SELF DEFENSE The non co operator’s pledge does not exclude the right of private self defence.
('26', 299, 2, 6, 729815) Non co operators are under prohibition as to political violence.
('26', 299, 2, 7, 729880) Those, therefore, with whom non co operation is not their final creed, are certainly free to defend themselves or their dependents and wards against their assailants.
('26', 299, 2, 8, 730047) But they may not defend themselves against the police acting in discharge of their duties, whether assumed or authorized.
('26', 299, 2, 9, 730169) Thus, there was no right of self defence under the pledge against Collectors who have, I hold, illegally belaboured volunteers.
('26', 299, 2, 10, 730297) IF MUSSALMANS OR HINDUS SECEDE If one of the big communities secede from the compact of non violence, I admit that it is most difficult, though certainly not impossible, for one party only to carry on the struggle.
('26', 299, 2, 11, 730512) That party will need to have an invulnerable faith in the policy of non violence.
('26', 299, 2, 12, 730594) But if one community does realize that India cannot gain swaraj for generations through violent means, it can by its consistently non violent, i.e., loving conduct, bring round all the opposing parties to its side.
('26', 299, 2, 13, 730809) IF BOTH REJECT ME If both the parties reject me, I should keep my peace just as ever and most decidedly carry on my propaganda of non violence.
('26', 299, 2, 14, 730953) I should then not be restricted as I am now.
('26', 299, 2, 15, 730998) Then I should be enforcing my creed, as today I seem to be enforcing only the policy.

('26', 304, 1, 4, 743256) MISLEADING Readers have besieged me with leaflets which the Propaganda Committee of W.I.N. Liberal Association has been distributing broadcast.

('26', 304, 4, 18, 744102) Everybody will be free to do what he likes.
('26', 304, 4, 19, 744146) It will be a very easy life, because everybody will have to go about in a khaddar langoti 1 and sleep in the open.
('26', 304, 4, 20, 744261) I cannot say that this is an exaggeration.

('26', 304, 4, 22, 744362) It is only suggestively false.
('26', 304, 4, 23, 744393) Let me say what I mean.
('26', 304, 4, 24, 744417) In the first instance, India is not striving to establish “Gandhi Raj”.
('26', 304, 4, 25, 744489) It is in dead earnest to establish swaraj and would gladly and legitimately sacrifice Gandhi for the sake of winning swaraj.
('26', 304, 4, 26, 744614) “Gandhi Raj” is an ideal condition, and in that condition all the five negatives will represent a true picture, but under swaraj nobody ever dreams, certainly I do not dream, of no railways, no hospitals, no machinery, no army and navy, no laws and no law courts.
('26', 304, 4, 27, 744878) On the contrary, there will be railways: only they will not be intended for military or the economic exploitation of India, but they will be used for promoting internal trade and will make the lives of third class passengers fairly comfortable.

('26', 305, 1, 3, 745483) Machinery there certainly will be in the shape of spinning wheel, which is after all a delicate piece of machinery, but I have no doubt that several factories will grow up in India under swaraj intended for the benefit of the people, not as now for draining the masses dry.

('26', 305, 1, 6, 746320) Lastly, whilst it will be optional for everybody who chooses to go about in langoti and sleep in the open, let me hope that it will not be necessary, as it is today, for millions to go about with a dirty rag which serves for a langoti for want of the means to buy sufficient clothing and to rest their weary and starved bodies in the open for want of a roof.
('26', 305, 1, 7, 746679) It is not right therefore to tear some ideas expressed in Indian Home Rule 1 from their proper setting, caricature them and put them before the people as if I was preaching these ideas for anybody’s acceptance.
('26', 305, 1, 8, 746890) In another pamphlet isolated acts of hooliganism, no doubt done by non co operators or their sympathizers, have been repeated as if they were the ordinary vocation of non co operators, and then follows the amazing summing up:
('26', 305, 2, 9, 747116) Non co operation is destruction, a falling back to the bad old days of bloody civil strife and confusion.
('26', 305, 2, 10, 747222) Non co operation is certainly partly destruction in so far as it is necessary, but not of the type of Bombay as suggested in the leaflet, but destruction of a vicious system by peaceful means, and I should very much like to know the bad old days of bloody civil strife and confusion.
('26', 305, 2, 11, 747506) Is there any warrant in history for such a belief?
('26', 305, 2, 12, 747557) I have known people sing of good old days.
('26', 305, 2, 13, 747600) I have seen some verses in the vernacular text books singing the praises of British rule at the expense of pre British rule, but I do not know that there ever was a time when there was “bloody civil strife and confusion” throughout the length and breadth of India.

('26', 310, 1, 6, 760053) A BLESSING Borodada (Dwijendranath Tagore) 1 sends me a beautiful little letter covering the following lines:
('26', 310, 2, 7, 760163) My views concerning the speeding and slackening motion of the Great Vessel which is just now bearing in its bosom the earnest prayers of the sons and daughters of India for the advent of a new era of peace and good will to mankind in this travailing earth of ours.
('26', 310, 3, 8, 760428) A wise captain slackens the speed of his vessel whilst moving in the right direction, whenever it arrives at a spot abounding in dangerous rocks, and speeds his vessel as soon as he enters into the open sea which is free from all sorts of such impediments.
('26', 310, 3, 9, 760685) But a foolish captain steers his vessel in a wrong direction for fear of rocks, where there is no such thing whatever under the sea, and proceeds towards an unknown region where hidden rocks are lying in wait to shatter his vessel into fragments the moment it approaches their dwelling place.
('26', 310, 4, 10, 760978) Mahatma Gandhi is guiding his vessel in the former way, while his advisers want him to take the latter course.
('26', 310, 4, 11, 761089) I hope that at the end of the chapter it will be possible to say that I was “a wise captain”.
('26', 310, 4, 12, 761183) I can truthfully say that I have never in my life been so storm tossed as I am at the present moment.
('26', 310, 4, 13, 761285) I have hitherto flattered myself with the belief that I have a fair measure of my capacity as also my limitations, but just now I seem to be in deeper waters than I should care to find myself in.
('26', 310, 4, 14, 761481) The prayers, therefore, and blessings of one so pure and so good as Borodada are most welcome to me at this juncture.

('26', 314, 2, 15, 771755) THE VALUE OF WORD OF HONOUR
('26', 314, 3, 16, 771783) Mr. Subramanya Siva has sent the following explanation in response to my invitation 1 published in Young India about his reported apology:
('26', 314, 4, 17, 771922) The Government communique relating to my release is likely to make many of my countrymen misunderstand me and my present position.
('26', 314, 4, 18, 772053) Mahatmaji himself writing in Young India wants me to clear myself by making a full statement.
('26', 314, 4, 19, 772147) I have already explained myself in The Hindu of the 20th January last.
('26', 314, 4, 20, 772218) The following is my explanation:
('26', 314, 5, 21, 772251) The communique is so worded as to mean that the Government released me because of my undertaking.
('26', 314, 5, 22, 772349) But the order to the Superintendent of the Central Jail at Trichinopoly ran thus:
('26', 314, 6, 23, 772431) “Under Section (some Section) of the Criminal Procedure Code, the Governor in Council is pleased to remit the unexpired portion of the sentence of convict Subramanya Siva unconditionally.”
('26', 314, 7, 24, 772620) 1Vide “Notes”, 9 2 1922, under the sub title “A Well Deserved Snub”.
('26', 315, 0, 1, 772689) 316 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('26', 315, 1, 2, 772731) It is plain from the word “unconditionally” in the order that nothing about the undertaking or any condition is mentioned and that the recom mendations of the Surgeon General and the District Medical officer ought to have been the chief cause of my release.
('26', 315, 1, 3, 772989) No condition has been imposed upon me; and I am as free as before to work in any way I like, I wish to inform my countrymen.
('26', 315, 1, 4, 773114) A word as to my undertaking.
('26', 315, 1, 5, 773143) Soon after my conviction I fell so seriously ill in the jail that I, in addition to suffering from high fever, was passing endless diarrhoea motions every day, so much so that at times I fell into delirium and my life was despaired of.
('26', 315, 1, 6, 773379) It was at that time I wrote an undertaking to the Government that if I were to be released, I shall refrain from politics in future.
('26', 315, 1, 7, 773512) This may be considered a weak act on my part by certain people.
('26', 315, 1, 8, 773576) But if the circumstances and the time in which I wrote were taken into consideration, I believe I am surely entitled to be excused.
('26', 315, 1, 9, 773708) “Even Homer nods”, man is liable to err; and I am no God.
('26', 315, 1, 10, 773766) I have every right to expect my countrymen who have been watching my life ever since 1905 to slight this small past weakness of mine.
('26', 315, 1, 11, 773900) Though one would wish that people even suffering tortures would not tender apologies, it is not open to outsiders to criticize the conduct of those who weaken under physical suffering.
('26', 315, 1, 12, 774085) Mr. Siva therefore rightly appeals to the public not to judge him harshly for having tendered the apology.
('26', 315, 1, 13, 774192) But the point is that the apology having once been tendered and a promise given, it should have been faithfully carried out.
('26', 315, 1, 14, 774317) Mr. Subramanya Siva is not entitled to take advantage of the word “unconditionally” occurring in the order of remission.
('26', 315, 1, 15, 774438) It is a mark of confidence in the probity of a non co operator.
('26', 315, 1, 16, 774502) Surely the Government were quite justified in believing that Mr. Siva would abide by his written word.
('26', 315, 1, 17, 774605) I wish non co operators to earn the credit for being above reproach so far as truth and non violence are concerned.
('26', 315, 1, 18, 774721) This struggle depends for its success solely upon the acquisition of a moral prestige which can only be built up by scrupulous regard for honesty under all circumstances.
('26', 315, 1, 19, 774892) Instead of taking the advantage that Mr. Siva wishes to take of the unconditional pardon, he should really recognize in this act at least the generosity of the Government in not having humiliated him by referring to the apology.
('26', 315, 1, 20, 775121) I cannot close this painful subject without appealing to Mr. Subramanya Siva even now to make a public declaration that he will strictly refrain from taking part in politics and apologizing that he ever departed from the undertaking he gave.
('26', 315, 1, 21, 775363) I am sure that neither he nor the public will lose by his strict adherence to his promise.
('26', 315, 1, 22, 775454) There is a vast scope for him to do social and economic work.
('26', 315, 1, 23, 775516) He can do a great deal of khaddar work in its purely economic and moral aspects.

('26', 316, 2, 3, 775756) Before I select a cosy corner in the Swaraj Mandir, I leave these few lines with a friend of mine to send them on to you.
('26', 316, 2, 4, 775878) The case as usual is a huge farce.
('26', 316, 2, 5, 775913) I have been run in under Section 108. The witnesses are all interested parties.
('26', 316, 2, 6, 775993) The utter demoralization of the present Government is made clear to me by this case.
('26', 316, 2, 7, 776078) The Press telegrams pertaining to it have been held up.
('26', 316, 2, 8, 776134) You will be glad to know what my wife writes about the case:
('26', 316, 3, 9, 776195) “Congratulations on your arrest.
('26', 316, 3, 10, 776228) Thank God, the much longed for day is come, and God has accepted your sacrifice.
('26', 316, 3, 11, 776309) We are all very happy.
('26', 316, 3, 12, 776332) May you cheerfully suffer for your country and your religion, and may the Almighty arm us with sufficient strength to bear hardships for our cause”.
('26', 316, 4, 13, 776481) Now I gladly await the orders of the National Parliament for my release.
('26', 316, 4, 14, 776554) The foregoing was written on the 26th January.
('26', 316, 4, 15, 776601) It makes somewhat sad reading on the 4th of March when the National Parliament seems to be not quite so near as it certainly appeared to be on the 26th of January.
('26', 316, 4, 16, 776765) To a soldier, however, it matters not when the battle is won.
('26', 316, 4, 17, 776827) To him it only matters that he should stand to his post.
('26', 316, 4, 18, 776884) In my opinion, the only dignified release must be by the first Act of the Swaraj Parliament or by efflux of time and I certainly do not lose hope of the prisoners being released by national strength if the revised Bardoli programme of construction can be successfully carried out.
('26', 316, 4, 19, 777165) CALCUTTA’S UNREADINESS A correspondent in the course of letter from Calcutta writes:
('26', 316, 5, 20, 777250) My mind compels me to say that Bengal is doing nothing about swadeshi in comparison to the neighbouring province of Bihar.
('26', 316, 5, 21, 777373) It is lagging far behind.
('26', 316, 5, 22, 777399) Even those who boast themselves of being volunteers are not clad in khaddar.
('26', 316, 5, 23, 777476) I have travelled through almost all the important quarters of this great town, but have not found a single person clad in khaddar.
('26', 316, 5, 24, 777607) In Bihar, on the other hand, you will rarely find a man wearing foreign cloth.
('26', 316, 5, 25, 777686) In the villages they have not yet begun to wear khaddar dhoties, but the attempt is being made to replace mill made dhoties with khaddar ones.
('26', 316, 5, 26, 777829) I have merely given a few extracts from the correspondent’s letter.
('26', 316, 5, 27, 777897) He goes on to say that, if Calcutta’s unpreparedness is re flected in the villages of Bengal also, the battle of satyagraha cannot be won.
('26', 316, 5, 28, 778036) This letter is supported by several others, but I am not prepared to admit that, even in Calcutta, no progress has been done in khaddar movement.
('26', 316, 5, 29, 778182) At the same time, I fear that the charge against Calcutta is mainly true.
('26', 316, 5, 30, 778256) Khaddar wear in Calcutta is rather an exception than the rule, and there is no denying the fact that full
('26', 317, 0, 1, 778362) 318 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('26', 317, 1, 2, 778404) satyagraha is impossible without full compliance with the conditions precedent.
('26', 317, 1, 3, 778484) If we are to usher in peaceful swaraj—and swaraj attained by peaceful means must be peaceful swaraj—we must be as ready for construction as we seem to be for destruction.
('26', 317, 1, 4, 778655) Boycott and manu facture, evacuation and occupation, disobedience and obedience must go hand in hand, if we are to avoid an interval of confusion, anarchy and civil strife.
('26', 317, 1, 5, 778828) The khaddar movement is the largest part of construction.
('26', 317, 1, 6, 778886) We dare not neglect it if the struggle is to remain non violent to the end.
('26', 317, 1, 7, 778962) INTERESTING INFORMATION Though now stale, the report issued by Messrs Prakasam, Nageshwara Row and Narayan Rao about the preparedness for mass civil disobedience of the areas selected by the Guntur District Congress Committee makes interesting reading.
('26', 317, 1, 8, 779215) The Commissioners divide the area into two parts: Peddanandipadu Firka and all the neighbouring villages forming one contiguous whole, and the second the rest of the Firkas consisting of Palnad, Vinukonda, Settanapalle and portions of Ongole, Narasaraopet, Tennali and Repalle.
('26', 317, 1, 9, 779493) The Commissioners found that the second part of the selected area fully satisfied the conditions about khaddar but not so about untouch ability, although there was a great advance in the mentality of people.
('26', 317, 1, 10, 779701) As to non violence, whilst the Commissioners admit that the people are non violent by temperament, they say: “Still we doubt whether they could withstand a provocation or insult if it is of an extreme nature.” They found that the condition about Hindu Muslim unity was largely fulfilled.
('26', 317, 1, 11, 779989) Of the first part of the area, the Commissioners are much more enthusiastic.
('26', 317, 1, 12, 780066) They estimate the total number of volunteers at about 4,000.
('26', 317, 2, 13, 780127) They are clad in khaddar uniform with badges.
('26', 317, 2, 14, 780173) Men of all ages have enlisted themselves.
('26', 317, 2, 15, 780215) We found even men of 60 to 65 years doing active work.
('26', 317, 2, 16, 780270) In some villages there were Panchama volunteers doing active work and freely mixing with others.
('26', 317, 2, 17, 780367) The excellence of the organization among these ryots consists in their devotion to duty and observance of non violence as part of their religion.
('26', 317, 2, 18, 780513) As to khaddar, the Commissioners remark:
('26', 317, 3, 19, 780554) Most of the villages are self contained.
('26', 317, 3, 20, 780595) In some almost every house has one or more charkhas actually working.
('26', 317, 3, 21, 780665) The yarn made in each village is woven generally by the village Panchamas.
('26', 317, 3, 22, 780740) Even orthodox Brahmins have been getting their clothes made by their Panchama brethren.
('26', 317, 3, 23, 780828) In most of the villages more than 50 per cent wear khaddar made by themselves.
('26', 317, 3, 24, 780907) In some the percentage is as high as 95.
('26', 318, 0, 1, 780948) VOL. 26 : 24 JANUARY, 1922 12 NOVEMBER, 1923 319
('26', 318, 1, 2, 780997) Remarking upon untouchability, they say:
('26', 318, 2, 3, 781038) We were surprised at the extraordinary progress made by some of the villages in this area in their attempt to remove untouchability within so short a time.
('26', 318, 2, 4, 781194) We could not believe that it was humanly possible to effect such a revolution in the minds of these countrymen of ours.
('26', 318, 2, 5, 781314) We found the so called untouchables admitted into the Panchayat Board.
('26', 318, 2, 6, 781385) In some places orthodox Brahmins took the Panchamas by hand and seated them in their midst, and in some places they are admitted into the premises of Brahmins to do the same services which other castes have been doing.
('26', 318, 2, 7, 781604) One rich Brahmin gentleman told us that he and some of his friends in the neighbouring villages would spend all their income to make provision for their needy Panchama brethren.
('26', 318, 3, 8, 781782) Their final opinion, however, is:
('26', 318, 4, 9, 781816) In some villages untouchability has ceased to exist and in several it is likely to disappear soon.
('26', 318, 4, 10, 781915) We consider the progress not uniform and not sufficient.
('26', 318, 4, 11, 781972) Their final summing up is: No doubt all this is a good record, but it is difficult to see how far the masses can remain absolutely peaceful if more drastic and inhuman measures are employed.
('26', 318, 4, 12, 782163) The time at their disposal for discipline has been too short.
('26', 318, 4, 13, 782225) They have been just at the beginning of the fight.
('26', 318, 4, 14, 782276) We consider it more advisable to postpone the campaign until the people have sufficient time to steel their hearts against all engines of oppression.
('26', 318, 4, 15, 782426) I have given relevant extracts from this valuable report to show: (1) the utter impartiality with which the Commissioners approach their mission, (2) the marvellous progress made in the selected area in fulfilling the conditions laid down by the Congress, (3) the necessity for much greater work before the idea of civil disobedience could be approached with any confidence.
('26', 318, 4, 16, 782801) I am aware that extraordinary efforts were being put forth in many parts of India for due fulfilment of the Congress conditions in order that the people might be able to exercise the privilege of civil disobedience.
('26', 318, 4, 17, 783017) That in itself is certainly a matter for congratulation, but work of construction ought not to have to depend upon stimulation.
('26', 318, 4, 18, 783145) It must go on irrespective of the excitement of civil disobedience.
('26', 318, 4, 19, 783213) Removal of untouchability, manu facture of khaddar, Hindu Muslim unity, cultivation of non violence are not measures of a temporary character.
('26', 318, 4, 20, 783356) They are the four pillars on which the structure of swaraj must for ever rest.
('26', 318, 4, 21, 783435) Take away any one of them and it must topple down.
('26', 318, 4, 22, 783486) The greater, therefore, the progress in these four matters, the nearer we are to swaraj, and the nearer also to capacity for civil disobedience.
('26', 318, 4, 23, 783631) Indeed, even disobedience, if it is truly civil, excludes the idea of excitement.
('26', 318, 4, 24, 783713) When Daniel threw open his doors in defiance of the laws of Medes and Persians, when John Bunyan became a non conformist, when Latimer thrust his hand into
('26', 319, 0, 1, 783869) 320 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('26', 319, 1, 2, 783911) the fire, when Prahlad embraced the red hot iron pillar, not one of these civil resisters of old resisted under excitement.
('26', 319, 1, 3, 784035) On the contrary they were, if possible, more collected and deliberate than on ordinary occasions.
('26', 319, 1, 4, 784133) Absence of excitement is an infallible test of civil disobedience.
('26', 319, 1, 5, 784200) I therefore hope that the good people of the selected area will not go to sleep now that mass civil disobedience has been suspended, but that they will go on with the programme of construction with greater zeal and devotion.

('26', 319, 5, 13, 784909) TO THE EDITOR, Young India
('26', 319, 7, 14, 784936) If I can be allowed to say a word or two in connection with your article “Our Laxity” 1 in the last issue, I beg to state as follows: I believe, at least from my personal experience in the C. P., that the vast majority of the volunteers do not conform to the Congress conditions because the recruiting officers themselves are careless in observing the principles laid down by the Ahmedabad Congress.
('26', 319, 7, 15, 785336) It is highly regrettable, while revered persons like Deshbandhu Das Lalaji, Panditji Nehru and others (now in gaols) are shouting out at the top of their voice that it is sinful for Indians to wear anything but khaddar, the Congress workers at several places are yet ashamed of wearing short khaddar dhotis instead of their mill or videshi dhotis.
('26', 319, 7, 16, 785684) Even many of the leaders who appear on platforms to deliver speeches, I am pained to say, are seen in their old videshi or mill clothes.
('26', 319, 8, 17, 785821) So under the circumstances, I think the public is entitled to have your advice over this vital question of dealing with the elected representatives and office bearers who do not abide (as stated above) by the Congress mandate.

('26', 320, 2, 4, 786352) 128. THE DEATH DANCE
('26', 320, 3, 5, 786373) Why is there this chorus of condemnation of the doubling of the salt tax and other taxes on the necessaries of life?
('26', 320, 3, 6, 786490) Wonder is expressed that now there is no apology even offered for the terrific military charges of sixty two crores.
('26', 320, 3, 7, 786607) The fact is, it is impossible to offer apology for the inevitable.
('26', 320, 3, 8, 786674) The military charges must grow with the growing consciousness of the nation.
('26', 320, 3, 9, 786751) The military is not required for the defence of India.
('26', 320, 3, 10, 786806) But it is required for the forcible imposition of the English exploiters upon India.
('26', 320, 3, 11, 786891) That is naked truth.
('26', 320, 3, 12, 786912) Mr Mon tagu has bluntly but honestly stated it.
('26', 320, 3, 13, 786960) The retiring President of the Bengal Chamber of Commerce has said it and so has the Governor of Bombay.
('26', 320, 3, 14, 787064) They want to trade with us not upon our terms, but upon their terms.
('26', 320, 3, 15, 787133) It is the same thing whether it is done with the kid glove on or without it.
('26', 320, 3, 16, 787210) The Councils are the kid glove.
('26', 320, 3, 17, 787242) We must pay for the glove.
('26', 320, 3, 18, 787269) The reforms hang upon us like an incubus.
('26', 320, 3, 19, 787311) They cover a multitude of defects including the blood sucking salt tax.
('26', 320, 3, 20, 787383) They say to us: “We propose to hold India whether you wish it or not.” We believe that all this is for our good.
('26', 320, 3, 21, 787496) We think we cannot keep from fighting one another without the protecting power of the British arms.
('26', 320, 3, 22, 787596) And so, being afraid to die at the hands of our brothers, we are content to live as bondmen.
('26', 320, 3, 23, 787689) It would be a thousand times better for us to be ruled by a military dictator than to have the dictatorship concealed under sham councils and assemblies.
('26', 320, 3, 24, 787843) They prolong the agony and increase the expenditure.
('26', 320, 3, 25, 787896) If we are so anxious to live, it would be more honourable to face the truth and submit to unabashed dictation than to pretend that we are slowly becoming free.
('26', 320, 3, 26, 788056) There is no such thing as slow freedom.
('26', 320, 3, 27, 788096) Freedom is like a birth.
('26', 320, 3, 28, 788121) Till we are fully free, we are slaves.
('26', 320, 3, 29, 788160) All birth takes place in moment.
('26', 320, 3, 30, 788193) What is this dread of the Congress but the dread of the coming freedom?
('26', 320, 3, 31, 788265) The Congress has become a grim reality.
('26', 320, 3, 32, 788305) And therefore it has to be destroyed, law or no law.
('26', 320, 3, 33, 788358) If only sufficient terror can be struck into the hearts of the people, the exploitation can last another century.
('26', 320, 3, 34, 788472) It is another question whether India itself can last that time under the growing strain or whether the people must during that time

('26', 321, 1, 2, 788646) die like flies.
('26', 321, 1, 3, 788662) When a man begins to eat a coconut, he is not called upon to be tender to the kernel.
('26', 321, 1, 4, 788748) When he has carved out the last bit, he throws away the shell.

('26', 321, 1, 11, 789379) The whole revolves beautifully round the central corporation.

('26', 321, 1, 22, 790516) This we can only do by showing them that non violence is the way to freedom—not the forced non violence of the slave, but the willing non violence of the brave and the free.

('26', 321, 2, 24, 790712) 129. IF I AM ARRESTED The rumour has been revived that my arrest is imminent.

('26', 322, 1, 2, 791221) possible for the Government to withstand the ever rising agitation in London for my arrest and deportation.
('26', 322, 1, 3, 791329) I myself cannot see how the Government can avoid arresting me if they want a permanent abandonment of civil disobedience, whether individual or mass.
('26', 322, 1, 4, 791479) I advised the Working Committee to suspend mass civil disobedience at Bardoli becasue that disobedience would not have been civil, and if I am now advising all provincial workers to suspend even individual civil disobedience, it is because I know that any disobedience at the present stage will be not civil but criminal.
('26', 322, 1, 5, 791801) A tranquil atmosphere is an indispensable condition of civil dis obedience.

('26', 322, 1, 9, 792427) I consider him to be one of the most capable among public workers.

('26', 325, 4, 14, 800754) 131. FOREIGN PROPAGANDA
('26', 325, 5, 15, 800778) I see that there is great deal of misunderstanding about the scope of foreign propaganda undertaken by the Working Committee.
('26', 325, 5, 16, 800904) I see that it was a mistake not to have published the report that was adopted by the Working Committee.
('26', 325, 5, 17, 801008) Here it is:
('26', 325, 6, 18, 801020) TO THE CHAIRMAN OF THE WORKING COMMITTEE OF
('26', 325, 7, 19, 801064) THE ALL INDIA CONGRESS COMMITEE, DELHI
('26', 325, 9, 20, 801103) At the meeting of the Working Committee held at Surat on 31st January last, the following Resolution was passed:
('26', 325, 10, 21, 801216) “The Working Committee records its firm conviction that dissem ination of correct news about Indian political situation in foreign countries is absolutely essential and refers to Mahatma Gandhi all the correspondence on the subject of foreign propaganda now with the Working Secretary with a request that he should prepare a definite scheme in that behalf at an early date so as to enable the next meeting of the Working Committee to consider it.”
('26', 325, 11, 22, 801664) Having considered the resolution and papers forwarded to me by the Secretary, I beg to report as Follows:
('26', 326, 0, 1, 801770) VOL. 26 : 24 JANUARY, 1922 12 NOVEMBER, 1923 327
('26', 326, 1, 2, 801819) In my opinion it is not only undesirable but it may prove even harmful
('26', 326, 2, 3, 801890) to establish at the present stage any Agency in any foreign country for the
('26', 326, 3, 4, 801966) dissemination of correct news in such country about the political situation in
('26', 326, 4, 5, 802045) India, for the following reasons:
('26', 326, 5, 6, 802079) First, because it would distract public attention and instead of making the people feel that they have to rely purely on their own strength, it will make them think of the effect of their actions on foreign countries and the support the latter can render to the national cause.
('26', 326, 5, 7, 802357) This does not mean that we do not care for the world’s support, but the way to gain that support is to insist upon the correctness of every one of our actions and rely upon the automatic capacity of Truth to spread itself.
('26', 326, 6, 8, 802580) Secondly, it is my experience that when an Agency is established for any special purpose, independent interest ceases to a certain extent and what is distributed by the Agency is previousely discounted as coming from interested quarters.
('26', 326, 7, 9, 802818) Thirdly, the Congress will not be able to exercise effective check over such Agencies, and there is great danger of authoritative distribution of wrong information and wrong ideas about the struggle.
('26', 326, 8, 10, 803018) Fourthly, it is not possible at the present moment to send out of India any person of importance for the sole purpose of disseminating news in foreign countries, for such men are too few for the internal work.
('26', 326, 9, 11, 803228) I am therefore of opinion that the work of publishing the Congress Bulletin should be better organized, if necessary, by engaging a special editor for the purpose and by sending the Congress Bulletin regularly to the chief news agencies of the world.
('26', 326, 9, 12, 803479) The editor should be instructed to enter into correspondence with these newspapers or news agencies which may be found to interest themselves in Indian questions.
('26', 326, 10, 13, 803642) It is my firm opinion based upon experience gained through the conduct of the journals I have edited in South Africa and here that the more solid the Congress work and the sufferings of the Congress men and women, the greater the publicity the cause will attain without special effort.
('26', 326, 10, 14, 803928) From the exchanges of letters and correspondence that I receive day by day from all parts of the world in connection with the conduct of Young India, I observe that never was so much interest taken in Indian affairs throughout the world as it is today.
('26', 326, 10, 15, 804181) It follows that the interest will increase in the same proportion as the volume of our sufferings.
('26', 326, 10, 16, 804280) The very best method of disseminating correct information about the political situation, therefore, is to make the Congress work purer, better organized and to evoke a greater spirit of suffering.
('26', 326, 10, 17, 804477) Not only is curiosity thereby intensified, but people become more eager to
('26', 327, 0, 1, 804552) 328 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('26', 327, 1, 2, 804594) understand the inwardness and the exact truth about the situation.
('26', 327, 2, 3, 804661) I remain,
('26', 327, 3, 4, 804671) BARDOLI, yours faithfully,
('26', 327, 4, 5, 804698) 22nd Feb.
('26', 327, 4, 6, 804708) 1922 M. K.GANDHI After having gone through all the papers that were given to me and after having heard all the arguments for and against, I remain convinced that, at least for the present, we want no news agency outside India.
('26', 327, 4, 7, 804935) We want the whole world with us, but we shall not get it by carrying on foreign agency.
('26', 327, 4, 8, 805023) We can only send correct information to those who care for it.
('26', 327, 4, 9, 805086) If a foreign country does not keep its own agency for gathering information from a particular country or about a particular movement, it is proof to me that that country is not interested in it.
('26', 327, 4, 10, 805281) We have been without our agency in London now for nearly 15 months.
('26', 327, 4, 11, 805349) I venture to think that we are no worse off today than we were 15 months ago.
('26', 327, 4, 12, 805427) We are certainly better off because and to the extent that we have done substantial work in India itself.
('26', 327, 4, 13, 805533) There are more people in the world interested today in India than there ever were.
('26', 327, 4, 14, 805616) We, therefore, owe it to them that we place at their disposal correct information, but our duty must end there.
('26', 327, 4, 15, 805728) I have before me a letter from Italy from an Italian editor telling me how deeply inter ested people in Italy are in the Indian movement, and the Italian news papers are therefore busy instructing the Italian public in Indian affairs.
('26', 327, 4, 16, 805963) This is what I call a natural and organic movement, but if, on the strength of this information, we were to establish an Indian agency in Italy to awaken further interest, we would not mend matters but would spoil them by overdoing.
('26', 327, 4, 17, 806196) We shall therefore better consult our own interest by relying upon our own strength to speak for itself.
('26', 327, 4, 18, 806301) Moreover, the non co operation movement is one of self help.
('26', 327, 4, 19, 806362) Its formula is:“We shall succeed only to the extent of our strength and no further.” No certificate of merit from the world will give us success, if we have not earned it by the sweat of the brow.
('26', 327, 4, 20, 806559) No condemnation of the movement will kill it, unless we are ourselves so fickle hearted as to give it up by reason of the condemnation.
('26', 327, 4, 21, 806695) Let us not therefore turn our attention from our own work.
('26', 327, 4, 22, 806754) Let us simply mind our work and let us be sure that the world will mind us without any further effort.
('26', 327, 4, 23, 806857) I am really jealous of even talking away from their work some of the young men who necessarily have to be engaged in the preparation and distribution of the Congress Bulletin.
('26', 327, 4, 24, 807033) But we have really no authentic record of the progress of our work from week to
('26', 328, 0, 1, 807113) VOL. 26 : 24 JANUARY, 1922 12 NOVEMBER, 1923 329
('26', 328, 1, 2, 807162) The Congress Bulletin will therefore be useful as well for workers in India as it undoubtedly will be for our friends in foreign countries.
('26', 328, 1, 3, 807302) Being almost impatient to see the work inaugurated, the Working Committee has given me a free hand in organizing the Bulletin.
('26', 328, 1, 4, 807429) I hope to issue the first Bulletin next week and thenceforth it would be issued from week to week.
('26', 328, 1, 5, 807528) The Bulletin will be sent to all the readers of Young India at a nominal charge to cover a part or the whole of the cost of paper and printing.
('26', 328, 1, 6, 807672) Young India has a registered circulation of over 25,000 and it goes to almost all parts of the world.
('26', 328, 1, 7, 807774) It has a comprehensive exchange list.
('26', 328, 1, 8, 807812) The price for the subscribers to the Bulletin only will be announced later.
('26', 328, 1, 9, 807888) The method I have sketched is intended to save the Congress as much expense as possible and to give the widest publicity to the Bulletin.
('26', 328, 1, 10, 808026) Whereas Young India represents my own views and those of my associates in the conduct of the journal, the Bulletin will contain nothing in the shape of individual views.
('26', 328, 1, 11, 808196) It will be mainly a record of Congress activities all over India in all its multifarious departments, and an epitome of newspaper opinions both pro Congress and anti Congress.
('26', 328, 1, 12, 808372) It will contain a Khilafat section registering all Khilafat activities during the preceding week.
('26', 328, 1, 13, 808470) Such a Bulletin cannot become a success unless there is co operation from all Congress and Khilafat workers.
('26', 328, 1, 14, 808579) I invite therefore all who are interested in the Bulletin to send their suggestions and news addressed to the Editor, Congress Bulletin, C/o Young India.
('26', 328, 1, 15, 808733) Correspondents will please take care to mark all such correspondence for the Congress Bulletin in order to save the Young India staff from having to handle correspondence intended for the Bulletin.
('26', 328, 1, 16, 808931) To start with, I would ask every Provincial Congress Committee to send the number of members on its provincial register, the number of village and district organizations, the names and addresses of nationalist newspapers, the number of national educational institutions with the average attendance during the past 6 months, the number of Pancha yats and all other information regarding non co operation activities.

('26', 329, 4, 4, 809451) TO THE EDITOR,

('26', 329, 6, 6, 809478) DEAR SIR,
('26', 329, 7, 7, 809488) In the course of a communication addressed to the Government of India, you have stated as one of the seven instances of “lawless repression” the treatment of volunteers who “had given no offence or cause whatever” by the police in Aligarh.
('26', 329, 7, 8, 809728) I have enquired into this on behalf of the Government from the Collector of Aligarh.
('26', 329, 7, 9, 809813) He replies that the charge is absolutely untrue and I beg that you will give publicity to what he writes:
('26', 329, 8, 10, 809919) That knocks have been given and bruises endured is true enough but they have been inflicted solely in the course of dispersing unlawful assemblies and they have been extraordinarily few in number.
('26', 329, 8, 11, 810116) No injured person has approached me, and even the non co operators of Aligarh are quite ready to do so if they have had any real grievance.
('26', 329, 9, 12, 810256) “The unruly spirit of a riotous crowd cannot be conjured away by the polite infinitive.
('26', 329, 9, 13, 810344) As a matter of fact the kid gloves have never yet been taken off in Aligarh and the trouble here has been handled with the greatest moderation.
('26', 329, 9, 14, 810488) Since the early attempt of the volunteers to behave in disorderly and intimidating manner when a certain amout of force had to be used, I am not aware that there has been any kind of physical collision in the town.
('26', 329, 9, 15, 810703) So far as good feeling can be said to exist anywhere, I should say that it exists here, and both the police and Europeans can now go freely about the city without interference.
('26', 329, 9, 16, 810880) To describe Aligarh as suffering, or as having suffered, from repression is a travesty of language and of fact.”
('26', 329, 10, 17, 810993) LUCKNOW, Yours faithfully,
('26', 329, 11, 18, 811020) 16TH FEBRUARY 1922 J. E. GONDGE This is no denial.
('26', 329, 11, 19, 811071) It is an attempt to justify the use of force which is admitted.
('26', 329, 11, 20, 811135) Every tyrant justifies the use he makes of his law lessness.
('26', 329, 11, 21, 811196) Naturally the non co operators did not report their bruises to the Collector.
('26', 329, 11, 22, 811274) If the kid gloves demonstration consisted of “knocks given and bruises endured”, I am curious to know what it will be like when the kid gloves are off in Aligarh.
('26', 329, 11, 23, 811437) If the arrest of Mr. Sherwani was great moderation and that of Mr. Khwaja was greater, then the “Knocks and bruises” were, indeed, the greatest moderation.

('26', 330, 1, 2, 811642) II IN BENARES JAIL
('26', 330, 2, 3, 811661) TO THE EDITOR, Young India
('26', 330, 3, 4, 811688) DEAR SIR,
('26', 330, 4, 5, 811698) In continuation of my d.o.
('26', 330, 4, 6, 811725) letter No.
('26', 330, 4, 7, 811736) 404/C, dated the 18th February 1922, I beg to draw your attention to a telegram from a certain Vishnudatiya of Benares to Mahatma Gandhi dated the 5th of Febuary, which was duly published in your paper on the 9th idem.
('26', 330, 4, 8, 811955) Inquiry has been made into the statements made therein and I must apologize for the length of the report which I must ask you to publish in explanation and contradiction of the telegram aforesaid.
('26', 330, 4, 9, 812152) The telegram was somewhat incoherent, but it has caused much concern in the mind of the public and its allegations can only be answered at considerable length.
('26', 330, 4, 10, 812312) I therefore reproduce the report which has been sent to me by Major N. S. Harvey, the Superintendent of the Benares Central Prison:
('26', 330, 5, 11, 812444) The facts about this case are as follows.
('26', 330, 5, 12, 812486) Eight youths were sentenced by the Joint Magistrate on the 21st January 1922, to rigorous imprisonment under section 143 I. P. C. and classed as non politicals.
('26', 330, 5, 13, 812647) As there was such an unruly and unwieldy mob of political prisoners in the jail at the time, the jailor was not able to keep these eight prisoners separate, and they got mixed up with their friends, the other political prisoners, and we were not able to get hold of them and put them to hard labour.
('26', 330, 6, 14, 812947) On the 3rd February the Joint Magistrate and myself decided that we would separate these ‘non political’ prisoners from the others, and after some trouble we were able to get hold of four of them—Ram Nath, Kamla Pati, Bhagwan Das and Satya Narayan, who were taken away to the regular juvenile prisoners’ enclosure.
('26', 330, 6, 15, 813262) This District Jail has had a juvenile jail in it for many years, so that the removal of these youths to this place was nothing out of the way.
('26', 330, 6, 16, 813405) I have had 50 juveniles confined in this place for seven years to my knowledge.
('26', 330, 6, 17, 813485) The juvenile barrack is a cellular one for obvious reasons, and youths are always locked up separately at night.
('26', 330, 6, 18, 813598) So that the locking up of these four youths in separate cells was not a punishment, but was just the ordinary jail practice.
('26', 330, 6, 19, 813723) They evidently did not like the idea of being separated from their political friends, so Bhagwan Das on the evening of the 4th Feb ruary worked himself into a so called state of ‘unconsciousness’.
('26', 330, 6, 20, 813920) This was about 7.30 p.m.
('26', 330, 6, 21, 813945) I happened to be in the jail at the time and went at once and saw this youth.
('26', 330, 6, 22, 814023) I most carefully examined him and came to the conclusion that there was nothing the matter with him and that he had worked himself into a ‘hysterical state’ purposely.
('26', 330, 6, 23, 814191) Of course, his self imposed hunger strike of two
('26', 331, 0, 1, 814240) 332 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('26', 331, 1, 2, 814282) days’ duration may have had something to do with his condition.
('26', 331, 1, 3, 814346) He probably thought that, if he got into a state of feigned unconsciousness, he would be taken away to hospital and given nourishment.
('26', 331, 1, 4, 814481) This actually happened, some milk was given him and he was quite well by the morning.
('26', 331, 2, 5, 814567) The hunger strike of the other political prisoners from the 3rd to the 5th had nothing to do with this business.
('26', 331, 2, 6, 814680) This was started because they were not allowed to get sweets and food from outside, and also as a sort of advertisement.
('26', 331, 3, 7, 814801) On the night of the 2nd February, Kripalani 1 and his youths gave a lot of trouble in being locked up.
('26', 331, 3, 8, 814904) They behaved like a lot of hooligans in their barracks and the jail people were not able to count or lock them up till 11.30 p.m.
('26', 331, 3, 9, 815034) The next morning they went on ‘hunger strike’ and refused to speak to or answer any jail officials.
('26', 331, 3, 10, 815134) It is all nonsense to say that the cells in which these youths were locked up are insanitary; they are undoubtedly the cleanest and most sanitary living rooms in the jail.
('26', 331, 3, 11, 815306) To prove this, the special treatment prisoners, who have recently been transferred from the Central Jail, have elected to live in these cells.
('26', 331, 3, 12, 815449) As for being waterless, this is absolutely untrue.
('26', 331, 3, 13, 815500) These youths were kept together in the enclosure during the day where there is a perpetual tap of good municipal water and if they had required water at night, there was a regular warder and two convict overseers to give it to them.
('26', 331, 4, 14, 815733) On the 5th February (Sunday) the political prisoners refused to have an interview with their friends as they said they were on hunger strike.
('26', 331, 4, 15, 815875) The mob of two or three hundred city people were told that their friends refused to see them and were asked to go away.
('26', 331, 4, 16, 815995) They refused to do so and collected a few yards in front of the main gate and started yelling, shouting and singing, and as there was a possibility of the gate being rushed into, the jailor telephoned to me.
('26', 331, 4, 17, 816203) I telephoned and asked the Superintendent of Police to remove this noisy and unruly mob from the jail precincts.

('26', 332, 2, 6, 817152) A REGRETTABLE MISREPRESENTATION
('26', 332, 3, 7, 817184) TO THE EDITOR, Young India
('26', 332, 5, 8, 817211) The attention of the Central Province Govenment has been drawn to the editorial note on “Interference with religious liberty” which appeared in your paper of the 2nd February 1922. Enquiries have been made from the Superin tendent, Saugor Jail, with the result that the information on which your com ments are based proves to contain a series of glaring mis statements.
('26', 332, 5, 9, 817581) As these mis statements are causing considerable uneasiness in the public mind, I beg that you will give a prominent place to the following denial in an early issue:
('26', 332, 6, 10, 817747) 1. Pandit Arjun Lal Shetti was admitted into the Saugor Jail on the 19th May 1921. He was put on twine making from the 13th June till he came to be admitted into the Jail Hospital for malaria (not for pneumonia) on the 24th September 1921. He remained in the Hospital for about a month and in consequence of the illness lost 11 lbs.
('26', 332, 6, 11, 818080) in weight, of which he has regained 7 lbs.
('26', 332, 6, 12, 818123) Ever since his discharge from the Hospital, he has been third class work in twine making.
('26', 332, 6, 13, 818213) I am thus able to affirm that he was never made to grind or prepare cords during his illness.
('26', 332, 6, 14, 818307) The allegation that “it was when he was thus pressed that he had tendered an apology which he withdrew immediately he came to his senses” is a wicked lie and has absolutely no foundation in fact.
('26', 332, 6, 15, 818503) The truth is that, in view of the assurance given by the Government in the Provincial Legislative Council on the 2nd August 1921, to consider sympa thetically any apology tendered by persons undergoing prosecution or imprisonment for seditious speeches or offences of similar nature, Superin tendents of Jails were addressed to communicate the Government attitude to the political prisoners in their charge.
('26', 332, 6, 16, 818911) This was accordingly communicated by the Superintendent, Saugor Jail to Pundit Arjun Lal Shetti on or about the middle of September 1921. On the 2nd November 1921 he verbally expressed to the Superintendent his desire to apologize.
('26', 332, 6, 17, 819143) A week after, he said the same thing to the Deputy Commissioner of the District when he paid a visit to the prisoner in Jail.
('26', 332, 6, 18, 819269) The Deputy Commissioner asked him to apply in writing if he really wished to do so.
('26', 332, 6, 19, 819353) The prisoner gave a written apology the next day, i.e, on the 10th November 1921, which was forwarded to the Local Govern ment in the usual official manner.
('26', 332, 6, 20, 819510) The fact of his having tendered an apology was well known and the interest taken by the public in this prisoner’s health
('26', 333, 0, 1, 819631) 334 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('26', 333, 1, 2, 819673) became very great.
('26', 333, 1, 3, 819692) On the 21st November 1921 his son interviewed him and pressed him to withdraw his apology.
('26', 333, 1, 4, 819783) The prisoner showed his willingness to do so in presence of his son and was told by the Superintendent to apply in writing, if he was really serious to withdraw it.
('26', 333, 1, 5, 819948) The prisoner gave the petition to withdraw his apology two days after, i.e., on the 23rd November 1921, and [it] was forwarded by the Superintendent to the Local Government.
('26', 333, 1, 6, 820122) I would pointedly draw your attention to the fact that the prisoner was discharged from the Hospital on the 17th October 1921, and he submitted his apology on the 10 November 1921, that is, nearly a month after the date of the discharge from the Hospital.
('26', 333, 1, 7, 820378) It will thus appear that the prisoner was neither drugged nor tricked into making an apology.
('26', 333, 1, 8, 820472) On the contrary it required the moral influence of his friends to make him withdraw it.
('26', 333, 2, 9, 820560) 2. The allegation that “he is being forced to take eggs and wine” is a perversion of the truth.
('26', 333, 2, 10, 820656) The fact is that neither of these articles is given to the prisoner.
('26', 333, 2, 11, 820725) The prisoner petitioned the Superintendent to give him eggs and also wrote to his relatives about it, asking them to keep the matter secret and not to out caste him.
('26', 333, 2, 12, 820891) He even mentioned this to his friends Laxmi Narayan and Panna Lal of Saugor who interviewed him on the 16th January 1922. The Superintendent could not grant the prisoner’s petition for eggs, as it is an article prohibited to good caste Hindus.
('26', 333, 3, 13, 821135) Yours faithfully, N. R. CHANDORKAR
('26', 333, 4, 14, 821170) PUBLICITY OFFICER TO GOVERNMENT,
