('26', 336, 1, 2, 825474) 135. IN HAZARIBAG JAIL [On or before March 10, 1922] 1
('26', 336, 2, 3, 825529) TO THE EDITOR, Young India
('26', 336, 3, 4, 825556) SIR, On 7 2 22, the Jail Superintendent, Major Cook and Mr. Meck, the Jailor of the local Central Jail, went to see Shah Abutorab Wazi Ahmed B. A., B. L., Vakil of the High Court, who is a political (non co operator) prisoner and who has been transferred here from the Buxar Central Jail.
('26', 336, 3, 5, 825845) At that time the said Maulvi Saheb who was engaged in reading his Quran was asked by the Superintendent to stand up; but as he was busy in reading his Quran he could not do so and hinted by raising his hand to wait, whereon the Jailor shouted out something in English and kicked the Quran and forcibly lifted up the aforesaid Maulvi Saheb and shook him physically and took away the Quran.
('26', 336, 3, 6, 826234) This created a great deal of sensation and unrest among the other political prisoners in the jail who made some sort of protest.
('26', 336, 3, 7, 826363) The public of this town has been greatly alarmed and shocked to hear all these incidents.
('26', 336, 3, 8, 826453) So much so that, on Friday last the Mussalmans of this place held a meeting in the mosque protesting against this sacrilegious act of the Jailor in kicking the Quran and brutally treating the Maulvi Saheb during his religious devotion.
('26', 336, 3, 9, 826689) On 18 2 22 Mr. A. W. Jones, Deputy Magistrate of Hazaribag, went to the jail hospital along with the Superintendent and the Jailor and there examined the aforesaid Maulvi Saheb, Babu Ram Narain Singh, B.L., a non co operator political prisoner, Babu Chitaranjan Guha Thakurta and Maulvi Md.
('26', 336, 3, 10, 826980) Fasiuddin, prisoners, and they all corroborated the fact of kicking the Quran by the Jailor.
('26', 336, 3, 11, 827073) After that, Doctor, Babu and Headwarder were examined and they denied all knowledge of the fact.
('26', 336, 3, 12, 827170) After this the Superintendent ordered that the aforesaid Maulvi Saheb Abutorab B. L., Babu Chitaranjan Guha Thakurta and Md.
('26', 336, 3, 13, 827295) Fasiuddin be given 15 stripes each and they were taken to the place for being flogged and the aforesaid Maulvi Saheb Abutorab B. L. was fastened to the triangular post whereon Mr. Wardi Jones, D. M., asked to wait as he had not examined the orderly.
('26', 336, 3, 14, 827545) Then orderly warder, Ramsagar Ram, was examined who fully corroborated the fact that the Jailor kicked the Quran whereon the Deputy Magistrate stopped the flogging.
('26', 336, 3, 15, 827710) On 23 2 22 the Deputy Commissioner of Hazaribag went to the Central Jail and dismissed the aforesaid warder.
('26', 336, 3, 16, 827819) I am etc., RAMESHWAR PRASAD SECRETARY, HAZARIBAG DISTRICT CONGRESS COMMITTEE 27 2 22
('26', 336, 4, 17, 827904) 1 This and the following item must have been sent to the Press by Gandhiji before his arrest on March 10.
('26', 337, 0, 1, 828010) 338 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('26', 337, 1, 2, 828052) If the statement made by the correspondent is correct, it betrays a lamentable lack of regard even for the most precious religious sentiments of the people.
('26', 337, 1, 3, 828209) Young India, 16 3 1922
('26', 337, 2, 4, 828232) 136. MY NOTES
('26', 337, 3, 5, 828246) [On or before March 10, 1922]
('26', 337, 4, 6, 828276) DISAPPOINTMENT There is keen disappointment in the air following the suspension of civil disobedience.
('26', 337, 4, 7, 828379) There may be two explanations for this: one, that the people’s hope of immediate swaraj has been shat tered and, two, that people did not realize the paramount importance of preserving peace.
('26', 337, 4, 8, 828571) If the first explanation is correct, then the meaning of swaraj has not been understood at all.
('26', 337, 4, 9, 828667) Swaraj is a state of mind to be experienced by us.
('26', 337, 4, 10, 828718) We have to win it by our own strength.
('26', 337, 4, 11, 828757) If this is true, there is no reason at all for disappointment.
('26', 337, 4, 12, 828820) Swaraj consists in our efforts to win it.
('26', 337, 4, 13, 828862) If it is not won at the first attempt, we may make a second, a third, as many more as necessary.
('26', 337, 4, 14, 828959) With every attempt, we shall advance.
('26', 337, 4, 15, 828997) Has our labour of the last fifteen months been wasted?
('26', 337, 4, 16, 829052) He who does not know which direction to take may feel disappointed.
('26', 337, 4, 17, 829120) If we know that swaraj can be won only by following the path of non violence and we discover that, in place of the spirit of non violence which we thought prevailed, people harboured violence, we should clearly see that our progress lies in suspending civil disobedience.
('26', 337, 4, 18, 829392) If an army which has been advancing in the belief that the road ahead is clear comes upon a moat, does its progress lie in jumping into it?
('26', 337, 4, 19, 829532) Does it not lie rather in abandoning the wrong path and seeking the right one or in stopping to build a bridge over the moat?
('26', 337, 4, 20, 829658) What would history say of an army which, standing in despair beside the moat, fills it with its tears?
('26', 337, 5, 21, 829761) NON CO OPERATION NOT UNDERSTOOD Such disappointment only shows that one has not understood the meaning of non co operation.
('26', 337, 5, 22, 829885) The foundation stone of swaraj was laid when non co operation was started.
('26', 337, 5, 23, 829960) The slave who stops saluting his master, is he not freed from that very day?
('26', 337, 5, 24, 830037) Let the master kick him, abuse him, hang him.
('26', 337, 5, 25, 830083) The slave has stopped saluting.
('26', 337, 5, 26, 830115) He has realized that he was a slave.
('26', 337, 5, 27, 830152) What does he care if the master does not
('26', 338, 0, 1, 830193) VOL. 26 : 24 JANUARY, 1922 12 NOVEMBER, 1923 339
('26', 338, 1, 2, 830242) acknowledge him a free man?
('26', 338, 1, 3, 830270) His strength increases with the latter’s resistance, because it is a challenge to him.
('26', 338, 1, 4, 830357) So long as we are firm in our determination to secure justice about the Punjab, to heal the Khilafat wound, to win swaraj and also to stick to non co operation till we have succeeded in these aims, what reason do we have to feel disappointed?
('26', 338, 1, 5, 830600) When the War with Germany started, the British had expected that it would end in two months.
('26', 338, 1, 6, 830693) Lord Curzon thought that he would have his Christmas dinner in Berlin.
('26', 338, 1, 7, 830764) December 1914 passed and the War continued till December 1920; did this mean that the British were defeated?
('26', 338, 1, 8, 830873) Liege was lost, so was Namur.
('26', 338, 1, 9, 830903) France was run over by Germans right up to Paris.
('26', 338, 1, 10, 830953) Did France admit defeat?
('26', 338, 1, 11, 830978) So long as a warrior continues to fight, how can he be regarded as having been defeated?
('26', 338, 1, 12, 831067) While the fight continues, strategy after strategy is planned, schemes of encirclement are tried out, tunnels are made through hills and bridges built over moats.
('26', 338, 1, 13, 831230) It is thus that men and even nations are moulded.
('26', 338, 1, 14, 831280) To Arjuna’s question, “Does not that soul perish which, though struggling, fails in its efforts?” 1 Shri Krishna replied, with the utmost affection: “No one who keeps striving ever meets with an unhappy end.” 2 “It is only the soul which doubts that perishes.” 3 If we do not have faith in our non co operation, we lose the struggle the very hour we embark on it.
('26', 338, 2, 15, 831644) NOT PLAY ACTING The struggle on which we embarked in Calcutta in 1920 was no mere play acting 4. The decision was an expression of the nation’s firm resolve.
('26', 338, 2, 16, 831802) It was a pledge, like the one taken by the mill hands in Ahmedabad 5. Whether the struggle takes thirteen days or twenty three, do those who stake their honour make any terms with God?
('26', 338, 3, 17, 831987) TIME LIMIT OF ONE YEAR MISUNDERSTOOD Some say: “Why should we send our children to national schools now?
('26', 338, 3, 18, 832092) We had withdrawn them [from government schools] in the hope that everything would be over in a year” If there are many people who think in this way, it is indeed good that our goal was not
('26', 338, 4, 19, 832281) 1 Bhagavad Gita, VI.
('26', 338, 4, 20, 832302) 38 2 ibid 3 ibid 4 At the special session of the congress held in Calcutta in September 1920, the Non co operation resolution was passed.
('26', 338, 4, 21, 832440) 5 In February 1918.
('26', 339, 0, 1, 832460) 340 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('26', 339, 1, 2, 832502) won in one year.
('26', 339, 1, 3, 832519) Otherwise, what would have been the condition of such people and the country?
('26', 339, 1, 4, 832597) If we have been unable to win power in one year, by what logic have schools which earlier appeared sinful to us become now fit for our children to attend?
('26', 339, 1, 5, 832752) Or, were the parents merely led away by my arguments when they withdrew their children from schools?
('26', 339, 1, 6, 832853) If so, I ask their forgiveness and would certainly advise such parents to send their children to Government schools.
('26', 339, 1, 7, 832970) I and those who have under stood the meaning of non co operation will ever look upon these schools, even if guineas were to be distributed there, as fit to be boycotted so long as the Government does not repent and bow to public opinion, whether this takes one year or many many years.
('26', 339, 2, 8, 833256) WRONG COURSE Some say that the Vidyapith should pay the expenses of schools.
('26', 339, 2, 9, 833333) If the Vidyapith is to pay, where will it get the money from?
('26', 339, 2, 10, 833395) Surely, it will not bring money from outside to educate children in Gujarat?
('26', 339, 2, 11, 833472) Instead of contributing money to the Vidyapith and then getting it back from it, why should we not raise enough in each town or village to run good private schools.?
('26', 339, 3, 12, 833638) SAHARA DESERT I am convinced that it is all to the good that our way has been blocked by this Sahara Desert.
('26', 339, 3, 13, 833747) We shall profit by the experience of being scorched by the heat and get hardened.
('26', 339, 3, 14, 833829) We shall now be able to distinguish right from wrong, make out the brave from the coward, differentiate between those who joined us with proper understanding and those who did so without such understanding.
('26', 339, 3, 15, 834036) We shall now know who are the actors and who the spectators.
('26', 339, 3, 16, 834097) It was indeed necessary that we should learn this.
('26', 339, 3, 17, 834148) Schools are an acid test for us, Wherever national schools are functioning, it is proper that the local people should regard it as a point of honour to run them on their own.
('26', 339, 3, 18, 834323) If no buildings are available, classes should be held under trees; if teachers cannot be paid, they may go round begging for provisions, live a life of privation and teach children.
('26', 339, 3, 19, 834505) Only in this way can the nation rise.
('26', 339, 4, 20, 834543) ROWDYISM WILL NOT SUCCEED
('26', 339, 5, 21, 834569) Defiance of law for its own sake is uncivil behaviour and rowdyism.
('26', 339, 5, 22, 834637) If swaraj is won through rowdyism will the rowdies then run the Government?
('26', 339, 5, 23, 834713) We are planning to win it with our own efforts
('26', 340, 0, 1, 834760) VOL. 26 : 24 JANUARY, 1922 12 NOVEMBER, 1923 341
('26', 340, 1, 2, 834809) and hope to run it ourselves.
('26', 340, 1, 3, 834839) The worth of the swaraj builder will not be tested by his ability to destroy, but by his ability to construct.
('26', 340, 1, 4, 834950) One who can construct certainly knows how to destroy.
('26', 340, 1, 5, 835004) But all those who can destroy cannot construct.
('26', 340, 1, 6, 835052) We call the person who is engaged for breaking stones and gravel a mere wage earner, while the one who builds is called mason.
('26', 340, 1, 7, 835179) Without having learnt how to construct, we wanted to start destroying in Bardoli 1 and so God, in His kindness, held us back and saved us from danger.
('26', 340, 2, 8, 835330) SWARAJ BUILDERS We should heed the warning.
('26', 340, 2, 9, 835374) We should now make an effort to become masons.
('26', 340, 2, 10, 835421) If we cannot give a good account of ourselves in the building department, we have no right to offer civil disobedience.
('26', 340, 3, 11, 835541) INDIFFERENCE ABOUT PRESERVING PEACE I have said that the second reason for disappointment may be that people failed to realize the importance of preserving peace.
('26', 340, 3, 12, 835704) This is more dangerous than even the failure to understand the meaning of swaraj, for in that failure we are merely guilty of faulty diagnosis.
('26', 340, 3, 13, 835848) If the vaid 2 is not sure of the correctness of his diagnosis, he can prescribe mild remedies.
('26', 340, 3, 14, 835943) In the second instance, however, the vaid is guilty of carelessness in prescribing a remedy.
('26', 340, 3, 15, 836036) A vaid gave a friend of mine zinc oxide in place of magnesium sulphate.
('26', 340, 3, 16, 836108) Instead of having motions, the latter started vomiting and it was with the greatest effort, with proper treatment and after he had suffered much, that the patient was saved.
('26', 340, 3, 17, 836282) Arsenic powder and powdered sugar look very much alike; what would be the condition of a person who takes arsenic instead of sugar?
('26', 340, 3, 18, 836414) A friend mistook salt for sugar and put three teaspoonfuls in a cup of tea.
('26', 340, 3, 19, 836490) When he took a sip, the expression on his face was worth reproducing in some comic journal.
('26', 340, 3, 20, 836582) The examples I have given are of ignorant, inexperienced vaids.
('26', 340, 3, 21, 836646) But what shall we say about one who, though knowing the difference between arsenic and powdered sugar, does not care whether he gives the one or the other?
('26', 340, 3, 22, 836802) We may understand the point of view of those who believe that swaraj cannot be won by peaceful means, but it is impossible to tolerate one who is so thoughtless as to incite violence
('26', 340, 4, 23, 836985) 1 The Bardoli Taluka Conference held on January 29, 1922 accepted Gandhiji’s proposal to launch civil disobedience and he informed the Viceroy about it in his letter of February 1. But the Chauri Chaura tragedy led Gandhji to decide that the movement should be suspended.

('26', 341, 0, 1, 837291) 342 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('26', 341, 1, 2, 837333) when an experiment in a peaceful method is in progress.
('26', 341, 1, 3, 837389) Anyone who is so thoughtless knows neither the meaning of swaraj nor the best means of securing it.
('26', 341, 1, 4, 837489) To such a person, concern for means seems to be fetters on his freedom.
('26', 341, 1, 5, 837561) My view is that, by suspending civil disobedience in Bardoli, we have saved ourselves from a great calamity.
('26', 341, 1, 6, 837670) If we are certain that we shall not on the whole succeed in influencing people to adopt peaceful methods and that the profes sional trouble makers, too, in the country will not yield to our persuasion, it would be wise to give up all talk of winning swaraj by peaceful means.
('26', 341, 1, 7, 837946) If we cannot gain control over them by such means, we should conclude that we shall never be able to bring round this Government also by peaceful means.
('26', 341, 1, 8, 838099) If they cannot be won over by our love, they will assuredly be over awed by the Government’s guns and help it, or they themselves will become the rulers.
('26', 341, 1, 9, 838253) Both these situations are undesirable.
('26', 341, 1, 10, 838292) I believe that, though it may be difficult, it is not impossible to win over the lawless elements.
('26', 341, 1, 11, 838391) We need to have faith in ourselves, as also patience.
('26', 341, 1, 12, 838445) Our lives should be governed by dharma.
('26', 341, 2, 13, 838485) If we earnestly start working on the various items in the non co operation programme and make progress in them all, we shall automatically learn the lesson of peace, for they include three impor tant constructive activitieskhadi, removal of untouchability and the unity of all communities.
('26', 341, 2, 14, 838776) Can anyone even dream that Hindus and Muslims can be truly united until they have fully realized the importance of peace?
('26', 341, 2, 15, 838898) If the two can maintain peaceful relations so that they may help each other, they together can, with love, win over the unsocial elements and other mischief makers.
('26', 341, 2, 16, 839063) Those who believe that this cannot be done cannot possibly believe in true friendship between Hindus and Muslims.
('26', 341, 2, 17, 839177) If these two major communities are not bound to each other by ties of mutual regard, I venture a prophecy and say that one day they will fight it out to their heart’s content.
('26', 341, 2, 18, 839353) If the pride of both is humbled after this, the two together will be able to overcome the third party; if, on the other hand, one of the two is defeated in fighting, it will be doomed to slavery.
('26', 341, 2, 19, 839549) This way of looking at the matter will furnish us the key to an understanding of all our problems.
('26', 341, 2, 20, 839648) That Hindus and Muslims should find themselves together in such large numbers in India, that they should have been enslaved by third power and that subsequently both should be awakenedthe
('26', 342, 0, 1, 839837) VOL. 26 : 24 JANUARY, 1922 12 NOVEMBER, 1923 343
('26', 342, 1, 2, 839886) significance of these facts is plain for all to see.
('26', 342, 1, 3, 839939) For myself.
('26', 342, 1, 4, 839951) I see every moment the providence of God in it.
('26', 342, 1, 5, 839999) Through peace lies victory, and through violence the destruction of both.
('26', 342, 2, 6, 840073) PROPAGATION OF KHADI Shri Ramji Hansraj writes from Amreli to say that there was a time when hand spun khadi was not available.
('26', 342, 2, 7, 840201) Now that there is a large stock of khadi, he says, there are no people to wear it, and the saddest part of the story is that the women who spin, the carders who make the slivers and those who weave cloth from hand spun yarn do not themselves wear khadi.
('26', 342, 2, 8, 840455) How can we hope to win swaraj under such circumstances?
('26', 342, 2, 9, 840511) What is one to make of the fact that, even in a part of the country like Kathiawar, people do not wear khadi?
('26', 342, 2, 10, 840621) Can anything be more perverse than that, instead of eating the bread I have made, I sell it in the market and then buy other bread for myself?
('26', 342, 2, 11, 840764) Should I not value my own handiwork?
('26', 342, 2, 12, 840801) What are the workers of Kathiawar doing about this?
('26', 342, 2, 13, 840853) Is not this one task enough to engage their energiesto produce khadi and see that people wear it?
('26', 342, 2, 14, 840952) If they give up busying themselves with other activities, things will soon get right.
('26', 342, 2, 15, 841038) If population of twenty six lakhs spins, cards and weaves to the value of no more than Rs. 10 per head every year, even then its work would produce goods worth two crore and sixty lakh rupees.
('26', 342, 2, 16, 841231) This would come to less than two pice per head daily.
('26', 342, 2, 17, 841285) But drop by drop the lake is filled, as they say; in like manner, the result which can be brought about by an increase of two pice in everyone’s earnings should be seen to be believed.
('26', 342, 2, 18, 841470) A postcard costing a pice, a tax of two pies on a rupee worth of salt, railway fares at the rate of three or four pies a milethis is how Government’s Postal Department makes a profit and the Post Master General gets an annual salary of thousands, the salt tax yields crores and the railway company earns lakhs from railway fares calculated at the rate of a few pies a mile.
('26', 342, 2, 19, 841845) The same kind of calculation applies to khadi.
('26', 342, 2, 20, 841892) The only difference is that, while taxes at rates of a few pies make it possible for the Government to rule over us and the Viceroy to be paid a salary of Rs. 20,000 a month, while the earnings of railways yield large dividends to foreigners, the income from khadi will remain in the homes of the poor and brighten their lives.
('26', 342, 2, 21, 842220) Practising this simple dharma even in a little measure can end much suffering.
('26', 343, 0, 1, 842299) 344 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('26', 343, 1, 2, 842341) I request everyone to help in clearing khadi stocks immediately wherever they have accumulated and in producing it wherever it is not being produced.
('26', 343, 1, 3, 842491) I believe that all the khadi in Amreli will be disposed off if every person there buys from the store khadi just enough for one shirt.
('26', 343, 1, 4, 842626) Are there not enough uses for khadi?
('26', 343, 1, 5, 842663) It can be used for making towels, loose covers, coverlets, double sheets, satchels, bags, hammocks and carpets.
('26', 343, 1, 6, 842775) When I hear of khadi stocks not being sold, I am reminded of persons who buy animal fat in place of ghee.
('26', 343, 1, 7, 842881) In our country people may refuse to buy khadi when they refuse to buy ghee.
('26', 343, 1, 8, 842957) We cannot claim to have understood the meaning of swaraj till khadi becomes as universal as currency.
('26', 343, 2, 9, 843059) COTTON SEASON This is the cotton season.
('26', 343, 2, 10, 843100) A reader, therefore reminds us that everyone, especially the cultivator, should store enough cotton for his own use.
('26', 343, 2, 11, 843217) Others may buy for their needs.
('26', 343, 2, 12, 843249) We should count no less than four seers of cotton per head.
('26', 343, 2, 13, 843309) The best way to store it is for each one of us either to spin the quantity into yarn or to get it spun by someone else.
('26', 343, 2, 14, 843429) The rich can employ skilled women and have fine, well twisted yarn spun according to their liking.
('26', 343, 2, 15, 843528) In this way, we can revive the old custom of employing one’s own spinner and weaver.
('26', 343, 3, 16, 843613) ARBITRATION BOARDS In Gujarat, the practice of appointing arbitration boards has not yet been introduced.
('26', 343, 3, 17, 843719) We have completely forgotten the advantages of having our disputes settled by a panch or an arbitrator, as if we thought that justice could only be got through unknown persons and by spending money.
('26', 343, 3, 18, 843918) Justice is not to be bought for money in this way; what can be sold is injustice.
('26', 343, 3, 19, 844000) Fraud or false witnesses will be of no avail before a panch or an arbitrator.
('26', 343, 3, 20, 844078) A panch settles the dispute and so brings the two parties together.
('26', 343, 3, 21, 844146) Courts increase enmity, panchas lessen it.
('26', 343, 3, 22, 844189) It is true that in these days people are tempted to go to courts because of absence of honest panchas.
('26', 343, 3, 23, 844292) Moreover, are those who are fond of litigation likely to go to a panch at all?
('26', 343, 3, 24, 844371) Nevertheless, if in every town or village, people make an effort, the practice of settling disputes through panchas or arbitrators can be revived.
('26', 343, 4, 25, 844518) POLLUTION OF SAFFRON
('26', 343, 5, 26, 844539) Till this day I was not aware that the saffron which is used for ritual worship and making sweets is imported from abroad and that it
('26', 344, 0, 1, 844673) VOL. 26 : 24 JANUARY, 1922 12 NOVEMBER, 1923 345
('26', 344, 1, 2, 844722) is smeared with animal fat.

('26', 344, 2, 4, 844792) In view of these painful facts, the use of saffron in ritual worship or for making sweetmeats is courting sin while seeking to do good.

('26', 347, 4, 6, 848897) 143. LETTER TO GOPALA MENON
('26', 347, 5, 7, 848925) SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, SABARMATI, March 10, 1922
('26', 347, 6, 8, 848970) MY DEAR GOPALA MENON, I certainly do remember your conviction.
('26', 347, 6, 9, 849033) I wish your venture all success.
('26', 347, 6, 10, 849066) The only message 1 that I can send in the midst of overwhelming work is for both Hindus and Mop lahs to realize their future responsibility not to brood over the past.
('26', 347, 6, 11, 849234) How to reach the Moplahs as also the class of Hindus whom you would want to reach through your newspaper is more than I can say, but I know that Hindus should cease to be cowardly.
('26', 347, 6, 12, 849415) The Moplahs should cease to be cruel.
('26', 347, 6, 13, 849453) In other words, each party should become truly religious.
('26', 347, 6, 14, 849511) According to the Shastras, Hinduism is certainly not the creed of cowards.
('26', 347, 6, 15, 849586) Equally certainly, Islam is not the creed of the cruel.
('26', 347, 6, 16, 849642) The only way the terrible problem before you can be solved is by a few picked Hindus and Mussalmans working away in perfect unison and with faith in their mission.
('26', 347, 6, 17, 849806) They ought not to be baffled by absence of results in the initial stages, and if you can get together from among your readers a number of such men and women, your paper will have served a noble purpose.
('26', 347, 7, 18, 850009) Yours sincerely, SJT.

('26', 351, 0, 1, 855272) 352 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('26', 351, 1, 2, 855314) The Superintendent of Police, Ahmedabad, first witness, produced the Bombay Government’s authority to lodge a complaint for four articles published in Young India dated 15th June 1921 entitled “Disaffection a Virtue”, dated 29th September, “Tampering with Loyalty”.
('26', 351, 1, 3, 855580) dated 15th December, “The Puzzle and its Solution” and dated 23rd February 1922, “Shaking the Manes”.
('26', 351, 1, 4, 855682) 1 He stated that the warrant was issued on the 6th instant by the District Magistrate, Ahmedabad, and the case was transferred to the file of Mr. Brown.
('26', 351, 1, 5, 855835) Meanwhile warrants were also issued to the Superintendents of Police of Surat and Ajmer as Mr. Gandhi was expected to be at those places.
('26', 351, 1, 6, 855973) The original signed articles and issues of the paper in which these appeared were also produced as evidence.
('26', 351, 2, 7, 856082) Mr. Gharda, Registrar, Appellate side, Bombay High Court, second witness, produced correspondence between Mr. Gandhi, the Editor of Young India and Mr. Kennedy, District Judge, Bombay High Court.
('26', 351, 2, 8, 856278) Mr. Chatfield, Collector and Magistrate of Ahmedabad, was the next witness.
('26', 351, 2, 9, 856354) He testified that security had been dispensed with on the understanding that he should be informed if Mr. Gandhi started his Satyagraha Campaign.
('26', 351, 2, 10, 856500) Two formal police witnesses were then produced.
('26', 351, 3, 11, 856548) Accused declined to cross examine the witnesses.
('26', 351, 4, 12, 856597) Mr. M. K. Gandhi, 53, farmer and weaver by profession, residing at Satyagraha Ashram, Sabarmati, said: I only want to state that, when the proper time comes, I shall plead “guilty”so far as disaffection towards Government is con cerned.
('26', 351, 4, 13, 856834) It is true that I am the Editor of Young India, that the articles read in my presence were written by me and that the proprietors and publishers permitted me to control the whole of policy of the paper.
('26', 351, 4, 14, 857037) That is all.

('26', 352, 1, 2, 857905) 149. INTERVIEW TO INDULAL YAGNIK 1
('26', 352, 2, 3, 857940) SABARMATI JAIL, March 11, 1922 A big job has been accomplished in Ajmer 2. Maulana Abdul Bari 3 made a scathing speech which deeply agitated the thousands of Muslims who had gathered there.
('26', 352, 2, 4, 858130) He had bragged a little.
('26', 352, 2, 5, 858155) Many believe when I went there that there would be fireworks between us two and Hindu Muslim unity would be wrecked.
('26', 352, 2, 6, 858272) But the Maulana is an extremely pure man.
('26', 352, 2, 7, 858314) I said to him: “Whatever you do today will be done in anger only.
('26', 352, 2, 8, 858380) That may, perhaps, incense a few other Muslims also, but that will not benefit us at all.
('26', 352, 2, 9, 858470) I, too, wish that both of us should go to the gallows, but only while we remain utterly pure.” “The Maulana understood my point fully and now I do not worry on his account at all.
('26', 352, 2, 10, 858650) Maulana Hasrat Mohani 4 also was there and he has come here with me.
('26', 352, 2, 11, 858719) He has promised me that he would not place obstacles in the straightforward work of the Congress by upholding violence even in the least.
('26', 352, 2, 12, 858857) Therefore, I am free from anxiety.
('26', 352, 3, 13, 858892) I have only one message to give and that concerns khadi, Place khadi in my hands and I shall place swaraj in yours.
('26', 352, 3, 14, 859008) The uplift of the Antyajas is also covered by khadi and even Hindu Muslim unity will live through it.
('26', 352, 3, 15, 859110) It is also a great instrument of peace.
('26', 352, 3, 16, 859150) This does not mean that I do not favour boycott of Councils and law courts, but in order that people may not have a grievance against those who go to them, I desire that the people should carry on work concerning khadi even with the help of lawyers and members of legislatures.
('26', 352, 3, 17, 859428) Keep the Moderates highly pleased, cultivate love and friendship for them.
('26', 352, 3, 18, 859503) Once they become fearless, that very moment they will become one with us.
('26', 352, 3, 19, 859577) The same holds good also for Englishmen.

('26', 353, 3, 5, 860333) 150. MESSAGE TO BOMBAY 3
('26', 353, 4, 6, 860358) SABARMATI JAIL, March 11, 1922 I do not want Bombay to mourn over the arrest of one of its mute Secretaries and myself, but to rejoice over our rest.
('26', 353, 4, 7, 860508) Whilst I would like an automatic response to all the items of non co operation, I would like Bombay to concentrate upon the charkha and khaddar.
('26', 353, 4, 8, 860653) The moneyed men of Bombay can buy all the hand spun and hand woven khaddar that could be manufactured throughout India.
('26', 353, 4, 9, 860773) The women of Bombay, if they really mean to do their share of work, should religiously spin for a certain time every day for the sake of the country.
('26', 353, 4, 10, 860923) I wish that no one will think of following us to jail.
('26', 353, 4, 11, 860978) It would be criminal to court imprisonment till a complete non violent atmos phere is attained.
('26', 353, 4, 12, 861074) One test of such atmosphere will be for us to put the Englishmen and Moderates at ease.
('26', 353, 4, 13, 861162) This can be done only if we have goodwill towards them in spite of our differences.

('26', 353, 7, 16, 861315) 151.LETTER TO HAKIM AJMAL KHAN
('26', 353, 8, 17, 861346) SABARMATI JAIL, March 12, 1922
('26', 353, 9, 18, 861377) MY DEAR HAKIMJI, Since my arrest, this is the first letter I have commenced to write after having ascertained that under the jail rules I am entitled to write
('26', 353, 10, 19, 861536) 1 Referring to Madan Mohan Malaviya 2 When Yagnik remarked, while taking leave of Gandhiji, that the latter had found in the jail a good nursing home, Gandhiji burst out into a great laugh and said, “Of course, of course, that is so”.
('26', 353, 10, 20, 861771) 3 The message was sent through Sarojini Naidu who met Gandhiji in Sabarmati Jail.
('26', 354, 0, 1, 861853) VOL. 26 : 24 JANUARY, 1922 12 NOVEMBER, 1923 355
('26', 354, 1, 2, 861902) as many letters as I like as an under trial prisoner.
('26', 354, 1, 3, 861956) Of course, you know that Mr. Shankerlal Banker is with me.
('26', 354, 1, 4, 862015) I am happy that he is with me.
('26', 354, 1, 5, 862046) Everyone knows how near he has come to menaturally, therefore, both of us are glad that we have been arrested together.
('26', 354, 1, 6, 862167) I write this to you in your capacity as Chairman of the Working Committee and, therefore, leader of both Hindus and Mussalmans or, better still, of all India.
('26', 354, 1, 7, 862326) I write to you also as one of the foremost leaders of Mussal mans, but, above all, I write this to you as an esteemed friend.
('26', 354, 1, 8, 862452) I have had the privilege of knowing you since 1915. Our daily growing association has enabled me to prize your friendship as a treasure.
('26', 354, 1, 9, 862589) A staunch Mussalman, you have shown in your own life what Hindu Muslim unity means.
('26', 354, 1, 10, 862673) We all now realize as we have never before realized that without that unity, we cannot attain our freedom and I make bold to say that, without that unity, the Mussalmans of India cannot render the Khilafat all the aid they wish.
('26', 354, 1, 11, 862902) Divided, we must ever remain slaves.
('26', 354, 1, 12, 862939) This unity, therefore, cannot be a mere policy to be discarded when it does not suit us.
('26', 354, 1, 13, 863028) We can discard it only when we are tired of swaraj.
('26', 354, 1, 14, 863080) Hindu Muslim unity must be our creed to last for all time and under all circumstances.
('26', 354, 1, 15, 863167) Nor must that unity be a menace to the minorities, the Parsis, the Christians, the Jews or the powerful Sikhs.
('26', 354, 1, 16, 863278) If we seek to crush any of them, we shall some day want to fight each other.
('26', 354, 1, 17, 863355) I have been drawn so close to you chiefly because I know that you believe in Hindu Muslim unity in the full sense of the term.
('26', 354, 1, 18, 863482) This unity, in my opinion, is unattainable without our adopting non violence as a firm policy.
('26', 354, 1, 19, 863577) I call it a policy because it is limited to the preservation of that unity.
('26', 354, 1, 20, 863653) But it follows that thirty crores of Hindus and Mussalmans united not for a time but for all time can defy all the powers of the world and should consider it a cowardly act to resort to violence in their dealings with the English administrators.
('26', 354, 1, 21, 863899) We have hitherto feared them and their guns in our simplicity.
('26', 354, 1, 22, 863962) The moment we realize our combined strength, we shall consider it unmanly to fear them and therefore, ever to think of striking them.
('26', 354, 1, 23, 864096) Hence, am I anxious and impatient to persuade my countrymen to feel non violent not out of our weakness but out of our strength.
('26', 354, 1, 24, 864225) But you and I know that we have not yet evolved the non violence of the strong and we have not done so because the Hindu Muslim union has not gone much beyond the stage of policy.
('26', 354, 1, 25, 864405) There is still too much mutual distrust and consequent fear.
('26', 354, 1, 26, 864466) I am not disappointed.
('26', 355, 0, 1, 864489) 356 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('26', 355, 1, 2, 864531) progress we have made in that direction is indeed phenomenal.
('26', 355, 1, 3, 864593) We seem to have covered in eighteen months’ time the work of a generation.
('26', 355, 1, 4, 864668) But infinitely more is necessary.
('26', 355, 1, 5, 864702) Neither the classes nor the masses feel instinctively that our union is necessary as the breath of our nostrils.
('26', 355, 1, 6, 864815) For this consummation, we must, it seems to me, rely more upon quality than quantity.
('26', 355, 1, 7, 864901) Given a sufficient number of Hindus and Mussalmans with almost a fanatical faith in everlasting friendship between the Hindus and the Mussalmans of India, we shall not be long before the unity permeates the masses.
('26', 355, 1, 8, 865116) A few of us must first clearly understand that we can make no headway without accepting non violence in thought, word and deed for the full realization of our political ambition.
('26', 355, 1, 9, 865295) I would, therefore, beseech you and the members of the Working Committee and the A.I.C.C. to see that our ranks contain no workers who do not fully realize the essential truth I have endeavoured to place before you.
('26', 355, 1, 10, 865511) A living faith cannot be manufactured by the rule of majority.
('26', 355, 1, 11, 865574) To me the visible symbol of all India unity and, therefore, of the acceptance of non violence as an indispensable means for the realization of our political ambition is undoubtedly the charkha, i.e., khaddar.
('26', 355, 1, 12, 865783) Only those who believe in cultivating a non violent spirit and eternal friendship between Hindus and Mussalmans will daily and religiously spin.
('26', 355, 1, 13, 865928) Universal hand spinning and the universal manu facture and use of hand spun and hand woven khaddar will be a substantial, if not absolute, proof of the real unity and non violence, and it will be a recognition of a living kinship with the dumb masses.
('26', 355, 1, 14, 866180) Nothing can possibly unify and revivify India as the acceptance by all India of the spinning wheel as a daily sacrament and the khaddar wear as a privilege and a duty.
('26', 355, 1, 15, 866348) Whilst, therefore, I am anxious that more title holders should give up their titles; lawyers, law courts; scholars, the Government schools or colleges; the Councillors, the Councils and the soldiers and the civilians, their posts, I would urge the nation to restrict its activity in this direction only to the consolidation of the results already achieved and to trust its strength to command further abstentions from association with a system we are seeking to mend or end.
('26', 355, 1, 16, 866823) Moreover, the workers are too few.
('26', 355, 1, 17, 866858) I would not waste a single worker today on destructive work when we have such an enormous amount of constructive work.
('26', 355, 1, 18, 866977) But perhaps the most conclusive argument against devoting further time to destructive propaganda is the fact that the spirit of intolerance, which is a form of violence, has never been so rampant as now.
('26', 355, 1, 19, 867181) Co operators are estranged from us.
('26', 356, 0, 1, 867217) VOL. 26 : 24 JANUARY, 1922 12 NOVEMBER, 1923 357
('26', 356, 1, 2, 867266) They fear us.
('26', 356, 1, 3, 867280) They say that we are establishing a worse bureaucracy than the existing one.
('26', 356, 1, 4, 867357) We must remove every cause for such anxiety.
('26', 356, 1, 5, 867402) We must go out of our way to win them to our side.
('26', 356, 1, 6, 867453) We must make Englishmen safe from all harm from our side.
('26', 356, 1, 7, 867511) I should not have to labour the point if it was clear to everyone, as it is to you and to me, that our pledge of non violence implies utter humility and goodwill even towards our bitterest opponent.
('26', 356, 1, 8, 867710) This necessary spirit will be automatically realized if only India will devote her sole attention to the work of construction suggested by me.
('26', 356, 1, 9, 867853) I flatter myself with the belief that my imprisonment is quite enough for a long time to come.
('26', 356, 1, 10, 867948) I believe in all humility that I have no ill will against anyone.
('26', 356, 1, 11, 868014) Some of my friends would not have to be as non violent as I am.
('26', 356, 1, 12, 868078) But we contemplated the imprisonment of the most innocent.
('26', 356, 1, 13, 868137) If I may be allowed that claim, it is clear that I should not be followed to prison by anybody at all.
('26', 356, 1, 14, 868240) We do want to paralyse the Government considered as a systemnot however by intimidation, but by the irresistible pressure of our innocence.
('26', 356, 1, 15, 868381) In my opinion, it would be intimidation to fill the gaols anyhow, and why should more innocent men seek imprisonment till one considered to be the most innocent has been found inadequate for the purpose?
('26', 356, 1, 16, 868585) My caution against further courting of imprisonment does not mean that we are now to shirk imprisonment.
('26', 356, 1, 17, 868690) If the Government will take away every non violent non co operator, I should welcome it.
('26', 356, 1, 18, 868779) Only, it should not be because of our civil disobedience, defensive or aggressive.
('26', 356, 1, 19, 868862) Nor, I hope, will the country fret over those who are in jail.
('26', 356, 1, 20, 868925) It will do them and the country good to serve the full term of their imprisonment.
('26', 356, 1, 21, 869008) They can be fitly discharged before their time only by an act of the Swaraj Parliament.
('26', 356, 1, 22, 869096) And I entertain an absolute conviction that universal adoption of khaddar is swaraj.
('26', 356, 1, 23, 869181) I have refrained from mentioning untouchability.
('26', 356, 1, 24, 869230) I am sure every good Hindu believes that it has got to go.
('26', 356, 1, 25, 869289) Its removal is as necessary as the realization of Hindu Muslim unity.
('26', 356, 1, 26, 869359) I have placed before you a programme which is, in my opinion, the quickest and the best.
('26', 356, 1, 27, 869448) No impatient Khilafatist can devise a better.
('26', 356, 1, 28, 869494) May God give you health and wisdom to guide the country to her destined goal.
('26', 356, 2, 29, 869572) I am Yours sincerely M. K. GANDHI

('26', 358, 1, 2, 871131) 153. LETTER TO ABDUL BARI
('26', 358, 2, 3, 871157) SABARMATI JAIL, [After March 12, 1922]
('26', 358, 3, 4, 871196) DEAR MAULANA SAHIB, Just now I am enjoying myself in my house of freedom.
('26', 358, 3, 5, 871270) Hakimji and other friends are here.
('26', 358, 3, 6, 871306) I feel your absence, but that does not much worry me since we had ample discussion at Ajmer.
('26', 358, 3, 7, 871399) I know that you will certainly steadily stick to those principles that formed the subject of our talk.
('26', 358, 3, 8, 871502) I will earnestly request you to avoid making any speeches in public.
('26', 358, 3, 9, 871571) Personally, after deep thought, I have come to the conclusion that, if there is anything that can serve an effective and visible symbol of the Hindu Muslim unity, it is the adoption of charkha and pure khaddar dress prepared from hand spun yarn by the rank and file of both the communities.
('26', 358, 3, 10, 871862) Only universal acceptance of this cult can supply us with a common idea and afford a common basis of action.
('26', 358, 3, 11, 871971) The use of khaddar cannot become universal until both the communities take to it.
('26', 358, 3, 12, 872053) The universal adoption of charkha and khaddar, therefore, would awaken India.
('26', 358, 3, 13, 872131) It will also be a proof of our capacity to satisfy all our needs.
('26', 358, 3, 14, 872197) Ever since the commencement of our present struggle, we have been feeling the necessity of boycotting foreign cloth.
('26', 358, 3, 15, 872314) I venture to suggest that, when khaddar comes uni versally in use, the boycott of foreign cloth will automatically follow.
('26', 358, 3, 16, 872437) Speaking for myself, charkha and khaddar have a special religious significance to me because they are a symbol of kinship between the members of both the communities and the hunger and disease stricken poor.
('26', 358, 3, 17, 872645) It is by virtue of the fact that our movement can today be described as moral and economic as well as political.
('26', 358, 3, 18, 872758) So long as we cannot achieve this little thing, I feel certain success is impossible.
('26', 358, 3, 19, 872844) Again, the khaddar movement can succeed only when we recognize non violence as an essential condition for the attainment of swaraj and Khilafat both.
('26', 358, 3, 20, 872994) Therefore, the khaddar programme is the only effective and successful programme that I can place before the country at present.
('26', 358, 3, 21, 873122) I was so glad when you told me that you would begin to spin regularly when I be arrested.
('26', 358, 3, 22, 873212) I can only say that every man, woman and child ought to spin as a religious duty till a complete and permanent boycott of foreign cloth is effected, the Khilafat and

('26', 361, 5, 9, 876479) 158. INTERVIEW IN JAIL 3
('26', 361, 6, 10, 876504) SABARMATI JAIL, March 14, 1922
('26', 361, 7, 11, 876535) A long discussion took place regarding the contribution of funds by some Ahmedabad mills towards the Tilak Swaraj Fund of about three lacs of rupees.
('26', 361, 7, 12, 876685) Mr. Gandhi insisted on the giving over the whole amount to the Gujarat Provincial Committee, in a manner so as to use any sum wholly or partly in the national education.
('26', 361, 7, 13, 876855) At the end of a long argumentative discussion, ultimately the parties came to a unanimous decision that the Fund Committee should pay every year such amount as may be voted by the Provincial Committee to the labour unions of Ahme dabad in the interest of labour schools.
('26', 361, 7, 14, 877126) The Unions were to submit their accounts to the Fund Committee of the mill owners and keep drawing amounts from them.
('26', 361, 8, 15, 877244) This matter being settled, Mr. Gordhandas Patel, who is the Honorary Joint Secretary of the Mill Owners’ Association, asked Gandhiji:
('26', 361, 9, 16, 877378) In case you are convicted, will the non co operation movement be adversely affected?
('26', 361, 9, 17, 877463) A. The words “in case” are inappropriate.
('26', 361, 9, 18, 877505) The more harsh the punishment, the more strong will the non co operation movement be.
('26', 361, 9, 19, 877591) This is my firm conviction.
('26', 361, 10, 20, 877619) 1 Revashanker Jagjivan Jhaveri, a friend of Gandhiji and brother of Dr. Pranjivan Mehta.
('26', 361, 10, 21, 877708) 2 Omission in the source 3 Gandhiji was interviewed by leading public men of Ahmedabad along with Gordhandas I. Patel, member of the Ahmedabad Mills Tilak Swaraj Fund who, in his private capacity, put a few questions to Gandhiji.

('26', 362, 0, 1, 877989) VOL. 26 : 24 JANUARY, 1922 12 NOVEMBER, 1923 363
('26', 362, 1, 2, 878038) Q. After your conviction, if Government resort to rigorous repressive measures can any district or tahsil embark upon mass civil disobedience?
('26', 362, 2, 3, 878181) A. Certainly not.
('26', 362, 2, 4, 878199) It is my emphatic advice that, whatever repressive measures Government may adopt, the people should in no circumstances indulge in any movement of mass civil disobedience.
('26', 362, 3, 5, 878371) Q. What should be the next move of the nation now?
('26', 362, 4, 6, 878422) A. The first and foremost duty of the nation is to keep perfect non violence.
('26', 362, 4, 7, 878500) Mutual ill will and feelings of hatred among the different sections of people have taken such a strong root that constant effort to eradicate them is absolutely essential and the non co operators should take the lead, because their number is considerable.
('26', 362, 4, 8, 878756) There is a considerable lack of toleration, courtesy and forbearance amongst non co operators and it is my firm belief that that is the sole reason why our victory is delayed, and I regard the charkha as the most potent weapon to secure the required peace, courtesy, etc.
('26', 362, 4, 9, 879028) Hence I would only advise that the people should become immediately occupied with the charkha and khaddar prepared therefrom.
('26', 362, 4, 10, 879154) No sooner could we effect a complete boycott of foreign cloth and the use of hand spun and hand woven khaddar than swaraj is in hand and in consequence whereof the doors of the jail would be automatically laid open and my companions and myself would be able to be out.
('26', 362, 4, 11, 879423) I anxiously await such an auspicious occasion.
('26', 362, 5, 12, 879470) Q. What is your opinion in regard to the remarks made by Sir William Vin cent 1 against the Ali Brothers?
('26', 362, 6, 13, 879576) A There is nothing new in it.
('26', 362, 6, 14, 879606) The Brothers have given out in the clearest terms what they believed to be true.
('26', 362, 6, 15, 879687) This is considered to be their greatest fault and I too am committing similar faults.
('26', 362, 6, 16, 879773) For the same reason I regard them both as my real brothers.
('26', 362, 7, 17, 879833) Q. Will India suffer any harm in consequence of Mr. Montagu’s resignation?
('26', 362, 8, 18, 879908) I certainly do not believe that there will be any harm.
('26', 362, 8, 19, 879964) But Mr. Montagu certainly deserves credit for what he has done.
('26', 362, 9, 20, 880028) Q. Is there any logical connection between the political conditions of England and India at present?
('26', 362, 10, 21, 880129) A. There certainly is such a connection.
('26', 362, 10, 22, 880170) If the programme whi ch I have laid down for India is carried through, it will produce a very salutary effect not only on the political situation of England but on
('26', 362, 11, 23, 880334) 1 Member, Viceroy’s Executive Council
('26', 363, 0, 1, 880372) 364 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('26', 363, 1, 2, 880414) that of the whole world.
('26', 363, 2, 3, 880439) Q. What do you think of the coming Paris Conference?
('26', 363, 3, 4, 880492) A. At present, I have no high expectations from that, as it is my firm belief that, as long as India does not show completely the miracle of the charkha, the problem of Khilafat will not be properly solved.
('26', 363, 4, 5, 880699) Q. What are your instructions regarding the harmonious relations between the mill hands and the capitalists of the place, in your absence?
('26', 363, 5, 6, 880838) A. Repose full confidence in Anasuyabehn 1.
('26', 363, 6, 7, 880882) Q. What message do you send to the people of Ahmedabad?
('26', 363, 7, 8, 880938) A. The people of Ahmedabad should take to khaddar, preserve perfect unity and support the current movement.

('26', 363, 9, 10, 881078) 159. LETTER TO JAMNALAL BAJAJ
('26', 363, 10, 11, 881108) [SABARMATI JAIL,] Thursday Night [March 16, 1922] 2
('26', 363, 11, 12, 881160) JAMNALAL 3, As I proceed in my quest for Truth, it grows upon me that Truth comprehends everything.
('26', 363, 11, 13, 881260) I often feel that ahimsa is in Truth, not vice versa.
('26', 363, 11, 14, 881314) What is perceived by a pure heart at a particular moment is Truth to it for that moment.
('26', 363, 11, 15, 881403) By clinging to it, one can attain pure Truth.
('26', 363, 11, 16, 881449) And I do not imagine that this will lead us into any moral dilemma.
('26', 363, 11, 17, 881517) But often enough, it is difficult to decide what is ahimsa.
('26', 363, 11, 18, 881577) Even the use of disinfectants is himsa.
('26', 363, 11, 19, 881617) Still we have to live a life of ahimsa in the midst of a world full of himsa, and we can do so only if we cling to Truth.
('26', 363, 11, 20, 881739) That is why I can derive ahimsa from truth.
('26', 363, 11, 21, 881783) Out of Truth emerge love and tenderness.
('26', 363, 11, 22, 881824) A votary of Truth, one who would scrupulously cling to Truth, must be utterly humble.
('26', 363, 11, 23, 881910) His humility should increase with his observance of Truth.
('26', 363, 11, 24, 881969) I see the truth of this every moment of my life.
('26', 363, 11, 25, 882018) I have now a more vivid sense of Truth and of my own littleness than I had a year ago.

('26', 370, 5, 14, 894858) 166. INTERVIEW TO “MANCHESTER GUARDIAN”
('26', 370, 6, 15, 894898) SABARMATI JAIL, [Before March 18, 1922] 2
('26', 370, 7, 16, 894940) We came to the subject of non co operation.
('26', 370, 7, 17, 894984) I asked him ifin view of the answer Christ gave in the incident of the tribute moneyhe did not think the policy of non co operation was contrary to Christ’s teaching.

('26', 380, 2, 16, 922861) STATEMENT I owe it perhaps to the Indian public and to the public in England, to placate which this prosecution is mainly taken up, that I should explain why, from a staunch loyalist and co operator, I have become an uncompromising disaffectionist and non co operator, To the Court, too, I should say why I plead guilty to the charge of promoting disaffection towards the Government established by law in India.
('26', 380, 2, 17, 923273) My public life began in 1893 in South Africa in troubled weather.
('26', 380, 2, 18, 923339) My first contact with British authority in that country was not of a happy character.

('26', 381, 1, 10, 925115) In all these efforts at service, I was actuated by the belief that it was possible by such services to gain a status of full equality in the Empire for my countrymen.
('26', 381, 1, 11, 925282) The first shock came in the shape of the Rowlatt Act, a law designed to rob the people of all real freedom.

('26', 381, 1, 14, 925625) I discovered, too, that the plighted word of the Prime Minister to the Mussalmans of India regarding the integrity of Turkey and the holy places of Islam was not likely to be fulfilled.
('26', 381, 1, 15, 925811) But, in spite of the forebodings and the grave warnings of friends, at the Amritsar Congress in 1919, 7 I fought for co operation and working the Montagu Chelmsford reforms, hoping that the Prime Minister would redeem his promise to the Indian Mussalmans, that the Punjab wound would be healed and that the reforms, inadequate and unsatisfactory though they were, marked a new era of hope in the life of India.
('26', 381, 1, 16, 926222) But all that hope was shattered.

('26', 382, 1, 3, 926867) I saw, too, that not only did the reforms not mark a change of heart, but they were only a method of further draining India of her wealth and of prolonging her servitude.
('26', 382, 1, 4, 927038) I came reluctantly to the conclusion that the British connection had made India more helpless than she ever was before, politically and economically.
('26', 382, 1, 5, 927188) A disarmed India has no power of resistance against any aggressor if she wanted to engage in an armed conflict with him.
('26', 382, 1, 6, 927309) So much is this the case that some of our best men consider that India must take generations before she can achieve the Dominion status.
('26', 382, 1, 7, 927446) She has become so poor that she has little power of resisting famines.
('26', 382, 1, 8, 927517) Before the British advent, India spun and wove in her millions of cottages just the supplement she needed for adding to her meagre agricultural resources.
('26', 382, 1, 9, 927672) This cottage industry, so vital for India’s existence, has been ruined by incredibly heartless and inhuman processes as described by English witnesses.
('26', 382, 1, 10, 927824) Little do town dwellers know how the semi starved masses of India are slowly sinking to lifelessness.
('26', 382, 1, 11, 927926) Little do they know that their miserable comfort represents the brokerage they get for the work they do for the foreign exploiter, that the profits and the brokerage are sucked from the masses.
('26', 382, 1, 12, 928120) Little do they realize that the Government established by law in British India is carried on for this exploitation of the masses.
('26', 382, 1, 13, 928250) No sophistry, no jugglery in figures can explain away the evidence that the skeletons in many villages present to the naked eye.
('26', 382, 1, 14, 928379) I have no doubt whatsoever that both England and the town dwellers of India will have to answer, if there is a God above, for this crime against humanity which is perhaps unequalled in history.
('26', 382, 1, 15, 928573) The law itself in this country has been used to serve the foreign exploiter.

('26', 382, 1, 17, 928945) Their crime consisted in the love of their country.
('26', 382, 1, 18, 928997) In ninety nine cases out of hundred, justice has been denied to Indians as against Europeans in the Courts of India.
('26', 382, 1, 19, 929114) This is not an exaggerated picture.
('26', 382, 1, 20, 929150) It is the experience of almost every Indian who has had anything to do with such cases.

('26', 383, 1, 3, 929626) I am satisfied that many English and Indian officials honestly believe that they are administering one of the best systems devised in the world and that India is making steady though slow progress.
('26', 383, 1, 4, 929824) They do not know that a subtle but effective system of terrorism and an organized display of force on the one hand, and the deprivation of all powers of retaliation or self defence on the other, have emasculated the people and induced in them the habit of simulation.

('26', 383, 1, 6, 930182) Section 124 A under which I am happily charged is perhaps the prince among the political sections of the Indian Penal Code designed to suppress the liberty of the citizen.
('26', 383, 1, 7, 930354) Affection cannot be manufactured or regulated by law.
('26', 383, 1, 8, 930408) If one has no affection for a person or system 1, one should be free to give the fullest expression to his disaffection, so long as he does not contemplate, promote or incite to violence.
('26', 383, 1, 9, 930596) But the section under which Mr. Banker and I are charged is one under which mere promotion of disaffection is a crime.
('26', 383, 1, 10, 930715) I have studied some of the cases tried under it, and I know that some of the most loved of India’s patriots have been convicted under it.
('26', 383, 1, 11, 930853) I consider it a privilege, therefore, to be charged under it.
('26', 383, 1, 12, 930915) I have endeavoured to give in their briefest outline the reasons for my disaffection.
('26', 383, 1, 13, 931001) I have no personal ill will against any single administrator, much less can I have any disaffection towards the King’s person.
('26', 383, 1, 14, 931128) But I hold it to be a virtue to be disaffected towards a Government which in its totality has done more harm to India than any previous system.
('26', 383, 1, 15, 931272) India is less manly under the British rule than she ever was before.
('26', 383, 1, 16, 931341) Holding such a belief, I consider it to be a sin to have affection for the system.
('26', 383, 1, 17, 931424) And it has been a precious privilege for me to be able to write what I have in the various articles tendered in evidence against me.
('26', 383, 1, 18, 931557) In fact, I believe that I have rendered a service to India and England by showing in non co operation the way out of the unnatural state in which both are living.
('26', 383, 1, 19, 931720) In my humble opinion, non co operation with evil is as much a duty as is co operation with good.
('26', 383, 1, 20, 931817) But, in the past, non co operation has been deliberately expressed in violence to the evil doer.
('26', 383, 1, 21, 931914) I am endeavouring to show to my countrymen that violent non co operation only multiplies evil and that, as evil can only be sustained by violence, withdrawal of support of evil requires complete abstention from violence.
('26', 383, 1, 22, 932135) Non violence implies voluntary submission to the penalty for non co operation with evil.

('26', 388, 1, 2, 941696) I certainly intend to write about Hinduism.
('26', 388, 2, 3, 941740) MOHANDAS GANDHI [PS.] I think it would be better not to give my name as the author of this primer.
('26', 388, 3, 4, 941839) FOREWORD This primer presupposes that the pupil has already spent a year or less in spinning, learning the letters of the alphabet, both Devana gari and Prakrit, and simple tables.
('26', 388, 3, 5, 942020) I have used in the primer the words laghushanka 3 and apaman 4 because I could not avoid them.
('26', 388, 3, 6, 942115) I have used the word laghushanka in place of peshab, thinking that it would be good if children learnt this fine word.
('26', 388, 3, 7, 942234) Apaman has been kept, as milder word could not be found.
('26', 388, 3, 8, 942291) The difficult words in Lesson 12 have been deliberately introduced.
('26', 388, 3, 9, 942359) The aim which has been kept in view in preparing this primer is that the pupil should be able to put into practice whatever he learns.
('26', 388, 3, 10, 942494) Nothing has been included which is not within the range of his daily experience.
('26', 388, 3, 11, 942575) The presentation of the lessons in this primer in the form of dialogue between a mother and her child has a touch of artificiality about it, as most Indian mothers today do not perform their duty of instructing children, nor are they equipped for the task.
('26', 388, 3, 12, 942832) This artificiality has been introduced to set forth an ideal, in the hope that now some mothers at any rate will do their duty towards their children.
('26', 388, 3, 13, 942983) I believe that the primer can be completed in three to six months.
('26', 388, 3, 14, 943050) Teachers should make the child write out every lesson in an attractive hand.
('26', 388, 3, 15, 943127) The lessons have been planned to serve as a basis for the teacher, who may elaborate them further as his zeal and enthusiasm may inspire him to do.

('26', 393, 4, 5, 951880) 173. LETTER TO HAKIM AJMAL KHAN 1
('26', 393, 5, 6, 951914) YERAVDA JAIL, April 14, 1922
('26', 393, 6, 7, 951943) DEAR HAKIMJI, Prisoners are allowed one visit every three months and to write and receive one letter during the same period.
('26', 393, 6, 8, 952068) I have had a visit from Devdas and Rajagopalachari.
('26', 393, 6, 9, 952120) And I am now writing the permitted letter.
('26', 393, 6, 10, 952163) You will remember that Mr. Banker and I were convicted on the 18th March on a Saturday.
('26', 393, 6, 11, 952251) On Monday night about 10 p.m.
('26', 393, 6, 12, 952281) we received notice that we were to be removed to an unknown destination.
('26', 393, 6, 13, 952354) At 11.30 p.m.
('26', 393, 6, 14, 952368) the Superintendent of Police took us to the special that was awaiting us at Sabarmati.
('26', 393, 6, 15, 952455) We were given a basket of fruit for the journey and we were well looked after during the whole journey.
('26', 393, 6, 16, 952559) The doctor of the Sabarmati Jail had allowed me, for health and religious reasons, the food to which I am used, and to Mr. Banker bread and milk and fruit for medical reasons.
('26', 393, 6, 17, 952735) Cow’s milk for Mr. Banker and goat’s for me were, therefore, ordered on the way by Deputy Superintendent who was escorting us.
('26', 393, 6, 18, 952862) We were taken off at Khirki where a prison van was waiting to take us to the jail from where I am writing this.
('26', 393, 6, 19, 952974) I had heard bad accounts of this Jail from ex prisoners and was therefore prepared to face difficulties in my path.
('26', 393, 6, 20, 953090) I had told Mr. Banker that if my hand spinning was stopped, I would have to refuse food as I had taken a vow on the Hindu New Year’s Day to spin every day at least for half an hour except when I was ill or traveling.
('26', 393, 6, 21, 953307) He should not, therefore, I told him, be shocked if I had to refuse food and that he should on no account join me out of false sympathy.
('26', 393, 6, 22, 953444) He had seen my view point.
('26', 393, 6, 23, 953471) We were not, therefore, surprised when, on reaching the Jail about 5.30 p.m., I was told by the Superintendent that he could not allow the spinning wheel which was with us nor could we be allowed to take the fruit that was with us.
('26', 393, 6, 24, 953703) I pointed out that hand spinning was

('26', 394, 1, 2, 953859) a matter of vow with me and that, as a matter of fact, both of us were permitted to do it everyday at the Sabarmati jail.
('26', 394, 1, 3, 953981) Thereupon we were told, Yeroda was not Sabarmati.
('26', 394, 1, 4, 954031) I told the Superintendent too that both of us were permitted at the Sabarmati jail for health reasons to sleep outside, but that was not to be expected at this Jail.

('26', 394, 1, 11, 954486) I am a seasoned jail bird.
('26', 394, 1, 12, 954513) The superintendent came the next morning to question us.
('26', 394, 1, 13, 954570) I saw that the first impression did not do justice to the Superintendent.
('26', 394, 1, 14, 954644) The previous evening he was evidently in a hurry.
('26', 394, 1, 15, 954694) We were received after the regular time and he was totally unprepared for what was undoubtedly to him a strange request.
('26', 394, 1, 16, 954815) He discovered, however, that my request for the spinning wheel was not a matter of cussedness, but rightly or wrongly a real religious necessity.
('26', 394, 1, 17, 954961) He saw too that it was no question of hunger striking.

('26', 394, 1, 20, 955160) And so far as I have been able to observe, the animal comforts are well looked after in this Jail.
('26', 394, 1, 21, 955259) Both the Superintendent and the Jailor appear to me to be tactful and have pleasant manners.
('26', 394, 1, 22, 955352) The first day’s experience I count as of no consequence.
('26', 394, 1, 23, 955409) The relations between the Superintendent and the Jailor and myself are as cordial as they can be between a prisoner and his keepers.
('26', 394, 1, 24, 955542) But it is evident to me that the human element is largely, if not entirely, absent in the jail system.
('26', 394, 1, 25, 955645) The Superintendent informs me that all prisoners are treated as I am treated.
('26', 394, 1, 26, 955723) If that is so, as animals prisoners could hardly be better cared for.
('26', 394, 1, 27, 955793) But, for the human sentiment, there is no accommodation in the Jail Regulations.
('26', 394, 1, 28, 955874) This is what the Jail Committee consisting of the Collector, a clergyman and some others did the next morning.
('26', 394, 1, 29, 955985) This Committee met quite by coincidence the very next day after our admission.
('26', 394, 1, 30, 956064) The members came to find our needs.
('26', 394, 1, 31, 956100) I mentioned that Mr. Banker suffered from nervousness and that he should be kept with me and that his cell should be kept open.

('26', 394, 1, 34, 956411) They knew nothing of Mr. Banker’s past or his position in life or of his upbringing.

('26', 395, 1, 2, 956568) to find all this out and to discover the cause for what appeared to me to be the most natural request.

('26', 395, 1, 4, 956790) Within one hour after the interview, a warder came ordering Mr. Banker to be removed to another quarter.
('26', 395, 1, 5, 956895) I felt like a mother suddenly deprived of her only child.

('26', 395, 1, 9, 957339) Mr. Banker lost his mother only a few months ago.
('26', 395, 1, 10, 957389) When I met her a few days before her death, she said she would die in peace as her son should be quite safe under my care.
('26', 395, 1, 11, 957512) Little did the noble lady know how utterly powerless I would prove to protect her son in the hour of his need.

('26', 395, 1, 15, 957988) I am trying to coax the Inspector General and the Superin tendent to let me read the Gita with Mr. Banker during the few minutes he is allowed to come.
('26', 395, 1, 16, 958140) This request is under consideration.
('26', 395, 1, 17, 958177) In fairness to the authorities, I must mention that Mr. Banker’s animal comforts are well looked after and that he is looking not bad at all.
('26', 395, 1, 18, 958319) He is gradually losing his nervousness.

('26', 395, 1, 20, 958707) I was given the option of presenting the said seven books to the Jail library and then using them.
('26', 395, 1, 21, 958806) Whilst I was prepared to do so with my other books, I gently told the Superintendent that to ask me to present religious books which I was using or gifts with a history was like asking me to give up my right arm.

('26', 400, 4, 13, 970693) 174. LETTER TO GOVERNMENT OF BOMBAY
('26', 400, 5, 14, 970729) YERAVDA JAIL, May 12, 1922 FROM PRISONER NO.
('26', 400, 5, 15, 970774) 8677 TO THE GOVERNMENT OF BOMBAY With reference to the Government orders passed on Prisoner’s letter to Hakimji Ajmal Khan, a friend of Prisoner’s, and returning said letter to Prisoner with certain remarks in the said orders read out to Prisoner by the Superintendent of Yeroda Jail, Prisoner No.
('26', 400, 5, 16, 971072) 8677 begs to say that on application to the Superintendent for a copy of the said orders, he says he has no authority to give Prisoner a copy thereof.
('26', 400, 5, 17, 971223) Prisoner would like to possess a copy of the said orders and send one to friends so that they may know under what circumstances Prisoner has been unable to send to friends a letter of welfare.
('26', 400, 5, 18, 971416) Prisoner hereby applies for instructions to the Superintendent to give him a copy of the said orders.
('26', 400, 5, 19, 971518) Regarding the orders, so far as Prisoner recollects and under stands them, the Government base their refusal to send Prisoner’s letter to its destination on the ground that (i) the letter contains reference to prisoners other than Prisoner himself, and (ii) the letter is likely to give rise to political controversy.
('26', 400, 5, 20, 971836) With regard to the first ground, Prisoner submits that the letter contains no references that are not strictly relevant to Prisoner’s own
('26', 401, 0, 1, 971974) 402 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('26', 401, 1, 2, 972016) personal condition and welfare.
('26', 401, 1, 3, 972048) With regard to the second ground, Prisoner respectfully con tends that the possibility of a public controversy cannot be a valid ground to deprive a prisoner of the right of sending a quarterly letter of welfare to friends and relatives.
('26', 401, 1, 4, 972286) The implication of the ground is, in Prisoner’s opinion, dangerous in the extreme, it being that an Indian prison is a secret department.
('26', 401, 1, 5, 972424) Prisoner contends that Indian prisons are an open public department subject to criticism by the public in the same manner as any other department.
('26', 401, 1, 6, 972571) Prisoner contends that his said letter is strictly one containing information regarding his personal welfare.
('26', 401, 1, 7, 972681) References to other prisoners were necessary to complete the information.
('26', 401, 1, 8, 972755) Prisoner would gladly correct mis statements or exaggeration if any be discovered to him.
('26', 401, 1, 9, 972845) But to send the letter in the mutilated manner suggested by the Government would be to give an erroneous idea of his condition to his friends.
('26', 401, 1, 10, 972988) Unless, therefore, the Government will forward Prisoner’s letter subject to such correction that may be found necessary, Prisoner has no desire to exercise the right of sending to friends a letter of welfare, which right becomes of doubtful value under the restrictions imposed by the Government under the said orders.
('26', 401, 1, 11, 973307) M. K. GANDHI PRISONER NO.
('26', 401, 2, 12, 973333) From a handwritten copy: S. N. 8013; also Young India, 28 2 1924

('26', 402, 3, 7, 974657) 176. LETTER TO JAIL SUPERINTENDENT, YERAVDA
('26', 402, 4, 8, 974701) YERAVDA JAIL, August 12, 1922 TO THE SUPERINTENDENT YERAVDA CENTRAL JAIL
('26', 402, 5, 9, 974774) SIR, There are regarding myself three matters pending for some time.
('26', 402, 5, 10, 974843) (1) In May last, I wrote to my friend Hakimji Ajmal Khan of Delhi the usual quarterly letter.
('26', 402, 5, 11, 974937) The Government declined to forward it unless I cut out portions objected to by them.
('26', 402, 5, 12, 975022) As I considered the portions strictly relevant to my condition in the Jail, I could not see my way to remove them and I respectfully notified to the Government that I did not propose to avail myself of the privilege or the right of sending to my friend the usual letter unless I could give him a full description of my condition.
('26', 402, 5, 13, 975352) At the same time, I wrote a brief letter to my friend saying that the letter I had written to him was disallowed and that I did not propose to write any letter regarding my welfare unless the Government removed the restrictions imposed by them.
('26', 402, 5, 14, 975597) This second letter, too, the Government have declined to send.
('26', 402, 5, 15, 975660) It is this second letter which I have asked should be returned to me as the first has been.
('26', 402, 5, 16, 975752) (2) After having received permission from Col.
('26', 402, 5, 17, 975799) Dalziel to write a
('26', 403, 0, 1, 975818) 404 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('26', 403, 1, 2, 975860) vernacular primer 1 and the assurance that there would be no objection to my sending it to my friends for publication, I wrote the primer and gave it to Col.
('26', 403, 1, 3, 976018) Dalziel for dispatch to the address mentioned in the covering letter.
('26', 403, 1, 4, 976088) The Government have declined to send the primer to the address given, on the ground that prisoners cannot be permitted to publish books whilst they are serving their term.
('26', 403, 1, 5, 976260) I have no wish to see my name on the primer as publisher or author.
('26', 403, 1, 6, 976328) If the primer may not be published even without my name being connected with it in any way, I would like it returned to me.
('26', 403, 1, 7, 976452) (3) The Government were pleased to notify that I could be allowed periodicals.
('26', 403, 1, 8, 976531) I therefore asked for permission to send for The Times of India weekly, the Modern Reviewa high class Calcutta monthly, and the Saraswatia Hindi magazine.
('26', 403, 1, 9, 976688) The last named has been kindly allowed.
('26', 403, 1, 10, 976728) No decision has yet been received regarding the other two.
('26', 403, 1, 11, 976787) I am anxiously awaiting the Government decision about them.

('26', 403, 3, 15, 977050) In expressing my opinion about Ramdas’s intended marriage, I was hasty and yielded to blind affectionI repented after we parted and saw how one who considered himself to be a careful man could become thoughtless and blinded by affection.

('26', 404, 1, 12, 978839) Parents ought not for their own selves impede the progress or thwart the wishes of their children.

('26', 404, 1, 25, 979696) He who is altogether free from impure thoughts has attained salvation.

('26', 404, 1, 27, 979836) There is only one remedy for attaining the end: To match pure against impure thoughts.

('26', 406, 1, 2, 981979) 179. LETTER TO JAIL SUPERINTENDENT, YERAVDA
('26', 406, 2, 3, 982023) YERAVDA JAIL, December 20, 1922 THE SUPERINTENDENT YERAVDA CENTRAL JAIL
('26', 406, 3, 4, 982095) SIR, You were good enough to tell me that of those who had recently applied for permission to see me, Pandit Motilal Nehru and Hakim Ajmal Khan and Mr. Maganlal Gandhi were refused permis sion to see me.
('26', 406, 3, 5, 982299) Mr. Maganlal Gandhi is a very near relative of mine, holds my power of attorney and is in charge of my agricultural and hand weaving and hand spinning experiments and is in close touch with my work among the depressed classes.
('26', 406, 3, 6, 982526) Panditji and Hakimji are, besides being political co workers, personal friends interested in my well being.
('26', 406, 3, 7, 982634) I shall be obliged if you will kindly ascertain from the Government the reasons for the refusal to Pandit Motilal Nehru, Hakimji Ajmal Khan and Mr. Maganlal Gandhi.
('26', 406, 3, 8, 982799) I observe that under the prison regulations governing interviews with prisoners, all the three gentlemen named above appear to be eligible as visitors to their prisoner friends.
('26', 406, 3, 9, 982977) I would like, too to know, if I may, what the Government’s wishes are regarding interviews with me; whom I may and may not see and whether I may receive information from the permitted visitors on non political topics or activities with which I am connected.
('26', 406, 4, 10, 983235) I remain, Yours obediently, M. K. GANDHI
('26', 406, 5, 11, 983276) From a photostat: S. N. 8016; also Young India, 6 3 1924
('26', 407, 0, 1, 983333) 408 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('26', 407, 1, 2, 983375) 180. LETTER TO JAIL SUPERINTENDENT, YERAVDA
('26', 407, 2, 3, 983419) YERAVDA JAIL, December 20, 1922 THE SUPERINTENDENT YERAVDA CENTRAL JAIL
('26', 407, 3, 4, 983491) SIR, You have been good enough to tell me that the Inspector General has without reasons refused to sanction the use by me of two Gujarati monthlies, namely, Vasant and Samalochak.
('26', 407, 3, 5, 983672) In view of the orders of the Government about the use of periodicals by prisoners, the foregoing decision is a surprise to me.
('26', 407, 3, 6, 983799) The Government orders, as I have understood them, are that prisoners may have periodicals which do not contain current political news.
('26', 407, 3, 7, 983934) I am not very conversant with the Samalochak, but I am with the Vasant.
('26', 407, 3, 8, 984006) It is the standard Gujarati literary monthly edited by Rao Bahadur Ramanbhai, well known as a social reformer, and contri buted to mainly by those who are in some way or other connected with the Government.
('26', 407, 3, 9, 984213) I have not known it to treat political questions as such, nor have I ever known it to contain political news.
('26', 407, 3, 10, 984323) But it may be that the Inspector General has other reasons for disallowing the periodicals or that both the Vasant and the Samalochak have now become political magazines.
('26', 407, 3, 11, 984494) Will you kindly, therefore, ascertain from the Inspector General the reasons for his decision?
('26', 407, 3, 12, 984589) I may add that if the decision is not altered, it will deprive me of the opportunity of keeping myself in touch with Gujarati literature.
('26', 407, 4, 13, 984727) I remain, Yours obediently, M. K. GANDHI

('26', 408, 7, 9, 985379) 1 In Gandhiji’s own hand, in Gujarati, the Diary is for the most part a factual record of his life as an inmate of the Yeravda Central Jail during the period March 1922 January 1924. The original is a note book, half foolscap in size, with the dates, days, etc, written by Gandhiji in pencil or ink.
('26', 408, 7, 10, 985679) It does not give all the days in a consecutive order, there being frequent omissions.
('26', 408, 7, 11, 985765) The titles of books read by Gandhiji, given by him in Gujarati script, have been generally checked with information available in Young India and elsewhere.
('26', 408, 7, 12, 985921) The original carried a list, in Gandhiji’s hand, of titles of books in English and in Indian languages evidently read by him in jail, and this is furnished as an appendix to the “Jail Diary, 1923,” which is given in this volume, as the last item for that year.
('26', 408, 7, 13, 986182) 2 Some of the entries in the Diary contain, besides the dates to the Gregorian calendar, the corresponding dates of the Vikram era.
('26', 408, 7, 14, 986314) Only the former are reproduced here.
('26', 408, 7, 15, 986351) 3 Gandhiji was taken to the Yeravda Central Jail on March 21, 1922. During the period of his imprisonment there he read, in all, about 150 books on religion, literature, social and natural sciences.
('26', 408, 7, 16, 986550) In the series, My Jail Experiences, which appeared in Young India from April 1924, Gandhiji offered detailed comments on some of these books.

('26', 417, 11, 22, 999918) He must be prepared to treat prison as his home, if he values his country’s liberty above everything else.
('26', 417, 11, 23, 1000025) He added that if he ever fell ill, it would not be because of any lack of
