('26', 418, 2, 5, 1000733) 183. LETTER TO JAIL SUPERINTENDENT, YERAVDA
('26', 418, 3, 6, 1000777) YERAVDA CENTRAL PRISON, February 4, 1923 THE SUPERINTENDENT YERAVDA CENTRAL PRISON,
('26', 418, 4, 7, 1000861) SIR, You were good enough to tell me yesterday that the Inspector General had replied to my letter of the 20th December last to the effect that you had full discretion regarding interviews by relatives and friends with me in terms of the prison regulations governing such interviews.
('26', 418, 4, 8, 1001145) This reply has come upon me as a surprise and is at variance with the information given me by my wife, who, together with Mrs. Vasumati Dhimatram, was permitted to see me on the 27th ultimo.
('26', 418, 4, 9, 1001336) My wife told me that she had to wait for over twenty days before receiving reply to her application for interview.
('26', 418, 4, 10, 1001451) On hearing rumours of my illness she came to Poona in the hope of being admitted to see me.
('26', 418, 4, 11, 1001543) Consequently, early last week, accompanied by Mrs. Vasumati Dhimatram, Mr. Maganlal Gandhi, Radhahis daughter about fourteen years old, and Prabhudas, a lad about eighteen years, old, Mr. Chhaganlal Gandhi’s son, who had come in the place of his father who was ailing and who was one of the applicants, my wife applied at the prison gate for admission.
('26', 418, 4, 12, 1001897) You told the party that you could not admit them as you had no authority to grant permission and that you were awaiting reply from the Government to whom the original application was sent by you.
('26', 418, 4, 13, 1002093) On Mr. Maganlal Gandhi’s pressing, you undertook to telephone to the Inspector General who, too, it seems could not grant the proposed interview and my wife and party had to go away disappointed.
('26', 418, 4, 14, 1002289) On the 27th ultimo, my wife told me you telephoned to her saying that you had heard from the Government that she and three others who were named in her original application could see me.
('26', 418, 4, 15, 1002476) This therefore excluded youngsters Radha and Prabhudas.
('26', 418, 4, 16, 1002532) If you had the discretion retained to you, the whole of the circumstances narrated above need revision.
('26', 418, 4, 17, 1002636) I feel sure that I have not misunderstood my wife.
('26', 419, 0, 1, 1002687) 420 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('26', 419, 1, 2, 1002729) Moreover, if your discretion had been retained, Radha and Prabhudas could not have been excluded.
('26', 419, 1, 3, 1002827) I shall therefore be obliged if you will enlighten me on the discrepancy between the Government reply and my wife’s version, and inform me further: (1) On what grounds Pandit Motilal Nehru, and Hakim Ajmal Khan and Mr. Maganlal Gandhi were excluded last year.
('26', 419, 1, 4, 1003087) (2) Who will and who will not be allowed to see me in future.
('26', 419, 1, 5, 1003149) (3) Whether, at these interviews, I may receive information on non political matters and activities initiated and now being conducted by my various representatives.
('26', 419, 1, 6, 1003314) Though I will not permit myself to believe that any humiliation was intended, I venture to think that the treatment received by them was in fact humiliating.
('26', 419, 1, 7, 1003472) I should not like a repetition of the unfor tunate occurrence
('26', 419, 2, 8, 1003534) I remain, Yours obediently,
('26', 419, 3, 9, 1003562) From a photostat: S. N. 8018; also Young India, 6 3 1924
('26', 419, 4, 10, 1003619) 184. LETTER TO MAJOR W. JONES
('26', 419, 5, 11, 1003649) February 10 [1923]
('26', 419, 6, 12, 1003668) DEAR MAJOR JONES, This is a personal letter because it embraces sentiment and travels beyond my province as a prisoner.
('26', 419, 6, 13, 1003788) At the same time, if your official position demands that you cannot help taking official notice of it, of course you are at liberty to do so.
('26', 419, 6, 14, 1003930) Yesterday morning I heard screaming and some of the men about shouted out: “There goes flogging.” 1 I wondered.
('26', 419, 6, 15, 1004042) A short while after, I saw four or five young men in gunny clothing being marched.
('26', 419, 6, 16, 1004125) One had a bare back.
('26', 419, 6, 17, 1004146) They were all walking very slowly and with bent backs.
('26', 419, 6, 18, 1004201) I observed that they were in pain.
('26', 419, 6, 19, 1004236) They bowed to me.
('26', 419, 6, 20, 1004254) I returned the bow.
('26', 419, 6, 21, 1004274) I concluded that they must have been flogged.
('26', 419, 6, 22, 1004320) During the day I saw a respectable man in irons and gunny clothing pass by.
('26', 419, 6, 23, 1004396) He too bowed.
('26', 419, 6, 24, 1004410) Contrary to my custom, I asked him who he was.
('26', 419, 6, 25, 1004457) He told me he was a Mulshi Peta man.
('26', 419, 6, 26, 1004494) I asked him whether he knew the flogged men.
('26', 419, 6, 27, 1004539) He said he knew them all, as they were also Mulshi Peta men.
('26', 419, 7, 28, 1004600) 1 Shankerlal Banker’s detailed statement on prison treatment, which was published in Young India, 19 4 1923, refers to this incident.
('26', 420, 0, 1, 1004734) VOL. 26 : 24 JANUARY, 1922 12 NOVEMBER, 1923 421
('26', 420, 1, 2, 1004783) The object in writing this is to know whether I could be permitted to see these men who are refusing to work 1. If I find them to be acting foolishly or thoughtlessly, I might be able to persuade them to reconsider their position.
('26', 420, 1, 3, 1005014) Satyagraha requires a prisoner to obey all reasonable prison regulations, and certainly to do the work given.
('26', 420, 1, 4, 1005124) In fact, his resistance ceases once a satyagrahi is in prison.
('26', 420, 1, 5, 1005187) It can be revived for extraordinary reasons, e.g., studied humiliation.
('26', 420, 1, 6, 1005259) If these men claim to be satyagrahis, I should like to explain all this to them.
('26', 420, 1, 7, 1005340) I know that a prisoner cannot ordinarily be permitted to assist or intervene in prison administration.
('26', 420, 1, 8, 1005443) My only ground for expecting response to my suggestion is that of common humanity.
('26', 420, 1, 9, 1005526) You, I am sure, will want to leave no stone unturned to avoid flogging, if it is at all possible.
('26', 420, 1, 10, 1005624) I have suggested a possibility in all humility.
('26', 420, 1, 11, 1005672) I wish you would and could be permitted to avail yourself of my offer.
('26', 420, 2, 12, 1005743) Yours sincerely,
('26', 420, 3, 13, 1005760) M. K. GANDHI

('26', 421, 4, 9, 1007739) 186. LETTER TO JAIL SUPERINTENDENT, YERAVDA:
('26', 421, 5, 10, 1007784) YERAVDA CENTRAL JAIL, February 12, 1923 THE SUPERINTENDENT YERAVDA CENTRAL JAIL
('26', 421, 6, 11, 1007864) SIR, I observe that some Mulshi Peta prisoners have been flogged, as they are said to have refused to work and to have wilfully done short task.
('26', 421, 6, 12, 1008009) If these prisoners claim to be satyagrahis, they are bound to obey all prison regulations so long as they are not humiliating or unreasonable, and certainly to the best of their capacity do the tasks allotted to them.
('26', 421, 6, 13, 1008227) If, therefore, they have refused to work or do not work according to their physical capacity, they are committing a
('26', 421, 7, 14, 1008343) 1 While reproducing the letter in Young India, 6 3 1924, Gandhiji added the following note: “The Superintendent, in reply to the foregoing, came to my cell and said that he harboured no anger against Mr. Jeramdas.
('26', 421, 7, 15, 1008557) Whatever he (Mr. Jeramdas) did was done openly, but he was bound to take some notice of the breach of regulations.
('26', 421, 7, 16, 1008672) He could not punish me for instigation.
('26', 421, 7, 17, 1008712) I had not left the boundary of my yard to talk to the satyagrahis and therefore he could not punish me.
('26', 421, 7, 18, 1008816) Owing to Mr. Jeramdas’s talk to the satyagrahis, an ugly situation was prevented.” About this episode, Jairamdas Doulatram says: “As a result of Gandhiji’s intervention through me, the Mulshi Peta prisoners respounded and carried out the task imposed on them.
('26', 421, 7, 19, 1009076) The authorities had intended to give them the punishment of whipping in case they persisted in their refusal.
('26', 421, 7, 20, 1009186) This would have led to other developments and, I believe, might have led to Gandhiji’s intervention in a much more active manner, leading to other consequences.”
('26', 422, 0, 1, 1009348) VOL. 26 : 24 JANUARY, 1922 12 NOVEMBER, 1923 423
('26', 422, 1, 2, 1009397) breach of their own canon of good conduct in addition to that of prison regulations.
('26', 422, 1, 3, 1009482) I am sure that the authorities do not desire to flog them, if they can be otherwise persuaded to work, and that they would wish prisoners to yield to reason rather than to fear of punishment.
('26', 422, 1, 4, 1009674) I fancy that the men will listen to me.
('26', 422, 1, 5, 1009714) I therefore, request that I may be permitted to meet in your presence all the Mulshi Peta men who wilfully break prison regulations, so that I may explain to them their duty as satyagrahis if they claim to be such.
('26', 422, 1, 6, 1009929) I am aware that it is not usual to permit prisoners to assist or intervene in matters of prison administration.
('26', 422, 1, 7, 1010041) But I imagine that considerations of humanity such as in the case mentioned will be allowed to supersede those of administrative custom.
('26', 422, 2, 8, 1010178) I remain, Yours obediently, M. K. GANDHI

('26', 422, 6, 12, 1010402) [SIR, ] You were kind enough to tell me today that you had heard from the Government in reply to my letter of the 4th instant, 2 and that the Government was sorry for the inconvenience that was caused to my wife and that, with reference to the other parts of my letter, the Government could not discuss with a prisoner the prison regulations in general.
('26', 422, 6, 13, 1010756) I appreciate the expression of sorrow about the incon venience caused to my wife.
('26', 422, 6, 14, 1010838) Regarding the other part of the Government reply, I beg to state that I am well aware of the fact that, as a prisoner, I may not discuss the prison regulations in general.
('26', 422, 6, 15, 1011010) If the government will reread my letter of the 4th instant, they will discover that I have not invited a general discussion of the regulations.
('26', 422, 6, 16, 1011154) On the contrary, I have merely
('26', 422, 7, 17, 1011185) 1 Gandhiji appended the following note later, while publishing the letter in Young India: “In reply, the Superintendent told me that whilst the Government than ked me for the offer, they could not avail themselves of it.” 2 Vide “ Letter to Jail Superintendent, Yeravda”, 4 2 1923.
('26', 423, 0, 1, 1011467) 424 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('26', 423, 1, 2, 1011509) ventured to seek information on the particular application of certain regulations in so far only as they bear on my future conduct and welfare.
('26', 423, 1, 3, 1011653) I presume that a prisoner is entitled to seek and receive such information.
('26', 423, 1, 4, 1011729) If I am to see my friends and wife in future, I ought to know whom I may or may not see, so as to avoid disappointment or even possible humiliation.
('26', 423, 1, 5, 1011878) I venture to make my position clear.
('26', 423, 1, 6, 1011915) I have the good fortune to have numerous friends who are as dear to me as relatives.
('26', 423, 1, 7, 1012000) I have children being brought up under me who are like my own children.
('26', 423, 1, 8, 1012072) I have associates living under the same roof with me, and helping me in my various non political activities and experiments.
('26', 423, 1, 9, 1012197) I could not, without doing violence to my most cherished sentiments, see my wife, if I may not from time to time also see these friends, associates and children.
('26', 423, 1, 10, 1012359) I see my wife not merely because she is my wife, but chiefly because she is my associate in my activities.
('26', 423, 1, 11, 1012466) Nor should I have any interest in seeing those I wish to, if I may not talk to them about my non political activities.
('26', 423, 1, 12, 1012585) Again, I am naturally interested in knowing why Pandit Motilal Nehru, Hakimji Ajmal Khan and Mr. Maganlal Gandhi were excluded.
('26', 423, 1, 13, 1012713) I should understand their exclusion if they were guilty of ungentlemanly conduct, or if they wanted to see me for any political discussion.
('26', 423, 1, 14, 1012853) But if they have been excluded for any unnamable political reasons, the least I could do is to waive the pleasure of seeing my wife.
('26', 423, 1, 15, 1012986) I entertain ideas of honour and self respect which I would like the Government, if they can, to understand and appreciate.
('26', 423, 1, 16, 1013109) I have no desire to hold political discussion with anybody, much less to send out political messages.
('26', 423, 1, 17, 1013211) The Government may post anyone they wish to be present at these interviews and their representative may take shorthand notes thereon if the Government deem it necessary.
('26', 423, 1, 18, 1013381) But I may be excused if I wish to guard against friends and relatives being refused permission for reasons outside the prison regulations.
('26', 423, 1, 19, 1013520) I have now stated my position frankly and fully.
('26', 423, 1, 20, 1013569) This correspondence commenced on the 20th December last.
('26', 423, 1, 21, 1013626) I would urge the Government to let me have an early, straight and undip lomatic reply.
('26', 423, 2, 22, 1013713) I remain Yours obediently, M. K. GANDHI No.

('26', 424, 3, 4, 1013989) SIR, You have kindly informed me that in reply to my letter of the 4th ultimo, the Inspector General says that the use of the two periodicals Vasant and Samalochak cannot be granted.

('26', 424, 8, 13, 1014912) THE SUPERINTENDENT YERAVDA CENTRAL JAIL
('26', 424, 10, 14, 1014952) You have kindly informed me that the Inspector General has replied to my letter of the 23rd ultimo saying that the decision about the Vasant and Samalochak was given by competent authority and that I was to be referred to the last paragraph of the Government’s letter regarding my inquiry about certain applications for interviews with me.
('26', 424, 10, 15, 1015292) I beg to tender my congratulations to the I.G. for the promptness of his reply, but greatly deplore the position adopted by
('26', 425, 0, 1, 1015416) 426 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('26', 425, 1, 2, 1015458) I.G.’s 1 competency to decide as to the periodicals was never questioned by me.
('26', 425, 1, 3, 1015538) And the paragraph of the Government’s letter referred to by him does not help me in the least.
('26', 425, 1, 4, 1015633) It says that you may not discuss with prisoners the prison regulations in general.

('26', 425, 1, 12, 1016565) Whilst he was Superintendent, he taught me to think that as Superintendent of a prison, although he undoubtedly carried out the descipline of a prison, his appointment required him equally to protect the rights, such as they were, of prisoners.
('26', 425, 1, 13, 1016810) He led me to think that a Superintendent of a prison was, in fact, guardian of the prisoners under his charge.
('26', 425, 1, 14, 1016921) If this is true, the Inspector General is, I take it, the super guardian of prisoners who, therefore, expect him to press their just claims even before the Government, when it happens to overlook or disregard them.
('26', 425, 1, 15, 1017136) A prisoner also expects him not to evade his just inquiries, but to satisfy him in every possible and reasonable way.
('26', 425, 1, 16, 1017254) I am sorry for carrying on this correspondence.
('26', 425, 1, 17, 1017302) But, rightly or wrongly, I believe that even as a prisoner I have certain rights, for example, the right to have pure air, water, food and clothing.
('26', 425, 1, 18, 1017451) Similarly, I have the right to have such mental nourishment given to me as I am used to.
('26', 425, 1, 19, 1017540) I ask for no favours, and if the Inspector General thinks that any single thing or convenience has been given to me as a favours, let it be withdrawn.
('26', 425, 1, 20, 1017691) But this matter of receiving periodicals I consider as important a right as that of receiving suitable food.

('26', 430, 5, 6, 1024960) YERAVDA CENTRAL PRISON, June 29, 1923 THE SUPERINTENDENT YERAVDA CENTRAL PRISON
('26', 430, 6, 7, 1025040) SIR, With reference to my letter of yesterday regarding the flogging of certain Mulshi Peta prisoners, I beg to thank you and the Inspector General for giving me full information about the cause of the punishment.
('26', 430, 6, 8, 1025254) You will recall that, when some months ago similar punishment was awarded to some other Mulshi Peta prisoners, I requested the Government to let me interview all such prisoners with a view to inducing them to conform to jail discipline.
('26', 430, 6, 9, 1025491) The Government were good enough to thank me for the offer, but declined to accept it.
('26', 430, 6, 10, 1025577) I did not press my request further, if only for the reason that I had hoped that occasion would not again arise for flogging such prisoners.
('26', 430, 6, 11, 1025718) But the hope has not been fulfilled and flogging has been resorted to more than once since the one referred to by me.
('26', 430, 6, 12, 1025836) I believe that, if I could see the prisoners, I could induce them to look at their imprisonment in the proper light and not to shirk work or resort to insubordination, as they are said to have done.
('26', 430, 6, 13, 1026035) To enable me to do so from time to time, I request that I may be accommodated with them.
('26', 430, 6, 14, 1026124) If this cannot be done, I request permission to see the prisoners as often as the occasion may require.
('26', 430, 6, 15, 1026228) I am aware that as a prisoner I may not ask or receive such permission, but I respectfully ask it as a human being to serve a humane purpose.
('26', 430, 6, 16, 1026370) The Government, I am sure, cannot wish to see the punishment of flogging inflicted if it can be at all avoided on any prisoner, much less on one who rightly or wrongly regards himself as imprisoned for conscience’ sake.
('26', 430, 6, 17, 1026590) They will appreciate my position when I state that these floggings are most distressing to me, specially
('26', 431, 0, 1, 1026695) 432 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('26', 431, 1, 2, 1026737) as I believe that they can be avoided if I am permitted to live with the prisoners.
('26', 431, 1, 3, 1026821) I venture to trust that the Government will reciprocate the spirit of my letter and not put me, by rejecting my offer of service, in the most awkward position of being compelled to take action, which may, without any such wish on my part, prove embarrassing to them.
('26', 431, 1, 4, 1027088) 1 It is not my purpose whilst undergoing imprisonment to embarrass the Government by any conduct that I can possibly avoid.
('26', 431, 1, 5, 1027212) In view of the fact that some of the prisoners are hunger striking in connection with the matter, I request as early a reply as possible.

('26', 433, 1, 2, 1030547) 197. LETTER TO F. C. GRIFFITHS
('26', 433, 2, 3, 1030578) YERAVDA CENTRAL PRISON July 17, 1923
('26', 433, 3, 4, 1030615) DEAR MR. GRIFFITHS, The Superintendent told me yesterday your reply to my message.
('26', 433, 3, 5, 1030698) Here then is my letter.
('26', 433, 3, 6, 1030722) You told me at the last interview last week that whilst His Excellency was willing to permit me to see the Mulshi Peta Satyagrahi hunger strikers and to issue suitable instructions for preventing the flogging of satyagrahi prisoners except in the case of assaults upon officials, and then, too, after previous sanction by the Government, he did not wish even to seem to consider my proposals under threat of my fasting which my letter of the 9th instant appeared to His Excellency to convey.
('26', 433, 3, 7, 1031214) I repeat here what I told you in the course of our conversation on Thursday last.
('26', 433, 3, 8, 1031296) Nothing was farther from my wish than to issue any threat to the Government.
('26', 433, 3, 9, 1031373) The contemplated fast, as already stated in my said letter, was for me a purely ethical step.
('26', 433, 3, 10, 1031467) As a prisoner, I was bound to inform the Superintendent of my wish to fast in the event of my failing to obtain an interview with the hunger strikers.
('26', 433, 3, 11, 1031618) My fast, I knew, was likely to embarrass the Government which had custody of my body, but I felt that I could not, without doing violence to my inner being, refrain from a clear duty because it might, without any such desire on my part, embarrass the Government if it would not take the course that humanity plainly dictated.
('26', 433, 3, 12, 1031944) To emphasize the meaning I put upon my said letter and the whole of my action since and before in connection with the hunger strike, I told you I was prepared to regard my letter as withdrawn, without in any way admitting that I had intended to issue any threat to the Government, and to believe His Excellency’s assurance that he would have granted my request on merits even if he had not known that I contemplated fasting.
('26', 433, 3, 13, 1032369) And I was thankful that you were authorized to accept my explanation of my letter and to let me see the two of the hunger strikers whose names I mentioned to you.
('26', 433, 3, 14, 1032532) I hope that the instructions regarding flogging have already been issued.
('26', 433, 3, 15, 1032606) If there is any omission or error, you will please not hesitate to tell me.
('26', 433, 4, 16, 1032682) Yours sincerely,
('26', 433, 5, 17, 1032699) From a photostat: S.N. 8032

('26', 436, 3, 4, 1037136) 200. LETTER TO GOVERNOR OF BOMBAY
('26', 436, 4, 5, 1037170) YERAVDA CENTRAL PRISON August 15, 1923 1
('26', 436, 5, 6, 1037211) TO H. E. THE GOVERNOR OF BOMABY SIR, Your Excellency will, I trust, forgive me for referring to our conversation of Monday last.
('26', 436, 5, 7, 1037340) The more I think of what you said about the powers of the Government about framing regulations, and reducing sentences, the more I feel that you are mistaken.
('26', 436, 5, 8, 1037499) I must confess that behind the special division regulations, I have always read not a sincere recognition of the necessity of some such provision, but a reluctant and, therefore, a mere paper concession to some public pressure.
('26', 436, 5, 9, 1037727) But if you are right in thinking that the law gives you no authority to specially classify rigorous imprisonment prisoners or to reduce sentences, I must revise my view of the Government action and rid myself of the suspicion about its motives.
('26', 436, 5, 10, 1037972) I should like to be able to do so all the more as its you tell me you have personally framed the regulations in question.
('26', 436, 5, 11, 1038094) I have always considered you to be the last person to do things weakly or to appear to conciliate public sentiment when you did not wish to.
('26', 436, 5, 12, 1038235) I would be glad, therefore to find that you excluded rigorous imprisonment prisoners from the benefit of the regulations only because the law rendered you helpless.
('26', 436, 5, 13, 1038400) But if your law officers advise you that the law does not prevent you, as you imagine it does, I hope you will do one of the two things: (1) Either remove me and my colleagues mentioned to you by me from the special division or (2) logically include in the special division those rigorous imprisonment prisoners who are accustomed to the same mode of life as we are.
('26', 436, 6, 14, 1038767) 1 Young India has “15th July 1923”, which is a slip.
('26', 437, 0, 1, 1038820) 438 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('26', 437, 1, 2, 1038862) I would ask your Excellency to send for and read my letter of 1st May last addressed to the Superintendent together with this.
('26', 437, 2, 3, 1038989) I remain, Your faithful servant, M. K. GANDHI
('26', 437, 3, 4, 1039035) From a photostat: S.N. 8035; also Young India, 6 3 1924
('26', 437, 4, 5, 1039091) 201. LETTER TO JAIL SUPERINTENDENT, YERAVDA
('26', 437, 5, 6, 1039135) YERAVDA CENTRAL PRISON September 6, 1923
('26', 437, 6, 7, 1039176) THE SUPERINTENDENT YERAVDA CENTRAL PRISON
('26', 437, 7, 8, 1039218) SIR, With reference to the names sent to the Government of certain visitors intending to see me, 2 you have today informed me that the Government have now decided to restrict the number of visitors to be permitted to see me to two, and that of the names sent, only Messrs.
('26', 437, 7, 9, 1039491) Narandas and Devdas Gandhi may be permitted to see me for this quarter’s interview.
('26', 437, 7, 10, 1039575) As the Government have hitherto permitted me to receive five visitors, I must confess that the present decision has come upon me as a surprise.
('26', 437, 7, 11, 1039719) But I welcome the decision inasmuch as they have refused to grant similar permission to my colleague Mr. Yagnik who is kept in the same block with me.
('26', 437, 7, 12, 1039870) Had it not appeared graceless, I would myself have waived the facility which I then saw was exclusively allowed to me.
('26', 437, 7, 13, 1039989) The case, however, of restricting the permission only to Messrs.
('26', 437, 7, 14, 1040054) Narandas and Devdas Gandhi stands on a different footing.
('26', 437, 7, 15, 1040112) If it means that henceforth I am not to see any but such blood relations only as may be allowed, I must deny myself the usual privilege of receiving visitors twice every quarter.
('26', 437, 7, 16, 1040291) I had thought the question of the qualifications of persons who were to be permitted to see me was decided once for all.
('26', 437, 7, 17, 1040412) I have no desire to weary the Government by reiterating the argument contained in the previous correspondence on this subject.
('26', 437, 7, 18, 1040539) I can only state that the three friends whose name have been sent to the Government fall under the category of those who
('26', 437, 8, 19, 1040660) 1 For Gandhiji’s observations made later, while releasing the correspondence in Young India, vide “Comment on Prison Regulations”, 6 3 1924. 2 Vide “Letter to Jail Superintendent, Yeravda”, 26 4 1923.
('26', 438, 0, 1, 1040861) VOL. 26 : 24 JANUARY, 1922 12 NOVEMBER, 1923 439
('26', 438, 1, 2, 1040910) have been permitted to see me since the correspondence referred to by me.
('26', 438, 1, 3, 1040984) And if I may not see these friends, whom I regard in the same light as my blood relations, I must simply not receive any visitors at all.
('26', 438, 1, 4, 1041122) I observe that the Government have taken over a fortnight to give the decision you have conveyed to me.
('26', 438, 1, 5, 1041226) May I ask now for an early decision on this letter, so as to avoid unnecessary suspense both o those who are eager to see me and to myself.
('26', 438, 1, 6, 1041366) I remain, Yours faithfully, M. K GANDHI No.

('26', 438, 2, 8, 1041468) 202. MESSAGE TO MAHOMED ALI 1
('26', 438, 3, 9, 1041498) [YERAVDA PRISON, September 10, 1923] I can send you no message because I am in prison.
('26', 438, 3, 10, 1041585) I have always disapproved of people sending messages from prison.
('26', 438, 3, 11, 1041651) But I may say that I am deeply touched by your loyalty to me.
('26', 438, 3, 12, 1041713) I would, however, ask you not to allow your loyalty to me to weigh with you so much as your loyalty to the country.
('26', 438, 3, 13, 1041829) My views are very well known.
('26', 438, 3, 14, 1041859) I expressed them before I went to jail, and there has been no change in
('26', 438, 4, 15, 1041931) 1 This message seems to have been given to Devdas Gandhi personally when he interviewed Gandhiji in Yeravda Prison, and was conveyed by him to Mahadev De sai, who later quoted it in his article, “Delhi Congress”, in Young India, 4 10 1923. On September 13, according to Mahadev Desai, Mahomed Ali “asked Devdas if Bapu had anything to say to him, and the ‘wireless’ message he jocularly referred to in his speech was then given to him.” This is however worded differently from the message which Mahomed Ali quoted in his speech, in support of the resolution advocating Council entry, at the special Congress session in Bombay on September 12, over which he presided.
('26', 438, 4, 16, 1042598) According to a report in The Hindu, 17 9 1923, the gist of the message from Gandhiji, which Mahomed Ali interpreted to mean as permitting a change in the non co operation programme of the Congress, was as follows: “I do not want you to stick to my programme.
('26', 438, 4, 17, 1042857) I am for the entire programme.
('26', 438, 4, 18, 1042888) But, if looking at the state of the country, you think that one or two items of the boycott programme should be discarded or modified or added to, then in the name of love of country, I command you to give up those parts of my programme of alter them accordingly.” There is, however, no evidence that this message was actually sent by Gandhiji.
('26', 438, 4, 19, 1043233) Vide Mahadev Desai’s, article “Delhi Congress” Young India, 4 10 1923, C. Rajagopalachari’s “Notes”, Young India, 20 9 1923, Pandit Sunderlal’s “Our Immediate Duty”, Young India, 1 11 1923 and finally, V.S. Srinivasa Sastri’s state ment to the Press reproduced in Young India, 17 1 1924.

('26', 439, 2, 5, 1043730) 203. LETTER TO JAIL SUPERINTENDENT, YERAVDA
('26', 439, 3, 6, 1043774) YERAVDA CENTRAL PRISON, November 12, 1923
('26', 439, 4, 7, 1043816) TO THE SUPERINTENDENT YERAVDA CENTRAL PRISON SIR, At the time you told my companion, Mr. Abdul Gani, that the prison rules did not permit you to let him have diet that cost more than the authorized scale, I informed you that your predecessor had allowed all my companions and me to regulate out diet.
('26', 439, 4, 8, 1044117) I further submitted to you that it was awkward for me to enjoy a facility Mr. Abdul Gani could not enjoy and that, therefore, my diet too should be so reduced as to be brought in harmony with the regulations, and the scale allowed to Mr. Abdul Gani.
('26', 439, 4, 9, 1044367) You were good enough to suggest that, for the time being, I should continue the present rations and that I might discuss the matter with the Inspector General, who would shortly visit the prison.
('26', 439, 4, 10, 1044563) I have waited now for over ten days.
('26', 439, 4, 11, 1044600) I feel that if I am to keep the peace of mind, I should wait no longer and, in any case, I have nothing to discuss with the Inspector General.
('26', 439, 4, 12, 1044743) I have no complaint whatsoever to make against your decision regarding.
('26', 439, 4, 13, 1044815) Mr. Abdul Gani.
('26', 439, 4, 14, 1044831) I recognize that you are powerless even if you were minded to help my companion.
('26', 439, 4, 15, 1044912) Nor is it my intention to seek any revision of the prison regulations regarding diet.
('26', 439, 4, 16, 1044998) All I am desirous of doing is to avoid my favoured treatment.
('26', 439, 4, 17, 1045060) You have kindly suggested that my diet scale might have been considered by your predecessor a medical necessity.
('26', 439, 4, 18, 1045173) I know, however, as a matter of fact, that such should not be the case, for my diet has been the same more or less from the time of my admission to this jail; and what is more to the point, my companions and I have, as has been already mentioned, been hitherto permitted to regulate our diet without regard to cost.
('26', 439, 4, 19, 1045489) I propose, therefore, to discontinue oranges and raisins as from Wednesday next.
('26', 439, 4, 20, 1045570) My diet will still exceed the authorized rate.
('26', 439, 4, 21, 1045617) I am not sure that I need 4 lbs.
('26', 439, 4, 22, 1045650) of goat’s milk, but unless you will kindly assist me to further change my diet so as to reduce the cost to the
('26', 440, 0, 1, 1045761) VOL. 26 : 24 JANUARY, 1922 12 NOVEMBER, 1923 441
('26', 440, 1, 2, 1045810) authorized rate, I shall reluctantly continue to take the 4 lbs.
('26', 440, 1, 3, 1045875) of milk and sour limes not exceeding two.
('26', 440, 1, 4, 1045917) I need hardly assure you that I contemplate the reduction in no querulous spirit.
('26', 440, 1, 5, 1045999) I fully sympathize with your decision regarding Mr. Abdul Gani.
('26', 440, 1, 6, 1046063) I propose to make the change purely for my inner peace, and in this I ask for your sympathy and approval.
('26', 440, 1, 7, 1046169) I remain Yours obediently, M. K. GANDHI No.
('26', 440, 2, 8, 1046213) From a photostat: S.N. 8038; also Young India, 6 3 1924

('26', 443, 3, 17, 1051375) Did not observe silence on account of pain.
('26', 443, 3, 18, 1051419) I believe the pain was due to my taking milk and bread as usual at 7 a.m.
('26', 443, 3, 19, 1051493) before the castor oil taken by me early on Saturday morning could act.
('26', 443, 3, 20, 1051564) Once before I had done precisely this.
('26', 443, 3, 21, 1051603) It had done no harm then, but this time it did.
('26', 443, 3, 22, 1051651) I draw two conclusions from this.
('26', 443, 3, 23, 1051685) First, the disease must be digging itself in slowly.
('26', 443, 3, 24, 1051738) Second, this body of mine will not stand the experiment of taking food before the purgative has had its effect.
('26', 443, 3, 25, 1051850) This result is both welcome and painful.
('26', 443, 3, 26, 1051891) God has been testing me on all sides.

('26', 453, 0, 1, 1066117) 454 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('26', 453, 1, 2, 1066159) APPENDICES
('26', 453, 2, 3, 1066170) APPENDIX I
('26', 453, 3, 4, 1066181) GOVERNMENT OF INDIA “COMMUNIQUE” ON GANDHIJI’S LETTER TO VICEROY
('26', 453, 4, 5, 1066246) DELHI, February 6, 1922
('26', 453, 5, 6, 1066270) The Manifesto issued by Mr. Gandhi on the 4th February justifying his determination to resort to mass civil disobedience contains a series of misstatements.
('26', 453, 5, 7, 1066427) Some of these are so important that the Government of India cannot allow them to pass unchallenged.
('26', 453, 5, 8, 1066527) In the first place, they emphatically repudiate the statement that they have embarked on a policy of lawless repression and also the suggestion that the present campaign of civil disobedience has been forced on the non co operation party in order to secure the elementary rights of free association, free speech and of free Press.
('26', 453, 6, 9, 1066858) In limine, the Government of India desire to draw attention to the fact that the decision to adopt a programme of civil disobedience was finally accepted on the 4th November before the recent notifications relating either to the Seditious Meetings Act or the Criminal Law Amendment Act to which Mr. Gandhi unmistakably refers, were issued.
('26', 453, 6, 10, 1067198) It was in consequence of the serious acts of lawlessness committed by persons who professed to be followers of Mr. Gandhi and the non co operation movement that the Government were forced to take measures whichare in strict accordance with the law for protection of peaceful citizens in the pursuit of their lawful avocations.
('26', 453, 6, 11, 1067525) Since the inauguration of the non co operation movement the Government of India, actuated by a desire to avoid anything in the nature of recrudescence of political activity even though it was of an extreme character, have restricted their actions in relation thereto to such measures as were necessary for the maintenance of law and order and the preservation of public tranquillity.
('26', 453, 7, 12, 1067909) Upto November no steps, save in Delhi last year, were taken against the Volunteer Associations.
('26', 453, 7, 13, 1068005) In November, however, the Government were confronted with a new and dangerous situation.
('26', 453, 7, 14, 1068094) In the course of the past year there had been systematic attempts to tamper with the loyalty of the soldiers and the police and there had occurred numerous outbreaks of serious disorder directly attributable to the propaganda of the non co operation party amongst the ignorant and excitable masses.
('26', 453, 7, 15, 1068393) These outbreaks had resulted in grave loss of life, the growth of a dangerous spirit of lawlessness and an increasing disregard for lawful authority.
('26', 453, 7, 16, 1068543) In November they culminated in the grave riots in Bombay in which 53 persons lost their lives and approximately 400 were wounded.
('26', 453, 7, 17, 1068673) On the same date, dangerous manifestations of
('26', 454, 0, 1, 1068719) VOL. 26 : 24 JANUARY, 1922 12 NOVEMBER, 1923 455
('26', 454, 1, 2, 1068768) lawlessness occurred in many other places and at this period it became clear that many of the Volunteer Associations had embarked on a systematic campaign of violence, intimidation and obstruction to combat which proceedings under the Penal Code and the Code of Criminal Procedure had proved ineffective.
('26', 454, 2, 3, 1069073) In these circumstances the Government were reluctantly compelled to resort to
('26', 454, 3, 4, 1069151) measures of a more comprehensive and drastic character.
('26', 454, 4, 5, 1069207) Nevertheless the operation of the Seditious Meetings Act was strictly limited to a few districts in which the risk of grave disturbances of the peace was specially great and the application of the Criminal Law Amendment Act of 1908 was confined to associations, the majority of the members of which had habitually indulged in violence and intimidation.
('26', 454, 4, 6, 1069560) It is impossible here to set out in details the evidence which justified the adoption of these measures in the different provinces.
('26', 454, 4, 7, 1069692) Abundant proof is, however, to be found in the published proceedings of the various legislative bodies, in the communiques of different local Governments, and in the pronouncements of the heads of provinces.
('26', 454, 4, 8, 1069900) While resolute in their determination to enforce respect for law and order and to protect loyal and peaceful subjects of the Crown, the Government have at the same time taken every precaution possible to mitigate where desirable the conditions of imprisonment and to avoid any action which might have the appearance of vindictive severity.
('26', 454, 4, 9, 1070240) Ample proof of this will be found in the orders issued by local Governments.
('26', 454, 4, 10, 1070317) Numerous offenders have been released, sentences have been reduced and special consideration has been shown in the case of persons convicted of offences under the Seditious Meetings Act or the Criminal Law Amendment Act.
('26', 454, 4, 11, 1070538) There is then no shadow of justification for the charge that their policy has been one of indiscriminate and lawless repression.
('26', 454, 5, 12, 1070667) A further charge which has been brought by Mr. Gandhi is that the recent measures of Government have involved a departure from the civilized policy laid down by His Excellency at the time of the apology of the Ali Brothers, namely, that the Government of India should not interfere with the activities of non co operation so long as they remained non violent in word and deed.
('26', 454, 5, 13, 1071044) The following citation from the communique of the Government of India issued on the 30th May conclusively disproves the statement.
('26', 454, 5, 14, 1071175) After explaining that in view of the solemn undertaking contained in the statement over their signatures, it had been decided to refrain from instituting criminal proceeding against Messrs Mahomed Ali and Shaukat Ali, the Government of India observed: “It must not be inferred from the original determination of the Government to prosecute for speeches inciting to violence that promoting disaffection of a less violent character is not an offence against the law.
('26', 454, 5, 15, 1071640) The Government of India desire to make it plain that they will enforce the law relating to offences against the State as and when they may think fit against any persons who have committed breaches of it.”
('26', 455, 0, 1, 1071845) 456 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('26', 455, 1, 2, 1071887) It remains with the Government of India to deal with the allegation that His Excellency summarily rejected the proposal for a conference although the terms put forward by the Conference at Bombay and accepted by the Working Committee of the Congress were “quite in keeping with His Excellency’s own requirement as indicated in his speech at Calcutta”.
('26', 455, 1, 3, 1072239) How far this is far from being the case will be manifested from a comparison of His Excellency’s speech with the terms proposed by the Conference.
('26', 455, 1, 4, 1072386) His Excellency in that speech insisted on the imperative necessity as a fundamental condition precedent to the discussion of any question by a conference, of the discontinuance of the unlawful activities of the non co operation party.
('26', 455, 1, 5, 1072621) No assurance on this point was, however, contained in the proposals advanced by the Conference.
('26', 455, 1, 6, 1072717) On the contrary whilst the Government were asked to make concessions which not only included the withdrawal of the notifications under the Criminal Law Amendment, and Seditious Meetings Acts and the release of persons convicted thereunder, but also the release of the persons convicted of offences designed to affect the loyalty of the army and the submission to an arbitration committee of the cases of other persons convicted under the ordinary law of the land, there was no suggestion that any of the illegal activities of the non co operators other than hartals, picketing and civil disobedience should cease.
('26', 455, 1, 7, 1073331) Moreover, it was evident from the statements made by Mr. Gandhi at the Conference that he intended to continue the enrolment of volunteers in prohibited associations and the preparations for civil disobedience.
('26', 455, 1, 8, 1073542) Further Mr. Gandhi also made it apparent that the proposed Round Table Conference would be called merely to register his decrees.
('26', 455, 1, 9, 1073672) It is idle to suggest that terms of this character fulfilled in any way the essentials laid down by His Excellency or can reasonably be described as having been made in response to the sentiments expressed by him.
('26', 455, 2, 10, 1073886) Finally, the Government of India desire to draw attention to the demands put forward in the concluding paragraph of Mr. Gandhi’s present manifesto which exceeded even the demands made by the Working Committee of the Congress.
('26', 455, 2, 11, 1074112) Mr. Gandhi’s demands now include, (1) the release of all prisoners convicted or under trial for non violent activities (2) a guarantee that the Government will refrain from interference with all non violent activities of the non co operation party, even though they fall within the purview of the Indian Penal Code or in other words an undertaking that Government will indefinitely hold in abeyance in regard to the non co operators the ordinary and the long established laws of the land.
('26', 455, 2, 12, 1074601) In return for these concessions he indicates that he intends to continue the illegal and seditious propaganda and operations of the non co operation party and merely offers to postpone civil disobedience of an aggressive character until the offenders now in jail have had an opportunity of reviewing the whole situation.
('26', 455, 2, 13, 1074922) In the same paragraph he reaffirms the unalterable character of the demands of his party.
('26', 455, 3, 14, 1075012) The Government of India are confident that all right thinking citizens will
('26', 456, 0, 1, 1075088) VOL. 26 : 24 JANUARY, 1922 12 NOVEMBER, 1923 457
('26', 456, 1, 2, 1075137) recognize that this manifesto constitutes no response whatever to the speech of His Excellency at Calcutta and the demands made are such as no Government could discuss much Iess accept.
('26', 456, 1, 3, 1075323) The alternatives that now confront the people of India are such as sophistry can no longer obscure or disguise.
('26', 456, 1, 4, 1075435) The issue is no longer between this or that programme of political advance but between lawlessness with all its dangerous consequences on the one hand, and on the other, the maintenance of those principles which lie at the root of all civilized governments.
('26', 456, 1, 5, 1075693) Mass civil disobedience is fraught with such dangers to the State that it must be met with sternness and severity.
('26', 456, 1, 6, 1075808) The Government entertain no doubt that in any measures which they have to take for its suppression they can count on the support and assistance of all law abiding and loyal citizens of His Majesty.
('26', 456, 2, 7, 1076006) India in 1921 22, pp.
('26', 456, 3, 8, 1076028) APPENDIX II
('26', 456, 4, 9, 1076040) LETTER FROM HAKIM AJMAL KHAN
('26', 456, 5, 10, 1076069) AHMEDABAD, March 17, 1922
('26', 456, 6, 11, 1076095) MY DEAR MAHATMAJI,
('26', 456, 7, 12, 1076114) I have received the letter which you wrote to me from Sabarmati Jail and thank you very sincerely for the kind sentiments that you have expressed towards me.
('26', 456, 7, 13, 1076272) Whether I really deserve them is another question into which I do not propose to enter.
('26', 456, 8, 14, 1076360) I am glad that Mr. Shankerlal Banker is with you in the jail.
('26', 456, 8, 15, 1076422) He has great affection for you and possesses qualities which have endeared him to you.
('26', 456, 8, 16, 1076509) I feel sure that his company in jail will be source of extra pleasure and satisfaction to you.
('26', 456, 9, 17, 1076604) I can, however, feel happy at your arrest only when I find that, as a mark of the profound respect that it has for you, the country takes still greater interest in the national movement than it did when you, were free.
('26', 456, 9, 18, 1076823) But it gives me infinite pleasure to see that the country observed perfect peace on your arrest.
('26', 456, 9, 19, 1076920) This is a clear sign of the spread of the spirit of non violence in the country, which is as essential for our success as pure air is for life.

('26', 461, 4, 6, 1089052) INNER TEMPLE ORDER
('26', 461, 5, 7, 1089071) The official order of the Inner Temple Bench disbarring Mr. Gandhi runs as follows: “Inner Temple: At a Parliament holden on Friday, the 10th day of November, 1992. “Whereas at a Bench Table holden on the 9th day of November 1922 the treasurer having reported that he had received a certified copy of the conviction and sentence to six years’ imprisonment of Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi, a barrister of this Inn, at the court of the Sessions Judge, Ahmedabad, India, on the 18th March, 1922, for sedition.” “It was ordered that the said Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi, having been convicted by a competent tribunal of an offence which, in the opinion of the Bench, disqualifies him from continuing a member of the Inn, should have his name removed from the books.”
('26', 461, 6, 8, 1089831) “And at the same Bench Table it was further ordered that at the Parliament to be holden on Friday 10th November, 1922, the said Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi should be disbarred and his name removed from the books of the Society and that this order be communicated to the judges of the Supreme Court of Judicature, to the other Inns of Court, to the General Council of the Bar and by registered letter to the said Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi, and be screened in the Hall.”
('26', 461, 7, 9, 1090300) This was confirmed at the Parliament of the Inner Temple held on November 10. Amrita Bazar Patrika, 21 12 1922
